title: Terms and Conditions of Use
description: Please Read These Terms and Conditions of Use Carefully Before Using This Site By using this site and all other registered UCR web sites, referred to as "these sites", you agree to these terms of use. If you do not agree to these terms of use, please do not use this site.

title: Privacy Policy
description: Policy The University of California, Riverside is committed to ensuring the privacy and accuracy of your confidential information to the extent possible, subject to provisions of state and federal law. Other than as required by laws that guarantee public access to certain types of information, or in response to subpoenas or other legal instruments that authorize access, personally-identifiable information is not actively shared. In particular, we do not re-distribute or sell personal information collected on our web servers.

title: Out-of-State
description: UCR believes that out-of-state students add an important and valuable depth to our campus. Our award-winning faculty will mentor you. Our diverse campus community will embrace you. And our dedicated resources will help you build your future! Sunny Southern California invites you to make the University of California, Riverside your home away from home.

title: Faculty
description: Faculty at UC Riverside thrive within America’s most prestigious public university system — and on one of the most dynamic campuses in the nation. UCR was America’s fastest rising university, according to the U.S. News 2019 rankings, and placed among the top 1 percent of universities worldwide, according to the 2018-19 Center for World University Rankings.  Our faculty members educate and elevate our students, our future leaders, while simultaneously creating visionary solutions and conducting path-breaking research of their own to address the greatest challenges facing our community and world. We make sure they have the resources, support, and stimulation they need to persevere. Among our distinguished faculty are two Nobel Prize winners, and 13 members of the National Academies of Science and Medicine. In fact, we are one of fewer than 20 public U.S. universities to boast multiple Nobel Prize winners on our faculty.  Every day, our diverse faculty bring an entrepreneurial spirit to education, showcasing what a public university is capable of in the 21st century. Through their interdisciplinary mindsets and shared commitment to collaborative inquiry, they are effecting the kind of transformative change that proves no barriers are too great at UCR.

title: Staff
description: Staff members at UC Riverside take pride in working for an institution that continually creates meaningful experiences for all Highlanders — and is rising in the ranks of national prominence. UCR was ranked the fastest rising university in America by U.S. News in 2019 and in the Top 30 of institutions dedicated to the public good by Washington Monthly in 2018. We want to create something better — on our campus and beyond — and our inspiring and dedicated staff helps us do just that. Without a doubt, the work we do daily to create transformative change on local, national, and global scales could not be done without them. And just as our staff helps to build better tomorrows by supporting UCR’s mission of research, teaching, and public service, we empower them and encourage their success through our unwavering support, resources, and mentorship — and outstanding benefits. That includes being on a campus situated in an ideal locale for work-life balance: In addition to all the vibrant city of Riverside has to offer, it’s also just a short drive from exquisite mountains, desert, and the beach.

title: Older adults may achieve same cognition as undergrads

The finding affirms a long-held assertion of the lead researcher, Rachel Wu, who is an associate professor of psychology at UC Riverside. That is, older adults can learn new tasks and improve their cognition in the process, if they approach learning as a child does.

title: Navigating the $1.9 trillion stimulus

It also includes a restaurant rescue fund, money for reopening schools, and funding for state and local governments, among other items. As many among us await stimulus checks, we asked Jana Grittersova, a UCR economist and associate professor of political science, to weigh in on the implications of the stimulus.

title: Doctors urged to reconsider controversial acne drug

But UCR researcher Misaki Natsuaki, one of the study’s authors, said severe acne itself, when left untreated, poses a serious risk for depression and anxiety.

description: UCR's John Martin Fischer examines near-death experiences through a philosophical lens

title: 'Hypervisibility' for Black girls; 'invisibility' for Black women
description: Being a Black female might involve navigating two extremes: too little attention when you’re older, and too much of the wrong kind of attention when you’re young.

title: Resources to better understand race, racism, and policing
description: Read, watch, and listen to these 60-plus recommendations from UCR faculty and staff members

title: This UCR historian once trained horses; now she studies them
description: Doctoral student Katrin Boniface turns a lifelong passion into research for a growing field: equine history

title: Grad Slam spotlights emerging UCR scholars and scientists
description: The annual competition returns to UC Riverside’s Culver Center on March 4 and Palm Desert Center on April 4

title: From foster care to a free MBA
description: “I have been through a few challenges in my life, but with the support of this school and Guardian Scholars, I have achieved more than I ever thought I would.” - Brandy Renee Taylor

title: ‘There are scholars working here’
description: The Center for Ideas and Society celebrates 30 years of bridging interdisciplinary gaps with Oct. 29 anniversary event

title: A Highlander DREAMer's dilemma
description: Gabriela Martinez is nervous about her trip to Washington D.C. Not because she’s going to be in the same building as the President of the United States. Nah, it isn't that. She’s nervous because this trip to the 2023 State of the Union, or SOTU, is the same week as her econ midterm.

title: Upgrading struggle meals with the Cooking Well series
description: If you don’t know what a struggle meal is, we envy your food security.  For the rest of us, perfecting the art of upgrading inexpensive foods so that they’re tastier is a skill many low-on-funds people know too well.

title: Human skin can be damaged by exposure to thirdhand smoke and electronic cigarette spills
description: A relatively short exposure is sufficient to cause the damage, UC Riverside study finds

title: UC Riverside to host 42nd-annual Writers Week
description: Writers Week, California’s longest-running free literary event, will return to the University of California, Riverside, for its 42nd installment Feb. 4-5 and Feb. 11-16, 2019, featuring 22 writers across the two-week span.

title: UCR’s first family makes new commitment to support students
description: Chancellor Kim Wilcox and his wife, Diane Del Buono, previously created the 13th Chancellor’s Research Fellowship

title: Confronting loss and loneliness in “If You Have to Go”
description: Loneliness, while inherently isolating, is also a universal experience. This dichotomy lies at the heart of poet Katie Ford’s newest collection, “If You Have to Go.” Dominated by a crown of 39 sonnets — each linked by the repetition of the last line of a poem as the first line of the next — the book unfolds as a dreamlike narrative loosely threaded together by one solitary, longing voice.

title: Authors, schedule announced for 45th Writers Week
description: The February 2022 festival will be virtual. Lifetime Achievement Awards and Costo Medals will be presented to literary giants Sandra Cisneros, Linda Hogan, and Ishmael Reed.

title: Physicists explain how large spherical viruses form
description: UC Riverside-led study deciphers key elements for the assembly of a large virus; understanding its formation could contain viruses’ spread

title: New method identifies adaptive mutations in complex evolving populations
description: UC Riverside study focused on how HIV mutates to escape the immune system

title: New multicampus consortium to study assembly of coronaviruses
description: Host campus UC Riverside will be joined by UC Davis and UC Merced

title: Moiré patterns facilitate discovery of novel insulating phases
description: UC Riverside-led study observed unexpected insulating phases by placing electrons on stacked monolayers of 2D semiconductors

title: Veteran and community college transfer student heads to UCLA for graduate studies
description: When he joined the U.S. Navy in 2010, Mychal Valle didn’t think he would ever return to school. After all, he got to work on new radar technologies in the navy and got recognized for writing technical manuals. But by the time he left the navy in 2016, Valle’s service helped him discover his passion: a career in science.

title: Searching for elusive supersymmetric particles
description: UC Riverside physicist on a team that conducted experiments at the Large Hadron Collider

title: A new dimension in the quest to understand dark matter
description: UC Riverside dark matter research program targets assumptions about particle physics

title: ‘Twisting’ atomic materials may convert light into electricity
description: US Army grant to UC Riverside will support the study of the science of light and its interaction with matter

title: Historian’s database offers new view of colonial California
description: Through his Pobladores Project, Steven Hackel spotlights the non-American Indian settlers and soldiers who lived in California between 1769 and 1850

title: UC Riverside study busts myths about gossip
description: A first-of-its-kind UC Riverside study asserts that women don’t gossip negatively more often than men, lower income people don’t gossip more than more wealthy people, and younger people are more likely to gossip negatively than their older counterparts.

title: Summer internships — from home
description: These UCR students aren’t letting a pandemic stop their personal and professional development.

title: Beyond Brilliant: Cam Calkins: The secret ingredient is love
description: UCR Dining Services employee donates $52,000 to the Graduate School of Education, and an additional $10,000 to the R'Pantry.

title: $4.8 million grant to benefit students, support community service projects
description: UCR is one of 45 colleges and universities participating in this statewide program.

title: 10 years of student wellness
description: The Well, UCR’s nonclinical health promotion center, celebrates a decade of achievements with an open house.

title: Highlander Pep Band surprises campus with hype song
description: Imagine you’re sitting in class on a random Thursday morning, listening to your chemistry professor, and then a 15-piece band bursts in the room blasting the Macklemore and Ryan Lewis throwback hit, “Can’t Hold Us” — but the tuba, symbols, trumpet, and flute version. If you were on campus on May 18, you didn’t have to imagine it because it happened in real life — and the UC Riverside Highlander Pep Band filled random locations around campus with music while a camera crew filmed crowd reactions.

title: Flame retardants linked to autistic-like behavior
description: UC Riverside-led study shows maternal transfer of PBDEs causes brain changes in female mice offspring

title: How are epilepsy and autism linked?
description: UC Riverside and Rutgers University scientists explore this question in a study on mice

title: Scientists find thirdhand smoke affects cells in humans
description: UC Riverside-led study is the first to find an association between thirdhand smoke and gene expression in humans

title: Sniffing your way to the gym
description: Exercise motivation could be linked to certain smells, UC Riverside mouse study finds

title: Book taps into the racier aspects of plant sex
description: Now that UC Riverside professor Norman Ellstrand has your attention, he’d like to teach you about genetics

title: Thirdhand smoke exposure linked to fabric type, heat, and humidity
description: UC Riverside-led team developed simple, rapid method to assess contaminants in household fabrics

title: Tiny particle, big payoff
description: UC Riverside scientists have solved a 20-year-old genetics puzzle that could result in ways to protect wheat, barley, and other crops from a devastating infection.  Ayala Rao, professor of plant pathology and microbiology, has been studying Brome Mosaic virus for decades. Unlike some viruses, the genetic material of this virus is divided into three particles that until now were impossible to tell apart.

title: How specificity of the brain is wired
description: UC Riverside mouse study identifies key molecules that determine specificity of neural circuits

title: Scientists image conducting edges in a promising 2-D material
description: Experimental study done at UC Riverside and University of Washington on monolayer tungsten ditelluride could lead to more energy-efficient electronic devices

title: Scientists identify genetic mechanism involved in how females inherit traits
description: Research could help reduce females’ susceptibility to several diseases, such as Fragile X and Rett syndromes

title: Teaching the teachers
description: Weeklong Summer Physics Teacher Academy at UC Riverside serves a large region in Southern California

title: Keto diet may not work for women
description: Scientists from UC Riverside are studying how the popular keto and intermittent fasting diets work on a molecular level, and whether both sexes benefit from them equally.

title: In search of dark matter
description: Particle physicist Hai-Bo Yu is an assistant professor of physics and astronomy at UC Riverside. (I. Pittalwala, UCR)

title: Physicists explain mysterious dark matter deficiency in galaxy pair
description: A new theory about the nature of dark matter helps explain why a pair of galaxies about 65 million light-years from Earth contains very little of the mysterious matter, according to a study led by a physicist at the University of California, Riverside. Dark matter is nonluminous and cannot be seen directly. Thought to make up 85% of matter in the universe, its nature is not well understood. Unlike normal matter, it does not absorb, reflect, or emit light, making it difficult to detect.

title: Economic Crisis Response Team ensures students receive food and shelter
description: The interdepartmental group has received dozens of requests for support since campus closure.

title: Dining, library, student services reopenings announced
description: For 18 months, the most consistent signs of life at the UC Riverside campus have involved spitting nocturnal sprinklers. That’s about to change. The campus is preparing for a full return in fall quarter, for which classes begin on Sept. 23. Long-shuttered dining halls and coffee joints are opening, along with essential student services.

title: UCR begins construction of new Student Health and Counseling Center
description: UC Riverside will begin construction this week on a Student Health and Counseling Center that will bring together health and wellness services at an accessible, modern facility. A groundbreaking ceremony will be held Friday, Feb. 18 for the planned two-story building located on the western portion of Parking Lot 21, south of Linden Street, between Aberdeen Drive and Pentland Way. Construction is anticipated to take over a year with the center opening to students by May 2023.

title: Students' summer impact
description: Summer break does not translate into idle hours for these three UC Riverside students.  For Bela Mendoza, a three-month summer internship with Riverside’s Operation SafeHouse, a youth emergency shelter, has given her an inside look at how to make a bigger — and more positive — impact in the lives of teens facing issues such as foster care, depression, homelessness, and human trafficking. At one point, she too experienced foster care and homelessness.

title: Cancer Patients’ Conversation Topics Reflect Well-Being, Study Finds
description: Substantive dialogue may help, but emotional exchanges likely don't. Research finds that substantive conversation – conversation about news and ideas – is reflective of greater well-being among breast cancer patients.

title: Early intervention following traumatic brain injury reduces epilepsy risk
description: UC Riverside-led rat study finds an immune receptor in the hippocampus is responsible for the onset of the disease after brain injuries

title: $1 million project helps tribal nations adapt to climate change
description: UC Riverside ecologists are leading a $1 million plant protection project that will help Southern California’s tribal nations adapt to climate change.

title: Geckos might lose their tails, but not their dinner
description: A new UC Riverside study finds geckos are fierce hunters whether or not their tails are attached to their bodies.

title: How mountain streams signal climate change
description: A new tool designed by UC Riverside researchers can better assess an overlooked indicator of global warming: the variety of bugs, worms, and snails living in high mountain streams.

title: Antibiotics wreak havoc on athletic performance
description: By killing essential gut bacteria, antibiotics ravage athletes’ motivation and endurance. The UC Riverside-led mouse study suggests the microbiome is a big factor separating athletes from couch potatoes.

title: New research bites holes into theories about Megalodons
description: A new study leaves large tooth marks in previous conclusions about the body shape of the Megalodon, one of the largest sharks that ever lived.

title: Better predicting how plants and animals will weather climate extremes
description: A team of scientists led by UC Riverside has devised a more accurate way to predict the effects of climate change on plants and animals — and whether some will survive at all.

title: Controlling deadly malaria without chemicals
description: Scientists have finally found malaria’s Achilles’ heel, a neurotoxin that isn’t harmful to any living thing except Anopheles mosquitoes that spread malaria.

title: Humans bite back by deactivating mosquito sperm
description: New UC Riverside research makes it likely that proteins responsible for activating mosquito sperm can be shut down, preventing them from swimming to or fertilizing eggs.

title: UCR experts discuss the J&J vaccine 'pause'
description: Even as vaccinations across the U.S. were ramping up due to the popularity and availability of the one-dose Johnson & Johnson vaccine, the CDC called a timeout due to reports of serious blood clots

title: New material shows high potential for quantum computing
description: Research by UC Riverside-MIT team focuses on quantum phenomena in gold

title: Experts on Diversity and the Oscars
description: Diversity and the Oscars The 93rd Academy Awards are scheduled for Sunday, April 25, 2021. Experts from the University of California, Riverside are available to discuss various Academy Awards topics, including diversity, acting, gender, culture, and more.  For fast access to experts, TEXT or call the 24-hour-experts hotline at 951-312-3049, or email news@ucr.edu

title: Study shows how memory function could be preserved after brain injury
description: UC Riverside-led study identifies role played by an immune signaling molecule in regulating memory function in the normal and injured brain

title: Psychologist receives high honor from NAACP
description: Carolyn Murray is a professor of psychology at UC Riverside. (I. Pittalwala/UCR)

title: Mentoring by text message
description: UCR’s Campus Collective has more than 2,000 mentees in four months.

title: Immigrant Asian American women may be at higher risk for breast cancer
description: Research highlights differences in risk among Asian American women who immigrated versus their U.S.-born counterparts

title: Expanding the vision of queer dance
description: The two-day Explode! Queer Dance Festival will showcase artists from across the United States and around the world, featuring contemporary dance, improvisation, and drag.

title: UC Riverside startup receives National Science Foundation grant
description: Small Business Innovation Research Program provides seed funding for BEAM-CA, LLC

title: UCR celebrates 25 years of dance and scholarship
description: A Feb. 9 event commemorates the Department of Dance’s critical dance studies program. The day-long celebration will feature performances, talks, and roundtable discussions.

title: Breast cancer study by UCR medical student could help patients live longer
description: Surgery is associated with increased survival for patients with HER2-positive stage 4 breast cancer

title: Ecopipam reduces stuttering symptoms in proof-of-concept trial
description: UC Riverside-led open-label pilot study leads to a double-blind clinical trial to further test ecopipam’s efficacy and safety in adult patients who stutter

title: Decoding race, monstrosity, and desire in ‘Candyman’
description: “Reflection Eternal,” on view at the Culver Center of the Arts Aug. 31-Jan. 19, unpacks the iconic horror film figure

title: Washington Monthly ranks UCR No. 28 public university
description: In its 2021 ranking of top national universities, Washington Monthly magazine has named UC Riverside No. 28 among public universities in the U.S.  In the subcategory of social mobility, UCR was No. 29 among the 380 four-year universities ranked in Washington Monthly’s 2021 list. UCR’s social mobility ranking was No. 34 in 2020. In the category of research, UCR also climbed, from No. 65 in the nation in 2020, to No. 57 in 2021.

title: Silver linings playbook: Think bad news before it's delivered
description: Psychologists have known there’s value in finding a “silver lining,” in coaxing oneself through bad news. You didn’t get the job? Just as well: That new boss seemed edgy during the interview. Someone outbid you at the last second for that antique something-or-other on eBay? You didn’t really have the money to spend anyway. Those coping strategies result in less depression, and greater life satisfaction and self-esteem. Finding silver linings can even mean better physical health.

title: Pent up consumer demand to drive rapid economic recovery in Inland Empire
description: Vaccine rollout, easing of public health mandates boosts local economic outlook

title: Top-performing soil microbes could be key to sustainable agriculture
description: UCR research will help agronomists breed plants that attract their own growth-promoting microbes

title: Study explains why tall individuals are more prone to cancer
description: UC Riverside evolutionary biologist says increased cancer risk associated with height is due primarily to an increase in the number of body cells

title: Professor receives grant to study how fish hunt
description: NSF grant will support research on how fish coordinate different body parts to catch prey

title: Size matters — To livebearer fish, big fins are a big deal
description: Females love males with big dorsal fins, but the appendages first evolved for males to fight other males

title: Study provides insights into how Zika virus suppresses the host immune system
description: A research team led by scientists at the University of California, Riverside, has outlined how the Zika virus, which constituted an epidemic threat in 2016, suppresses the immune system of its host. The Zika virus, or ZIKV, spreads through mosquito bites and sexual intercourse. Currently, no approved vaccine or antivirals against ZIKV exist.

title: Sugar-poor diets wreak havoc on bumblebee queens’ health
description: UC Riverside study shows that without adequate sugar, a bumblebee queen’s fat body, which functions like a human liver, does not correctly produce enzymes required for healthy metabolism and detoxification from pesticides.

title: Guppies teach us why evolution happens
description: Guppies, a perennial pet store favorite, have helped a UC Riverside scientist unlock a key question about evolution: Do animals evolve in response to the risk of being eaten, or to the environment that they create in the absence of predators? Turns out, it’s the latter.

title: How giant-faced owls snag voles hidden in snow
description: Great gray owls’ physical features, especially parts of their wings and face, help them correct for sonic distortions caused by snow, enabling them to find moving food with astonishing accuracy, according to a new UC Riverside study.

title: Psychologist to study how motor development changes infants’ learning experiences
description: John Franchak has long been interested in how learning a new motor skill, such as sitting or walking, changes how infants interact with their surroundings. He has now been awarded a grant from the National Science Foundation to pursue this research question.

title: Beyond Brilliant: Born to succeed
description: Elñora Tena Webb grew up in the foster care system; UCR gave her a clean canvas and after becoming a college president, she is now a success coach .

title: UCR marks 20 years of Spanish-language orientations
description: More than 100 parents are scheduled to attend the July 19 session.

title: $1.28 million awarded to UCR’s Native American Student Programs
description: The 10-year grant is a gift from the San Manuel Band of Mission Indians

title: UC report: UCR sends largest number of acceptance letters to California freshmen within UC system
description: The campus also issued the most welcome letters to African American, first-generation, low-income, and a percentage of community college transfers.

title: UCR brings back Pow Wow Princess tradition
description: After a 22-year hiatus, Katianna Warren is the second princess since the competition was reinstated in 2017.

title: Hope on the horizon for treating stroke
description: UC Riverside biomedical scientist’s decades-long work moves to clinical trials

title: UCR to host California attorney general debate
description: Primary candidates Xavier Becerra, Steven Bailey, Eric Early, and Dave Jones will convene at UCR's Culver Center on May 15

title: Leaving it all to chance
description: Douglas McCulloh is not a man ruled by fate, but rather, chance. In fact, McCulloh, who joined UCR ARTS as the new senior curator for the California Museum of Photography, or CMP, in July has made chance his primary modus operandi. He traces his preoccupation with chance back to his parents — a geologist and an Austrian refugee — inheriting notions of deep time and geologic inconsequence from his father and proof that life can change in an instant from his mother, who was forced to flee Europe during her childhood.

title: Graphic Novel Adaptation of “Kindred” Nominated for Eisner Award
description: John Jennings discusses the challenge of transforming the beloved classic into a best-selling graphic novel.

title: Graphic Novelist John Jennings pens essay for Marvel’s forthcoming “Marvel’s Voices” anthology
description: In an essay for Marvel, Jennings lends his voice to discuss the forthcoming “Marvel’s Voices,” a new one-shot anthology series.

title: UCR offers the first Cahuilla language course in UC system
description: Students in the four-class series also study Cahuilla society and culture.

title: Graphic Novelist John Jennings reflects on relevance of X-Men story ‘God Loves, Man Kills’ in an essay for Marvel
description: In an essay for Marvel, John Jennings, a professor of media and cultural studies, reflects on the 1982 graphic novel “X-Men: God Loves, Man Kills” by Chris Claremont and Brent Anderson, which is being re-released this year in a two-part extended cut.

title: ARTSblock exhibition features public’s work alongside artist’s
description: The Culver Center will host an exhibition featuring photography submitted by the community in conjunction with installations by Xavier Cázares Cortéz

title: An 'awe-full' state of mind may set you free
description: An induced feeling of awe, or state of wonder, may be the best strategy yet for alleviating the discomfort that comes from uncertain waiting. Kate Sweeny’s research explores the most excruciating form of waiting: the period during which one awaits uncertain news, the outcome of which is beyond one’s control. It’s waiting for news from a biopsy, or whether you aced — or tanked — the exam. That’s distinguished from waiting periods such as when looking for a new job, when you have at least some control over the outcome.

title: Tetris: It could be the salve for a worried mind
description: Tetris could be the salve for a worried mind.  The venerable video game was used in a recent experiment to create a state of “flow” – the term psychologists use to describe a state of mind so engaged it makes the rest of the world fall away, and time pass more quickly. UCR researcher Kate Sweeny and her team have found that state of perfect disengagement may improve the otherwise-emotionally unpleasant experience of awaiting uncertain news.

title: KD Ganaway exhibition coming to the California Museum of Photography
description: UCR’s California Museum of Photography will showcase the work of King Daniel (KD) Ganaway, one of the earliest Black photographers in the U.S. The exhibition runs Feb. 25 - Aug. 6.

title: Researchers identify new approach for controlling dengue fever and Zika virus
description: UC Riverside study uses gene-editing tool to disrupt serotonin receptor linked to egg production in Aedes aegypti mosquitoes

title: Ancestor of all animals identified in Australian fossils
description: A wormlike creature that lived more than 555 million years ago is the earliest bilaterian

title: High-speed videos capture how kangaroo rat escapes rattlesnake attack
description: Bipedalism may have been favored in kangaroo rats to avoid ambush predators like vipers and owls, says UC Riverside biologist

title: Environmental threats put bumblebee queens under pressure
description: Insecticide exposure and declining floral diversity are jeopardizing key pollinator group

title: As bumblebee diets narrow, ours could too
description: There has been a lot of buzz about honeybees’ failing health because they pollinate our produce. Less well known is how critical bumblebees are for some of our favorite foods. And their numbers are also rapidly declining. A new study from the University of California, Riverside, reveals the loss of plant diversity harms the humble bumble at a critical stage in its development from egg to adult.

title: Ladies’ choice: What drives faster, flashier formation of new animal species
description: Evolution is actually a Sadie Hawkins dance, as new research shows females not only determine whether male animals develop bright colors, but also how fast new species develop.

title: Childhood diet and exercise creates healthier, less anxious adults
description: Exercise and a healthy diet in childhood leads to adults with bigger brains and lower levels of anxiety, according to new UC Riverside research in mice.

title: Rodolfo H. Torres to be appointed Vice Chancellor for Research and Economic Development
description: Torres is a distinguished mathematician whose work has been supported by the National Science Foundation

title: Oregon state leader with passion for student success to lead Undergraduate Education
description: Jennifer Brown has been named vice provost and dean of Undergraduate Education at UCR, effective Aug. 1, 2018

title: UCR ecologists work toward post-fire rebirth of healthy landscapes
description: The worst fire impacts this year are predicted to hit Northern California’s higher elevation forests and Southern California’s chaparral-clad mountainous National Forest lands. To aid recovery, UC Riverside ecologists are collaborating with the US Forest Service to target these spots with new post-fire ecological restoration strategies.

title: Even Sonoran Desert plants aren’t immune to climate change
description: In North America’s hottest, driest desert, climate change is causing the decline of plants once thought nearly immortal and replacing them with shorter shrubs that can take advantage of sporadic rainfall and warmer temperatures.

title: Early humans thrived in this drowned South African landscape
description: The Paleo-Agulhas Plain had diverse, verdant ecosystems and abundant game

title: “Fictive Kin” questions how we view the everyday
description: A new exhibition showcasing the photography of contemporary artists Sarah Conaway, Annette Kelm, and Kim Schoen will debut at the Culver Center of the Arts at UCR ARTSblock on Feb. 24. Much information in our daily lives is consumed through visual cues, like billboards blinking by on a highway, with little time to question authenticity. “Fictive Kin” invites viewers to consider the often-unconscious assumptions we make when looking at photos.

title: Exhibition explores 20th Century through the lens of dust
description: A peculiar photograph leads to an examination of modernity, war, and ruin in “A Handful of Dust”

title: UCR Ph.D. student curates Riverside Art Museum Exhibition
description: Running Feb. 3 through Dec. 30, 2018, the show features a selection of Mesoamerican artifacts on public display for the very first time

title: Indigenous philharmonic musicians will perform repertoire of mexican music
description: UCR will host four bands, all formed in Los Angeles by Mexican immigrants from the southern state of Oaxaca, Mexico

title: Come say ‘barn voyage’ to beloved eatery before its renovation
description: The Barn will close June 14 for an 18-month renovation

title: More than books: discover UC Riverside’s Tomás Rivera Library
description: Puppets, art book collections, literature in various languages, and water faucets that date back to the 1950s

title: Hot or cold, venomous vipers still quick to strike
description: Most reptiles move slower when temperatures drop, but venomous rattlesnakes appear to be an exception. The cold affects them, but not as much as scientists expected.

title: Scorpions outdo spiders as scary creatures
description: Although spider fear is one of the most common and well-studied phobias, UCR-led study shows people are more afraid of scorpions

title: Two new creatures discovered from dawn of animal life
description: Names of recently discovered Ediacaran era fossil animals honor President Barack Obama and Sir David Attenborough

title: Special journal issue looks for new clues about old life
description: Collection edited by UCR researchers focuses on the role of rising oxygen in the birth of complex life

title: UC Riverside partners with City of Riverside on Eastside revitalization project
description: CE-CERT will track greenhouse gas reductions, indicators of public health, and economic impacts from the $31 million dollar project

title: Experts on anti-Asian racism and violence
description: Anti-Asian Racism and Violence For fast access to experts, TEXT or call the 24-hour-experts hotline at 951-312-3049, or email news@ucr.edu.

title: UCR offers commencement compromise
description: A plan announced by Chancellor Kim A. Wilcox on Wednesday aims to address graduates' urge to walk at commencement, while respecting the caution still required by the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.  Under the plan, graduates can have their photos taken on stage, but no guests will be permitted. A prerecorded 30-minute program will be made available for students and their families to watch from home.

title: Meteor magnets in outer space
description: Astronomers believe planets like Jupiter shield us from space objects that would otherwise slam into Earth. Now they’re closer to learning whether giant planets act as guardians of solar systems elsewhere in the galaxy.  A UCR-led team has discovered two Jupiter-sized planets about 150 light years away from Earth that could reveal whether life is likely on the smaller planets in other solar systems.

title: New study dramatically narrows the search for advanced life in the universe
description: In a new study, a UC Riverside–led team discovered that a buildup of toxic gases in the atmospheres of most planets makes them unfit for complex life as we know it.

title: On safari at UC Riverside
description: Wildlife experts explain why you won’t meet mountain lions in the Botanic Gardens

title: University innovation alliance executive director to lead event at UCR
description: Bridget Burns to discuss the future of higher education and UC Riverside's role in influencing change

title: Anthropologist plots new use for motion-capture technology
description: UCR bioarchaeologist Sara Becker plans to use the cutting-edge technique to document traditional labors of indigenous Andean people

title: Tropical trees use unique method to resist drought
description: UCR research may alleviate concerns about impact of drought on Amazonian trees, which play a critical role in regulating the global climate

title: Study finds natural fires help native bees, improve food security
description: Native bees that boost food crops are in decline but changing fire management policies could help them. Most flowering plant farms employ honeybees, a non-native species originally imported from Europe and managed by beekeepers. However, research shows that farms surrounded by natural bee habitat have higher crop yields.

title: California’s worst wildfires are helping improve air quality prediction
description: New method measures and predicts air quality in areas with insufficient monitoring

title: Wildfire dataset could help firefighters save lives and property
description: WildfireDB contains over 17 million data points that capture how fires have spread in the contiguous United States over the last decade

title: Surprise effect: Methane cools even as it heats
description: Most climate models do not yet account for a new UC Riverside discovery: methane traps a great deal of heat in Earth’s atmosphere, but also creates cooling clouds that offset 30% of the heat.

title: Observation of intervalley transitions can boost valleytronic science and technology
description: An international research team led by scientists at the University of California, Riverside, has observed light emission from a new type of transition between electronic valleys, known as intervalley transmissions. The research provides a new way to read out valley information, potentially leading to new types of devices.

title: Atmospheric seasons could signal alien life
description: UCR researchers are using seasonal changes in the Earth’s atmosphere to guide their search for life outside the solar system

title: Search for life beyond the solar system topic of faculty research lecture
description: Timothy Lyons will deliver the 66th annual lecture at UC Riverside

title: UCR team among scientists developing guidebook for finding life beyond earth
description: Major series of review articles outlines past, present, and future of searching for life on other planets

title: Study: Children as young as 7 suffer effects of discrimination
description: A new UC Riverside study finds children are sensitive to and suffer the impacts of discrimination as young as 7 years old. Previous studies have shown children can identify racism at that age, but the study from Tuppett Yates, a UC Riverside psychology professor, and Ana Marcelo, an assistant professor of psychology at Clark University, is the first to study the impacts on children under 10 years old. The study also suggests that a strong sense of ethnic-racial identity is a significant buffer against these negative effects.

title: Navy grant will increase community college STEM transfers to UC Riverside engineering
description: The TUNE program will help the college of engineering to recruit and educate transfers to fulfill Navy needs

title: Scientists honored by American Geophysical Union
description: Marilyn Fogel and Timothy Lyons will be honored as new fellows during December meeting

title: In higher education, the positives outweigh the negatives
description: A UC Riverside sociologist’s 35-year survey of American universities offers evidence of surprises and successes

title: What does it really mean to be a land-grant college?
description: For Margaret Nash, recognizing who “granted” the land is key to acknowledging a history of American Indian dispossession

title: New NASA research consortium to tackle life's origins
description: NASA is uniting experts across multiple disciplines to investigate life's beginnings on our planet -- and to explore if and how life sprung up elsewhere in the universe

title: Developing a COVID-19 vaccine at warp speed
description: Dr. Paul Offit, an international expert on vaccines, will give the 2020 Thomas and Salma Haider Biomedical Breakthrough Lecture at UC Riverside

title: How cluster hiring at U.S. research universities has fared
description: A UC Riverside-led survey of cluster hires at universities across the country reveals the widespread practice could be refined

title: Meet the educator building bridges between teachers of color
description: A UCR professor’s annual institute seeks to turn isolation — a fact of life for teachers of color across the country — into action

title: Medicine from the heart
description: Edgar Ortega overcame language barriers, injuries in effort to help his new community as a doctor

title: Want to make college more equitable? Start with the board
description: University governing boards are severely understudied; here’s why that matters, and what one researcher is doing to fix it

title: Fishing for knowledge
description: Shannon Sweitzer carries life lessons from her father during UCR journey

title: Capturing life’s little moments
description: Joe Leavenworth, graduate of UCR’s MFA in Visual Art, continues to make his mark as a photographer on both the East and West Coast

title: Taking the ‘Scenic Route’
description: Lusiana Wainiqolo, a first-generation transfer student, finds a home away from home within UCR's Pacific Islander community

title: Stories of victory among UC Riverside’s 2018 graduating class
description: UCR’s 64th Commencement includes School of Medicine’s Hippocratic oath ceremony

title: Clearing the air (inside your car)
description: UC Riverside research can improve car cabin air quality and help you choose your next car

title: Will kids’ religious training save – or doom – the world?
description: Children's Views of Environment, Politics Are Sculpted by Religion; UC Riverside Researcher's Worldwide Network Will Study the Impacts

title: UC Riverside receives $2 million to monitor air quality impacts of goods movement in Inland Southern California
description: The grant comes from the California Attorney General’s Office Automobile Emissions Research and Technology Fund

title: UC Riverside Police Officer Association and University Neighborhood Enhancement Team (UNET) redefine holiday giving
description: Inspiration leads officers to surprise local children with holiday cheer

title: Omega centauri unlikely to harbor life
description: Close encounters between stars in the Milky Way’s largest globular cluster leave little room for habitable planetary systems

title: ‘Super Earth’ discovered near one of our galaxy’s oldest stars
description: A hot, rocky “super Earth,” near one of the oldest stars in the galaxy has taken a team of planet-hunting scientists by surprise.

title: Salton Sea restoration efforts could fail without science
description: There are finally efforts under way to improve the environmental health disaster that is the Salton Sea — California’s largest and most polluted lake. However, a group of UC Riverside scientists, engineers, medical experts, and economists has published a new report warning that without science, these efforts may not succeed.

title: Venus might be habitable today, if not for Jupiter
description: Venus might not be a sweltering, waterless hellscape today if Jupiter hadn’t altered its orbit around the sun, according to new UC Riverside research.

title: For children with autism, strong bonds with teachers are key to success
description: UC Riverside's Jan Blacher is leading the charge to improve relationships between kids with autism and their teachers

title: Training the next generation of special education teachers
description: A UC Riverside Graduate School of Education program enables students to earn debt-free master’s degrees

title: Entomologist gains ignoble distinction
description: People who research insects for a living are just like us — totally creeped out by spiders. This is the finding of a paper that earned retired UC Riverside spider expert Richard Vetter a 2020 Ig Nobel Award.

title: Creating a healthy racial climate to diversify the teacher workforce
description: Paper offers a framework for racial literacy in teacher education

title: Teacher incentive programs can improve student achievement
description: Programs that combine group and individual rewards can have good results and be cost-effective

title: These inclusive practices help general education teachers foster positive relationships with children with autism
description: Teachers make time to find students’ interests, celebrate talents, and have one-on-one time to form stronger relationships with students with autism, finds study

title: Distant moons may harbor life
description: UCR researchers have identified 121 giant planets that may have habitable moons

title: UC Riverside’s FIERCE Scholars are diversifying the Inland Empire teacher workforce
description: A gift from SchoolsFirst Federal Credit Union to UC Riverside School of Education is funding a program to get local education students into graduate or credential programs

title: $10 million grant will study children's religious views
description: A $10 million grant to psychology researcher Rebekah Richert will fully implement a network of international researchers who will study how religion impacts children’s world views.

title: Neuroscientist receives Klingenstein-Simons Fellowship Award in neuroscience
description: Hongdian Yang is UC Riverside’s first recipient of the prestigious fellowship

title: Natural gas engine can reduce smog from heavy-duty trucks
description: Simulated on-road testing shows the engine maintains near-zero emissions during all duty cycles

title: Research identifies possible on/off switch for plant growth
description: New research from UC Riverside identifies a protein that controls plant growth —  good news for an era in which crops can get crushed by climate change.

title: UC Riverside astrophysicist part of TESS planet finder team
description: Satellite telescope launched Wednesday will seek out new alien worlds

title: UCR again named a top social mobility university
description: UCR was named the No. 4 university in the country in terms of social mobility, which gauges a school's success in elevating its graduates to higher income brackets.

title: A faster way to fail
description: Electromigration at normal operating temperatures causes integrated circuits to fail in hours instead of years, allowing researchers to assess how durable they are

title: Fallout 'serious' for noncompliance to UC vaccination policy
description: As the Aug. 16 deadline looms for compliance with the UC vaccination policy, the fallout for those who fail to comply is being made clear.  In a campus announcement this week, Human Resources delineated protocols for employees who haven’t provided proof of full vaccination or requested an exemption or deferral by Aug. 16.

title: Astronomers measure enormous planet lurking far from its star
description: Scientists aren’t usually able to measure the size of gigantic planets, like Jupiter or Saturn, which are far from the stars they orbit. But a UC Riverside-led team has done it.

title: America’s most widely consumed oil causes genetic changes in the brain
description: New UC Riverside research shows soybean oil not only leads to obesity and diabetes, but could also affect neurological conditions like autism, Alzheimer’s disease, anxiety, and depression.

title: Are people living with HIV more isolated during the pandemic?
description: A UC Riverside-led study, funded by Merck, is set to find out

title: A quieter campus greets the start of the school year
description: Classes start Thursday at UC Riverside, in a manner unprecedented in the university’s history.

title: University of California and Los Alamos National Laboratory researchers receive $3.6M to secure smart campuses
description: The project, co-led by UC Riverside and UCLA, will develop a holistic framework to enhance the security, privacy, and safety of campus operation

title: Collective nostalgia makes people prefer domestic products
description: New study could help countries bolster domestic industries without resorting to tariffs or international trade re-negotiations

title: Revisiting the tragic tale of Willie Boy and Carlota
description: More than a century ago, a Romeo and Juliet-esque tragedy unfolded in the desert southwest. The antagonist, Willie Boy, shot and killed the shaman, William Mike, and eloped with William Mike’s daughter, Carlota, who met her demise at the hands of the pursuing posse.

title: UCR is among top 25 'best value' public universities
description: UC Riverside was named among the top 25 public universities in a college rankings system from The Princeton Review . The Princeton Review rankings are based on “return on investment,” or ROI, that factors low tuition and/or generous financial aid, combined with “strong career prospects for graduates.”

title: Winter quarter will bring full return to classrooms
description: Provost Elizabeth Watkins announced Wednesday that winter quarter will signal a full return to in-person classes. Winter quarter begins Jan. 3, 2022.

title: College on the spectrum
description: A breakthrough documentary explores what it’s like to go to college with an autism diagnosis

title: More than $1 million in grants for computational chemistry and materials science
description: The research will improve understanding of catalysis and develop new photodetection technologies

title: Among body shapes, pears are healthier than apples
description: Whether we like it or not, everyone accumulates fat. For women, it usually accumulates around the hips, resulting in a pear-shaped look. In men, fat tends to build up around the abdomen, creating an apple shape. As it turns out, it’s healthier to be a pear than an apple.

title: A match made in neural heaven: How a neuron grows an axon
description: Scientists unlock new molecular secrets to unravel the mystery

title: Neurons are genetically programmed to have long lives
description: UC Riverside-led study identifies mechanism that prevents death of neurons

title: L.A. Times spotlights move to protect ‘Noah’s Ark of citrus’
description: Citrus greening has made its way to Riverside and is spreading. The L.A. Times features UCR researchers fighting to protect the 22-acre Citrus Variety Collection

title: Malaria parasite’s survival linked to two proteins
description: UC Riverside-led research could lead to novel antimalarial therapeutic strategies

title: Chancellor's L.A. Times op-ed broaches fever to abolish SATs
description: In an L.A. Times op-ed UC Riverside Chancellor Kim Wilcox weighs in on the debate whether to keep standardized tests as part of the UC admissions process.

title: Four Engineering Professors Named as Fellows
description: This year, four UCR Marlan and Rosemary Bourns College of Engineering professors were named Fellows in recognition to their contributions and extraordinary achievements to advancing science.

title: Addiction Medicine Fellowship program receives initial accreditation
description: The first class of fellows begins training in the Coachella Valley’s Betty Ford Center and Eisenhower Medical Center on July 1

title: When the world took notice
description: The course is named “Seminar in Social Psychology,” but it could be “Wednesdays with Bob.” At 85, Robert Rosenthal is in his last year teaching at UC Riverside. Distinguished Professor David Funder — who first worked with Rosenthal at Harvard University in the early 1980s — urged Rosenthal to host a semester-long brain dump. Funder is the emcee, the inquisitor. Says Rosenthal: “It’s a strange course. It’s a class about me.”

title: One-dimensional material packs a powerful punch for next generation electronics
description: The new technology has applications in nanometer-scale transistors and circuits

title: How greener grids can stay lit
description: A new index to guide utility demand bidding could balance electricity distribution and lower consumer costs as California solar-panel mandate takes effect

title: Tips for celebrating the holiday season during a pandemic
description: Meeting virtually with people outside your household is safest, says UC Riverside epidemiologist

title: Study gauges social responsibility in slowing COVID-19 spread
description: Researchers conducted focus groups of UC Riverside faculty, staff, and students

title: Upward ventilation offers better protection from indoor coronavirus transmission
description: A simple change in the direction of the air forced through indoor gathering spaces by heating, air conditioning, and ventilation systems, could reduce the spread of infectious diseases like COVID-19.

title: A project about Zoom... Zoom... Zoom, on Zoom
description: A pair of short films were a hit at the April 13 “Filmworks – Original Short Films” held at the University Theatre, drawing attention to a suite of pandemic monologues and songs professor Bella Merlin created along with students, entitled “20:20 Vision.” For the first time this week, the short film/music video “Zoom,” and other components of 20:20 Vision are publicly available on YouTube.

title: PCORI award seeks to support students in recovery
description: Project is the first major effort in the UC system to assess the needs of students in recovery

title: Epidemiologist answers common questions about coronavirus
description: Brandon Brown is an associate professor in the School of Medicine at UC Riverside

title: Epidemiologist answers questions on COVID-19 ranging from grocery store visits to wearing masks and gloves
description: Brandon Brown is an associate professor in the Center for Healthy Communities in the School of Medicine

title: Study reports high level of hazardous drinking among Pacific Islander young adults in US
description: UC Riverside-led study calls for culturally tailored approaches to encourage this neglected population to seek behavioral health treatment

title: Impact of HPV vaccination mandates on social inequalities
description: Policy has limited impact on vaccine uptake because of individual decision making, study finds

title: Acclaimed industry designer Scott Saltsman presents summer youth workshop in video game design
description: Gear-up for a future in technology at UCR Extension and UCR Palm Desert

title: Join UCR faculty and alumni at the LA Times Festival of Books
description: Attend panel discussions and book signings featuring UCR writers at the USC campus April 13-14.

title: Project aimed at improving Latino population’s access to healthy local foods receives new funding
description: UC Riverside School of Medicine to lead engagement project in eastern Coachella Valley

title: Improved oxidation is water wizardry against drought
description: Research finds ways to remove more of the tricky substances that can squeak through water treatment

title: Nanofiber filter improves rural water treatment
description: An electrospun nanofiber uniquely suited to removing nitrogen and phosphorous could help prevent nitrate contamination of drinking water in small, rural communities most at risk

title: Research offers new insights into malaria parasite
description: A team of researchers led by a University of California, Riverside, scientist has found that various stages of the development of human malaria parasites, including stages involved in malaria transmission, are linked to epigenetic features and how chromatin — the complex of DNA and proteins within the nucleus — is organized and structured in these parasites.

title: How to block eavesdropping on wireless communications
description: Confusing channel state information offers a first line of defense in full-duplex wireless

title: Genetically engineered virus spins gold into beads
description: The discovery could make production of some electronic components cheaper, easier, and faster

title: Magnonic devices can replace electronics without much noise
description: Magnonic devices of the future could use low power to avoid performance losses

title: Winter break activities for on the go … or on the couch
description: Whether you plan to stay indoors or enjoy the outdoors, check out this list of ideas from UCR staff.

title: Amir Zaki publishes 23 years of photography in new monograph, ‘Building+Becoming’
description: The book weaves stories that capture both nature and architecture. It goes on sale on April 26

title: UCR faculty, staff, and alumni will be at the LA Times Festival of Books
description: This year’s Los Angeles Times Festival of Books includes a UC Riverside star-studded lineup.  Nineteen UCR faculty, staff, and alumni will be participating in this annual literary event that takes place at the University of Southern California. More than 550 authors, poets, artists, chefs, celebrities, and musicians will gather on April 23-24. See full details: LA Times Festival of Books.

title: Product authentication at your fingertips
description: UC Riverside-led research brings rapid and reversible switching of plasmonic color to solids

title: New property revealed in graphene could lead to better performing solar panels
description: International research team, co-led by UC Riverside physicist, shows how pure graphene efficiently converts light into electricity

title: Implantable piezoelectric polymer improves controlled release of drugs
description: Repeated tests showed a similar amount of drug release per activation, confirming robust control of release rate

title: Small magnets reveal big secrets
description: Work by international research team could have wide-ranging impact on information technology applications

title: UCR Extension offers new series of STEM workshops based on the makerspace ideology
description: Join the 'Maker Movement' for hands-on learning the Makerspace way

title: Building a stronger community through partnerships
description: UCR Extension's Kasey Wilson leads the way

title: How UCR’s Low-Residency MFA program uses remote teaching to its advantage
description: The program’s faculty members and students offer advice for transitioning to online classes due to coronavirus

title: Professors to debate the merits and pitfalls of taking risks
description: UC Riverside’s annual Disciplines in Dialogue program returns with a series of discussions about various types of risk-taking

title: UCR Palm Desert’s MFA celebrates 10th anniversary
description: What has made this low residency, self-sustaining program successful, can be attributed to three factors: it embraces fiction genre writing, it teaches students the business aspect of writing, and is driven by student success, boasting a publication/production rate of more than 75 percent within two years of graduating.

title: Scientists to study how lungs respond to worm infections
description: Research supported by five-year NIH grant may have relevance for COVID-19 patients

title: Study sheds new light on how bilinguals process language
description: Research led by a psychologist at the University of California, Riverside, shows that bilinguals regulate, or suppress, their native language when reading in a second language. Many in media and in science often assume that reading or speaking in a second language — one that has been learned later in life than the native or first language — is always going to be difficult.

title: UCR School of Business awarded re-accreditation by distinguished AACSB international
description: The UCR School of Business is the premier public business research institution in Inland Southern California and provides insights and resources that impact the development of the region

title: Decoding the secret language of photosynthesis
description: For decades, scientists have been stumped by the signals plants send themselves to initiate photosynthesis, the process of turning sunlight into sugars. UC Riverside researchers have now decoded those previously opaque signals.

title: Culturally-informed mental health screenings improve student, school and community successes
description: As concerns about youth mental health, school shootings, and other forms of violence prompt more school systems to conduct mental health screenings, a UC Riverside-led analysis is urging school officials to proceed with deference to student family, cultural, and community backgrounds.

title: Does Ticketmaster have a monopoly?
description: Two UCR experts to weigh in on whether Ticketmaster is a monopoly and should be subjected to antitrust action.

title: An alternate theory for what causes Alzheimer's disease
description: A UC Riverside study points to lysosomal storage observed in all brains afflicted with the disease; finding could open up new avenues for treatment and prevention

title: Nobel Prize winner to join UC Riverside faculty
description: UCR alumnus and renowned scholar Richard Schrock will share pioneering science with faculty and students

title: Chemist receives Department of Energy award
description: Early Career Research Program award will support Ming Lee Tang’s research on developing hybrid organic-inorganic materials

title: The vibrating universe: Making astronomy accessible to the deaf
description: UC Riverside astronomers develop educational workshop converting astronomical phenomena into vibrations that can be felt rather than heard

title: Making higher-energy light to fight cancer
description: Researchers use nontoxic silicon nanocrystals to convert low-energy photons into high-energy ones, bringing scientists closer to developing photodynamic treatments for cancer

title: Governor’s initiative misunderstands inland California’s economies
description: ‘Regions Rise Together’ comparison to coastal regions may distort policy direction

title: Game changer: New chemical keeps plants plump
description: A UC Riverside-led team has created a chemical to help plants hold onto water, which could stem the tide of massive annual crop losses from drought and help farmers grow food despite a changing climate.  “Drought is the No. 1 cause, closely tied with flooding, of annual crop failures worldwide,” said Sean Cutler, a plant cell biology professor at UC Riverside, who led the research. “This chemical is an exciting new tool that could help farmers better manage crop performance when water levels are low.”

title: Detection of very high frequency magnetic resonance could revolutionize electronics
description: UC Riverside-led research has applications in ultrafast and spin-based nanoscale devices

title: UC Riverside freshman builds computers for high school students in need
description: Computer science student helps ensure Covid-19 pandemic won’t hinder academic success in his community

title: UCR’s midcentury architecture to be showcased during Modernism Week
description: Photographs, including images captured by Ansel Adams, will be featured during a free exhibition open to the public at UCR's Palm Desert Center.

title: Safeguarding against ‘Zoom bombing’
description: XCITE director Richard Edwards explains UCR’s response to the phenomena and offers guidance on how to tighten Zoom security

title: UCR team develops homegrown solution to online proctoring
description: Richard Edwards and Nathaniel Wildes of XCITE discuss preparing UCR for remote exams while students continue to shelter in place

title: Crimped or straight? Lung fiber shape influences elasticity
description: The shape and architecture of collagen and elastin fibers can improve our understanding of lung diseases, including the one associated with vaping

title: COVID-19 highlights what we have yet to learn about lung mechanics
description: UC Riverside engineer is working on ways to pre-screen patients with difficulty breathing for earlier intervention

title: Petri dishes don’t make good hosts for parasitic nematodes
description: Some of what scientists know about how parasitic nematodes damage their host’s tissues may be missing the mark

title: Awards help faculty commercialize inventions
description: Proof of concept grants advance new technologies to fight cancer and improve agriculture

title: A mother’s greatest nightmare: Susan Straight broaches school shootings
description: As of March 8, there have been 14 school shootings so far this year. Since the Feb. 14 shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., 756 copycat threats have been made targeting schools across the country.

title: Striking a balance between immunity and inflammation
description: Focusing on hookworms, UC Riverside mouse study identifies role infection-fighting cells play in inflamed and damaged tissue

title: Housing scarcity: the Inland Empire’s natural barrier to economic growth
description: UCR’s Center for Economic Forecasting says the region’s housing problem is a land use issue solvable at the local level

title: Research center receives additional Department of Energy funding
description: SHINES at UC Riverside pursues fundamental advances in energy production, storage, and use

title: It's all about bite-sized pieces
description: Annie Ditta’s graduate school training was in fixation. As she says, “I got fixated on fixation.” Her familiarity with fixation is useful as instructors at the University of California, Riverside, must reinvent how they teach within the space of two weeks. On March 14, UCR announced instruction for spring quarter — which begins March 30 — will move online in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

title: The new provost is ready to get started
description: Elizabeth Watkins is UC Riverside's new provost and executive vice chancellor. The provost is eager to help raise the profile and funding support for UCR's research enterprise, and to work with its high-achieving students — this past year, UCR set a new six-year graduation rate record — many of whom are first-generation students, and from underrepresented and low-income families.

title: Student workers hired to support faculty in using new technology
description: UC Riverside hired nearly 100 student workers to provide support to faculty with new technology in 110 classrooms. These student workers, both graduate and undergraduate, will assist professors in the 110 general assignment classrooms. The new technology was installed onsite over the summer as part of the Rooms for Increasing Student Engagement, or RISE initiative. RISE is a joint effort by UCR’s Information Technology Solutions, or ITS, and UCR’s Exploration Center for Innovative Teaching & Engagement, or XCITE. The cadre of student workers serves one of two support teams.

title: Female presidents are held to higher standards than males
description: An analysis of presidential approval ratings reveals truths about gender biases

title: Classroom technology on the RISE
description: UC Riverside is getting ready for new modes of instruction this fall as it unveils classrooms equipped with state-of-the-art video and audio technology. The program, called Rooms for Increasing Student Engagement, or RISE, will feature classrooms that allow for both in-person and remote options for the same class. The campus is planning for a return to mostly in-person instruction this fall.

title: Hope for the infected
description: Though no proven treatment for COVID-19 currently exists, UC Riverside virologist Juliet Morrison feels there’s a good chance one will emerge. Morrison, an assistant professor in the Department of Microbiology & Plant Pathology, investigates the science behind promising avenues for new antiviral therapies. She explains what those are and weighs in on drugs being tested.

title: David Leonhardt presents Feb. 27 Hays P-E Lecture
description: New York Times columnist David Leonhardt will offer the Feb. 27 Hays Press-Enterprise Lecture, which will take place between 4-6 p.m. at the UC Riverside Extension Center.

title: Fiber-optic probe can see molecular bonds
description: Pointing the new nanoscopy tool like a Harry Potter wand reveals a high-resolution image of molecules

title: UC Riverside research could eventually lead to advances in pulmonary healthcare
description: Scientists are just beginning to understand the mechanics of the lung

title: Can I mix those chemicals? There’s an app for that!
description: New technology can find the safest way to store and dispose of reactive chemicals

title: Microbiome study suggests marine nematodes are not picky eaters
description: UCR research finding no relationship between nematode species and microbial profile suggests marine worms don’t have a restrictive diet

title: How well do you know the Salton Sea?
description: What was once a destination for Hollywood's biggest stars is now one of California's gravest environmental threats. Test your knowledge to see how much you know about the Salton Sea.

title: Friends remember lifelong UC Riverside advocate Bill DeWolfe
description: William “Bill” DeWolfe, 84, a prominent Riverside attorney and philanthropist who was one of UC Riverside’s earliest graduates and an ardent advocate of the university for the rest of his life, died April 16, 2020.

title: Inland Empire economic gains will continue in 2019
description: Worker scarcity driving wage increases; Inland Empire affordability advantage will help buffer region from slowdown in Southern California home sales

title: Parasitic worm venom evades human immune system
description: It’s likely that billions of people are unaware they have been infected with parasitic worms. A UC Riverside scientist has won $1.8 million to try and understand why.  The National Institutes of Health granted an Outstanding Investigator Award to Adler Dillman, an assistant professor of parasitology, so he can shed light on the mystery of worm infections that escape detection by human immune systems.

title: How to eat a poison butterfly
description: In high enough concentrations, milkweed can kill a horse, or a human. To be able to eat this plant, monarchs evolved a set of unusual cellular mutations. New UC Riverside research shows the animals that prey on monarchs also evolved these same mutations.

title: Precisely poking cells en masse to cure cancer
description: Device can mass-produce engineered cells at lower cost, a tipping point for emerging lifesaving therapies

title: UC Riverside named to Top 50 Green Colleges list
description: UC Riverside was recently named among the Top 50 Green Colleges by the Princeton Review; ranking No. 16 among public universities and No. 48 overall in the nation. The Top 50 list is chosen from school-reported data and student opinions collected from online surveys. The survey questions canvass whether students experience a healthy, sustainable quality of life; how well the university is preparing students for “green” jobs; and the school’s environmental policies.

title: Scientists are using AI originally developed for producing deepfake videos to stop future pandemics
description: Generative adversarial networks are being used to predict the structure of antibodies that could neutralize a previously unknown virus

title: Highlander Venture Fund chooses UCR professor’s ‘next-generation’ mosquito repellent for second investment
description: Up to $500,000 will help a startup company market a killer repellent that’s nontoxic, natural, and sweet-smelling

title: $10 sensor reduces brewers’ natural gas use
description: $45,000 UC Riverside investment helps researchers win $1.5 million grant

title: Pest-monitoring device enters into field trials
description: The technology invented by engineers at UC Riverside could reduce pesticide use and crop loss

title: Riverside named a top city for entrepreneurs
description: Riverside outranks the better-known entrepreneurship hotspot of San Jose

title: Award-winning inventions improve electronics and renewable natural gas
description: Graphene thermal interface and steam hydrogasification receive TechConnect National Innovation Awards

title: Elizabeth Watkins to be appointed UCR provost and EVC
description: UC Riverside Chancellor Kim A. Wilcox announced the appointment of Elizabeth Watkins as provost and executive vice chancellor effective May 1, 2021, pending approval by University of California President Michael Drake. Watkins has extensive experience as a University of California administrator, faculty member, and leader in the Academic Senate.

title: Students receive Bear Bucks for COVID-19 test results
description: An incentive program aims to increase testing compliance and improve campus health at UC Riverside.

title: Men's Soccer Wins First Big West Conference Championship
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif.—The loud, raucous roars resonated throughout UCR Soccer Stadium Saturday, Nov. 10 as Daniel Castaneda belted the deciding penalty kick past UC Davis goalie Jon Laughlin, giving the Highlanders their first Big West Conference Championship in school history. The second the ball went past Laughlin to give UCR the win after a 4-2 decision in penalty kicks, fans stormed the field as the team began hugging and jumping up and down.

title: Climate change is worsening, but population control isn't the answer
description: Jade S. Sasser's new book highlights contemporary population control’s consequences for poor women in the Global South

title: Microchips can permanently link patients with clinical samples
description: Project to embed patient data directly in biological samples receives Gates Foundation funding

title: Musical sensor shows bad medicine plays false note
description: Inspired by a musical instrument, the simple sensor can be constructed from common materials and used to detect adulterated or counterfeit drugs

title: Computers, nematodes, and curiosity
description: Alejandro De Santiago Perez wants more lab experience before pursuing a doctorate in bioinformatics.

title: Machines whisper our secrets
description: Spies can learn what a machine is making from the sounds it makes

title: Seeing through food and drug fakes and frauds
description: “Chronoprints” can identify a sample from a video taken as it reacts to disturbance

title: ‘A closed mouth doesn’t get fed’
description: This future PepsiCo associate was raised without her parents since the age of 9. Her resiliency transformed into grit

title: Air-powered computer memory helps soft robot control movements
description: “Airhead” robot uses pneumatic RAM to play piano

title: Simple new testing method aims to improve time-release drugs
description: Glass tuning-fork-shaped tubing gives accurate, continuous measurements of drug dissolution

title: ‘Barbershop Walk’ offers men fitness and comradery
description: It’s 6:30 a.m. and a group of men are happily fist-bumping one another, smiles evident under their face masks. The morning’s exercise leader is Bert Wright, ’99, who is about to lead the group on a 3-mile trek around the UC Riverside campus.

title: 2018 Athletics Hall of Fame Inductee: Melissa Sanchez
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif.—When Melissa Sanchez saw the 951 area code pop up on her phone a few months ago, she had a feeling it was someone from UC Riverside. However, she wasn't expecting the news that awaited her. Sanchez, who graduated from UCR in 2006, would be inducted into the 2018 Athletics Hall of Fame. Sanchez, a standout on the softball team from 2003-06, is in the Highlanders' top-10 all-time for batting average, games played, hits, doubles, home runs, RBIs, slugging, and on-base percentage.

title: This deep neural network fights deepfakes
description: Artificial intelligence to accurately detect altered photos is getting smarter

title: From UCR’s garden to students’ tables
description: UCR’s community garden delivers fresh fruit and vegetables to students who remain on campus.

title: How servicization addresses sustainability with a focus on profitability for firms
description: UCR professor evaluates emerging business strategy in updated academic paper

title: Highlanders move into second place after blowout win
description: High-octane offense was on display on both sides at Premier America Credit Union Arena, but UC Riverside proved too much for CSUN on Monday night with a resounding 96-76 win over the Matadors.  Their 19th win, which extended a team record in Division I play, was the Highlanders third straight and vaulted them into sole possession of second place in the hypercompetitive Big West Conference.

title: Athletics releases spring schedules
description: UC Riverside’s Department of Intercollegiate Athletics this week released schedules for its spring athletic teams.  Baseball  UC Riverside head baseball coach Justin Johnson has announced the Highlanders’ 2023 schedule. UC Riverside returns more than half of its starting lineup from 2022 and its top three starting pitchers in Tyler Frazier, Tucker Juline, and Eric Marrujo. Click here for the full schedule.

title: Back in camp: women's soccer
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif. — For UC Riverside women's soccer head coach Nat Gonzalez, this season's message is simple. It started all the way back in spring.

title: Focus on the Future: Men's Soccer
description: When a new crop of student-athletes report to camp for the first time, it can be difficult for them to blend in well with the veterans. That hasn't been the case for the UC Riverside men's soccer team. "My new teammates are really the ones that are helping us out by the way they have acclimated to the team's chemistry and our game plan so quickly," said senior forward Antonio Lokossou. The Highlanders come into the season with a 27-man roster that features five freshmen and six transfer students. For the 11 student-athletes, the veterans have already been a great guide.

title: Focus on the Future: Women's Volleyball
description: While the UC Riverside women's volleyball team has a solid core of upperclassmen, it will be the seven new additions to the roster that could take the team to the next level in the Big West Conference. "Our freshmen are a really good class," head coach Michelle Patton-Coleman said. "They have a lot to learn when it comes to the system and the speed of the game. They just have to get in games and know what it is like to play at the Division I level." One of the freshmen the team will rely on is outside hitter Marissa Holt, whose physicality will help put balls away.

title: Focus on the Future: Women's Soccer
description: As freshman defender Katie Wong stepped onto the field for her first practice as a member of the UC Riverside women's soccer team earlier this month, she noticed some familiar faces. A local student-athlete from Corona, Wong played with forward Leigh Polson, midfielder Jen Barroso and forward Liz Chua on her club team.
