"I came into UCR feeling so comfortable because of all the people I know," Wong said. "I got even more excited when the time came to start practicing."

title: Athletics Set to Induct 2018 Hall of Fame Class
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif. – The UC Riverside Athletics Department is pleased to announce its 2018 Athletics Hall of Fame inductees. Scheduled to receive the highest honors during the induction ceremony on Nov. 16 at the Historic Mission Inn Hotel & Spa in downtown Riverside are Larry Cunningham (men's basketball), David Finley (baseball), Fred Morawczski (football), Melissa Sanchez (softball), and the 1982 baseball team.

title: 2018 Athletics Hall of Fame Inductee: Fred Morawczski
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif.—It's been nearly 50 years since Fred Morawczski finished playing football at UC Riverside, but his memories are as fresh as ever. "The best thing was the comradery and really having a sense of purpose," Morawczski said. "I had great teammates and really inspiring coaches." Morawczski, who is a 2018 UC Riverside Athletics Hall of Fame inductee, holds the career rushing record with 1,035 yards, even though he only played on the team for two years (1968-69).

title: Former Highlanders Pitcher Joe Kelly Helps Red Sox Win World Series
description: Walk into the UC Riverside Baseball Complex and you immediately notice framed jerseys on the walls of current and former Major League players. One that stood out a little more than the rest on Monday is of Red Sox reliever Joe Kelly. He won a World Series Championship with the Boston Red Sox Sunday night, playing a pivotal role in the team's run.

title: Brian Haynes to be appointed UCR Vice Chancellor for Student Affairs
description: Career Public University Administrator is Currently Head of Student Affairs at Cal State San Bernardino

title: 2018 Athletics Hall of Fame Inductee: Larry Cunningham
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif.—When Larry Cunningham found out a few months ago via phone that he would be a 2018 UC Riverside Athletics Hall of Fame inductee, his first reaction was an unusual one. "I thought someone was prank calling me," Cunningham said with a laugh. "I had no idea. I wasn't expecting it. As they continued talking, I realized it was the truth. I was just so honored." Cunningham, who played basketball for the Highlanders from 2004-08, is still the program's all-time leading scorer, with 1,502 points.

title: Malou De Kergret Takes on Leadership Role
description: Forward Malou De Kergret is one-of-a-kind on the UC Riverside women's basketball team this season. She's the only senior. "Something is different about your senior year," De Kergret said. "All seniors from all sports feel it. You know it is your last year and you want to make a difference."

title: 2018 Athletics Hall of Fame Inductee: David Finley
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif.—David Finley has visited and played on his fair share of baseball diamonds. However, the one he played on at UC Riverside is still his favorite. "When I played at Riverside, our field was on campus. I've been on a million fields since then and our field is by far the best one I've ever played on," Finley said. "When I think of UC Riverside, I think about taking ground balls, taking batting practice and being able to see all of the palm trees and mountains in the distance."

title: Women's Basketball Signs Three Recruits
description: UC Riverside Highlanders Women's Basketball team has announced the signing of future student-athletes Yohana Ewodo, Georgia Ohiaeri, and Fapou Semebene. "This is one of the best recruiting classes in my time here and we are very excited," said John Margaritis, who is in his 15th season as head coach. Ewodo, a 5' 11'' forward and the sister of junior forward Marina Ewodo, was a starter for France in the FIBA 17 and under World Championships this past summer and won a silver medal.

title: 2018 Athletics Hall of Fame Inductee: 1982 Baseball Team
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif.—It's a feeling very few people get to experience, but for the 1982 UC Riverside Men's Baseball team, each player is able to call themselves a National Champion. That achievement helped the team become one of the 2018 Athletics Hall of Fame inductees.

title: Climate change predicted to bring more extremes to inland southern california
description: Regional report authored by UCR researchers is included in California’s Fourth Climate Change Assessment

title: ‘Real Women Have Curves’ director joins UCR faculty
description: This fall, Cardoso joined UCR’ Department of Theatre, Film, and Digital Production and is currently teaching two courses. The Colombian-born creator said she felt identified to the students and to UCR’s mission.

title: From juvenile detention to college graduation
description: A felony conviction gave Ramón Leija the determination to turn his life around.

title: Pushing back against poverty
description: Mark Sebarrotin said UCR was his shot at the California dream; now, he wants to help others achieve their dream, too.

title: On the front line of medicine
description: Medical school graduate Hurnan Vongsachang will start her residency in emergency medicine this summer

title: Engineering her family's future
description: Andrea Cruz Castillo pushed through self-doubt and maternal guilt to launch a career in data administration and database management

title: For the love of caterpillars
description: A first-generation student’s journey into entomology.

title: Connecting through culture
description: This psychology major from Dubai made it her mission to connect local and international students.

title: Alzheimer's gene may impact cognition before adulthood
description: A gene linked to Alzheimer’s disease may impact cognitive health much sooner than previously realized. The APOE gene creates a protein, apolipoprotein E, which packages cholesterol and other fats to transport them through the bloodstream. There are three versions, or alleles, of APOE. One of those is the APOE4 allele, present in about 15% of the population. APOE4 carriers are up to three times more likely to develop late-onset Alzheimer’s disease, which occurs in people 65 and older.

title: 'Falling out of love' led to record-breaking tennis career
description: A shift from soccer to tennis jostled Kyle McCann's Irish footballer-father, but a storied UCR career affirms it was the right move.

title: Patricia Cardoso directs TV episodes for Netflix and The CW
description: “In the Dark” and “The Society” are now airing.

title: Staying on beat
description: Irvin Rosales balances school, two jobs, and a music-industry internship.

title: Grads and jobs: It pays to stay local
description: A UCR report finds more than 80% of graduates start their careers in California.

title: UC Riverside students take first and second place at prestigious conference
description: Leadership-in-action competition yields prizewinning strategies for increasing Hispanic leadership in engineering

title: A warming world increases air pollution
description: Climate change is warming the ocean, but it’s warming land faster and that’s really bad news for air quality

title: Going with the floe: Sea ice movements trace dynamics transforming the new Arctic
description: Image processing algorithms on satellite images show how sea ice drift affects freshwater flux in Arctic Ocean currents

title: The newest California water-worry is the megastorm
description: Research from UCLA and other sources recently predicted another “big one” to hit the West Coast. This time, it’s not an earthquake, but a “megastorm.” Such a flood typically hits California every 100 to 200 years, but the dynamics and frequency of this storm will be exacerbated by climate change. That is, warmer temperatures mean much of the precipitation will fall as rain, and not snow.

title: Generous funding to malaria-parasite researcher promises new therapeutic strategies
description: UC Riverside’s Karine Le Roch is principal investigator on two NIH grants

title: Back in Camp: Track and Field Excited for Competition to Begin
description: Whether it's the men or women, indoor or outdoor, UC Riverside Track and Field director Nate Browne is excited for the year ahead. The track and field season officially begins on Friday in the Lumberjack Team Challenge. On the women's side, the team has a lot of fresh, new talent that will try to replace many difference makers who have graduated. "Our goal was to get people that could cover two if not three events well. We've had a steady fall and look to express that preparation in some great indoor competitions," said Browne.

title: Renewable natural gas can help California meet climate goals
description: UC Riverside study finds California can replace up to 5 percent of its natural gas supply using existing raw materials and infrastructure, recommends new state standard

title: Back in Action: Baseball Optimistic About Season Ahead
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif.—With a slew of new faces and a strong core of upperclassmen, the UC Riverside baseball team is optimistic about the season ahead. "People will enjoy watching the style of play we have," head coach Troy Percival said. "We've never had as much speed as we do right now. Our outfield speed is going to be incredible. You are going to see a lot of diving plays and guys who can defend."

title: Men's Basketball Announces the Signing of Three Recruits
description: The UC Riverside men's basketball team has announced that three phenomenal student-athletes will join its 2019 recruiting class. Daniel Mading, Oliver Hayes-Brown, and Akol Mawein have signed their National Letters of Intent to join the Highlander family. Daniel Mading Mading is a former four-star recruit that comes to Riverside from Neosho City College. The South Sudan native grew up in Perch, Austrailia and has been recruited by many programs this year.

title: Retailers can manipulate consumer regret to beat competitors
description: Offering an everyday low price might not be the best strategy for retailers facing the threat of new competitors in their market

title: Tiny desk, huge accomplishments – and his own bed
description: The bed

title: Nobel Laureate Barry Barish joins UC Riverside faculty
description: Physicist, whose contributions enabled the first observation of gravitational waves, is the university’s second Nobel Prize winner

title: Bioengineering-led Neuroengineering Symposium brings more than 80 academic experts to share their advancement and build partnerships
description: UCR’s Department of Bioengineering led the campus’ first Computational Neuroimaging and Neuroengineering Symposium (CNNS) in November. The symposium brought together more than 80 cognitive neuroscientists, computational psychologists, bioengineers and neuroengineers, electrical and computer engineers, and computer scientists to discuss new advances and results in the fast-growing field.

title: Bioengineering to host an open house of its new Pediatric Rehabilitation Technology Lab showcasing advancements in pediatric assistive devices
description: The ability to move independently permits us to examine the world around us. Children born with motor impairments face unique challenges to learn about their environment and develop cognitively and socially through locomotion.  Innovative research in pediatric rehabilitative technologies allow children with these disabilities to interact with and explore their world in a way previously thought to be impossible.

title: Patricia Cardoso to helm upcoming episodes of Netflix, CBS, ABC, and Freeform shows
description: The UCR professor will be directing episodes of “Tales of the City,” “All Rise,” “Emergence,” and “Party of Five.”

title: First Latina film director included in National Film Registry is a UCR professor
description: The 2002 film that placed a middle-class Latino family on the big screen is now officially part of United States cinematic history.  “Real Women Have Curves,” directed by University of California, Riverside professor Patricia Cardoso, is now part of the Library of Congress’ National Film Registry. Cardoso is the first Latina director to be included in the registry’s 31-year history, according to the registry’s women director’s list.

title: Graduation with a global perspective
description: An international education was key for these UCR students’ futures.

title: Networking in life and business
description: This Nigeria native came to UC Riverside ready to make friends and learn about finance.

title: Men's basketball releases its 2018-19 schedule
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif.

title: Back in Camp: Men's Tennis Aims to Keep Making History
description: With the 2018-2019 season just one day away, the UC Riverside Men's Tennis Team is poised to continue its tradition of building and growing year by year. Since Head Coach Mattias Johansson's arrival before the 2015-16 season, a year in which he led the team to a DI record 13 wins, the Highlanders have consistently surpassed their previous accomplishments every year. In 2017 the team earned 14 wins and just last year set the current record of 16. This year Johansson and the squad have their sights set on not only reaching internal milestones, but making some noise in the Big West.

title: Men's Soccer celebrates 2018 season with chancellor
description: Thursday morning, the UC Riverside Men's Soccer Team took a walk across campus to the office of University's Chancellor, Kim Wilcox, to be honored for a successful and historical 2018 season. The Highlanders piled into Wilcox's conference room with their Big West Tournament trophy in hand as each coach and student-athlete met with the Chancellor and received his applause for their accomplishments this past year.

title: UC Riverside enrolls second-highest rate of first-generation freshmen in UC system
description: A systemwide initiative was launched in 2016 to increase support for these students.

title: Optical pre-processing makes computer vision more robust and energy efficient
description: Hybrid neural network can reconstruct Arabic or Japanese characters that it hasn’t seen before

title: Making mezcal is an art; science shows us why
description: Experiments show how bubbles indicate alcohol value

title: Trade disputes have little effect on Inland Empire economy
description: The region’s economy continues to grow despite ongoing trade disputes that many feared would inhibit the logistics industry

title: Coastal ecosystems suffer from upriver hydroelectric dams
description: A recent study demonstrates the widespread environmental consequences of large dam reservoirs in Mexico

title: Cruise buyers’ counterintuitive response to prices could help the industry rebound post-pandemic
description: The post-pandemic cruise industry should plan ticket sales to attract loyalists, who book early in advance and are less price sensitive

title: Lonely? These odd rituals can help
description: Personal rituals around everyday tasks ease loneliness

title: Payless stunt shows how expectation guides experience
description: Sometimes quality is in the eye of the beholder

description: Marie Schultz will oversee the university's development program

title: UC Riverside reaffirms MOU with EPA
description: A number of environmentally focused activities with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) will be continuing, thanks to the renewal of a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) between EPA’s Region 9 and the University of California, Riverside.

title: Virtual program links students around the globe
description: UC Riverside’s International Affairs shifted into a nearly 24/7 operation earlier this year, especially in its efforts to recruit new international students. The team spent thousands of hours redesigning programs for virtual platforms — all made accessible to students in the United States and around the world.

title: Meet the 2021 Goldwater, Fulbright scholars
description: Goldwater scholars Shayan Saeed and Ryan Gates; and U.S. Fulbright scholars Jacqueline Aguirre de la O and Zehra Qazi are recipients of two of the nation’s most prestigious awards.  The Barry M. Goldwater Scholarship is one of the country’s most competitive honors in the science, technology, engineering, and mathematics fields, or STEM. The application process is rigorous and asks students to think deeply about their research and long-term goals.

title: Highlanders fend off Cal Poly, move into first place in Big West
description: UC Riverside welcomed students back to campus on Monday at a packed SRC Arena, treating them to free extra basketball with a thrilling 83-78 overtime win over Cal Poly to move into first place in the Big West. The Highlanders are now 6-1 in conference play, the best start in program history.  Monday's win was the seventh straight in the series for UCR, the Highlanders' longest current winning streak over any conference opponent.

title: Would you get bored of eternal life?
description: John Martin Fischer’s videotaped lectures on near-death experiences and immortality have garnered the most views of any content on UCR’s YouTube site.

title: Eleven students awarded study-abroad scholarships
description: Eleven UC Riverside students have been selected for two prestigious national scholarships to study or intern outside of the United States.

title: Fundraising effort seeks to aid at-risk Afghan scholars
description: Public donations will help scholars fleeing from danger, offer them safety .

title: Marlan and Rosemary Bourns College of Engineering welcomes 17 new faculty
description: This year, UC Riverside’s Marlan and Rosemary Bourns College of Engineering (BCOE) welcomed 17 new faculty members, bringing its total faculty cohort to 129. Among the additions are the new engineering dean, a distinguished engineering professor, three provost diversity fellows, a Fulbright Scholar, a National Science Foundation (NSF) CAREER awardee, and two assistant research engineers.

title: UCR dance professor receives 2019 Bessie Award
description: This is the second such honor for Ni’Ja Whitson.

title: UC Riverside receives Diversity Award
description: INSIGHT into Diversity recognition acknowledges recruitment, retention efforts for underrepresented, first-generation students and faculty

title: Physics undergraduate student headed to CERN
description: Sergio Garcia will do research during the winter quarter on a particle detector at the Large Hadron Collider

title: UCR recognized as a First-gen Forward Institution
description: The University of California, Riverside, has been selected to join a group of universities looking to advance educational opportunities for first-generation college students. On Monday, March 2, the National Association of Student Personnel Administrators, known as NASPA, announced UCR will join its 2020-21 First-gen Forward cohort, an honor that earned the university a designation as a First-gen Forward Institution. The cohort will work within NASPA’s Center for First-Generation Student Success.

title: First-gen virtual chats now offered twice a week
description: Students looking for assistance and resources can connect through Zoom chats every Tuesday and Thursday.

title: COVID-19 expressions in video, art, poetry
description: A history assignment gave UCR students an opportunity to capture their lives during the pandemic.

title: UCR joins Big Brothers Big Sisters in new virtual mentoring program
description: Born from the pandemic, College Bigs, will count on nearly 150 UCR students to work with local high school mentees.

title: CE-CERT Director appointed to U.S Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Committee
description: Matthew J. Barth, UC Riverside College of Engineering - Center for Environmental Research and Technology Director and Yeager Families Chair, was recently appointed to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency’s Mobile Sources Technical Review Subcommittee (MSTRS) of the Clean Air Act Advisory Committee (CAAAC).

title: To vaccinate or not to vaccinate
description: A UCR sociologist is part of a $1.5 million effort to better understand skepticism toward childhood vaccines

title: Why renting can be better than owning
description: Purchasing a skill-based product can be self-defeating

title: Women's Volleyball Adds Former National Champion Andy Hein to Coaching Staff
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif.- The UC Riverside women's volleyball team made a huge addition to its coaching staff on March 4 as the Highlanders announced the hiring of Assistant Coach Andrew Hein. The former national champion and Team USA medalist comes to Riverside with a lengthy coaching and player resume in Southern California.

title: Back in Action: Softball Has Sights Set on Success
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif.—After an incredibly successful and historical 2018 season for the UC Riverside Softball Team, the Highlanders have waited patiently to return to the diamond, flipping their calendars and preparing for an exciting 2019 campaign.  "We are so excited to get this season going," Head Coach Nikki Palmer said. "Each year we continue to climb up the competitive ladder and I know our team is ready to take on the challenge that this tough schedule is going to present."

title: Experts on coronavirus
description: Coronavirus  For fast access to experts, TEXT or call the 24-hour-experts hotline at 951-312-3049, or email news@ucr.edu  John Barton, assistant professor of physics

description: Fifty items from the collection will be showcased in an exhibition that opens Jan. 22 and runs through May 31.

title: Queer students interested in health? There’s a club for you
description: Health Queers is now one of more than 450 campus student organizations.

title: Scholar will learn Indigenous language with grant
description: Alejandra Dubcovsky, an associate professor of history at UC Riverside, has received a $231,000 award from The Andrew W. Mellon Foundation to support a fellowship during which she will work to become one of the few historians working with the Indigenous language Timucua. The fellowship, called a New Directions Fellowship, will allow Dubcovsky to study over 27 months Timucua, an Indigenous language spoken in what is now northern Florida and southern Georgia.

title: Capturing daily life during the COVID-19 pandemic
description: UCR community’s photos, letters, and event information to be included in new library collection.

title: Ramadan in the time of COVID-19
description: The pandemic has forced smaller gatherings, but students have still found an opportunity for reflection and family time.

description: UCR has more than 4,400 degreed Black alumni, and is nationally recognized for having one of the smallest achievement gaps in the country.

title: Class of 2020: Remembered for ‘their flexibility and resilience’

title: Engineering college interim dean to become dean at Drexel University College of Engineering
description: The interim dean of the Marlan and Rosemary Bourns College of Engineering at UC Riverside will become the new dean of the College of Engineering at Drexel University in Philadelphia, beginning Sept. 1. Sharon Walker has been interim dean since July 2016, replacing Reza Abbaschian, who had been dean for 11 years, and who became director of the Winston Chung Global Energy Center at UCR.

title: Researchers receive $1 million for project challenging long-standing paradigm in endocrinology
description: W. M. Keck Foundation award supports UC Riverside research aimed at showing membrane transporters guide flow of steroid hormones into cells

description: The Professional Science Master’s Degree in Industrial Biotechnology prepares students for the most in-demand, highly skilled jobs

description: An international team of researchers has unraveled the evolutionary history of the world’s tropical forests

title: Highlanders get a cooler, off-campus commencement
description: UC Riverside will hold most of its 2023 Commencement Ceremonies inside the air-conditioned Toyota Arena in Ontario. The new location is less than 20 miles from campus, and UCR Vice Chancellor Brian Haynes said the venue will provide a more well-rounded experience for all attendees.

title: Four professors receive $270K in grants from the National Endowment for the Humanities
description: The awards will allow for book projects and innovative curriculum development.

description: University Extension is the first continuing education program in California to offer teachers a professional development certificate for a newly state-mandated course.

title: Campus community gets first look at OASIS
description: On a campus already actively growing its footprint in Inland Southern California, a proposed clean technology park would lead to a reinvention of UC Riverside’s relationship with the city and region. The park is Phase I of a more ambitious research and economic development project.

title: UC Riverside and UC Davis help create program targeted for students who didn’t finish college
description: More than $4.85 million in state funds will allow these campuses to reengage with former UC students and California residents with some college and no degree attainment.

title: ‘I am the product of rape. Here’s why I support abortion rights’
description: Victoria Reyes, an assistant professor of gender and sexuality studies at UCR, speaks from personal experience in this Q&A.

title: Here are the many ways UCR is helping students right now
description: A list of available resources during this time of uncertainty.

title: UCR bioengineer awarded Fulbright grant
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif. (www.ucr.edu) — A University of California, Riverside scholar has been awarded a Fulbright grant to conduct research at the University of Sao Paulo in Brazil for 2018-19.

title: UCLA Leader Named as Dean of Bourns College of Engineering
description: A UCLA engineering leader with a vision for UC Riverside’s ability to meet California’s STEM needs has been named the new dean of the Marlan and Rosemary Bourns College of Engineering. Christopher S. Lynch will join Bourns as dean on September 1. Lynch is the chair of the UCLA Samueli School of Engineering’s Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering Department.

title: UCLA leader named dean of Bourns College of Engineering
description: A UCLA engineering leader with a vision for UC Riverside’s ability to meet California’s STEM needs has been named the new dean of the Marlan and Rosemary Bourns College of Engineering. Christopher S. Lynch will join Bourns as dean on September 1. Lynch is the chair of the UCLA Samueli School of Engineering’s Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering Department.

title: Kimberly Guerrero co-starring in CBS drama pilot
description: The show is described as “Northern Exposure” meets “The West Wing.”

title: University lends a hand by lending doctors a bed
description: The top floor of the UC Riverside Extension building has a new and esteemed set of occupants: doctors and other health care workers on the front lines of the battle against the COVID-19 pandemic. About two weeks ago, the university received two requests to provide healthcare workers with alternative housing. The requests came from the Riverside County Medical Association and on behalf UCR School of Medicine residents.

title: Faculty member pens book to help researchers work ‘Online, Offline, and In Between’
description: Work includes field notes and observations of in-person and virtual research.

title: University Extension receives federal grant to help train the local labor force
description: The United States Department of Labor has awarded nearly $1 million to UC Riverside’s University Extension to help train the Southern California’s labor force.

title: Boyle Heights: Cemented in history
description: Capturing the essence of a place requires more than time. It requires confianza. Trust.    That’s why for more than a year a team co-led by a UC Riverside cultural and urban historian interviewed, researched, and documented the lives of Boyle Heights residents — all in the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic. For centuries, Boyle Heights, a community three miles east of downtown Los Angeles, has been home to generations of immigrants and social justice movements.

title: Want to know L.A.'s Latinx story? Follow the music posters
description: Beginning around 1990, the demographic landscape of the Los Angeles area changed dramatically through an infusion of immigrants from Mexico and Central America. But historian Jorge Leal says its impact on the neighborhoods of the Los Angeles area has never been charted in earnest. With his recently published research, Leal has taken a furtive step into documenting the Latinx community’s emerging L.A. footprint, using an unconventional source. If you want to know about the Latinx community’s presence in L.A. over the past 30 years, Leal says to follow the music posters.

title: UCR has money to help students re-enroll
description: More than $188,000 in HEERF funds are available for students who stopped coming to UCR during the 2020-21 school year for COVID-19 related reasons.

title: Pandemic gun-buying binge crosses party lines
description: A fear for health and safety has driven a record number of American gun sales

title: Gun control legislation is popular; why won't it pass?
description: The routine has been too familiar for too many years. A school shooting or mass shooting event occurs and stirs the American consciousness for a moment. But a week or two passes and talk of gun-control legislation fades. The issue goes into hibernation until the next mass shooting event. In 2018, an opinion article by UCR political science Professor Ben Bishin was published in The Washington Post. It was Bishin's attempt to explain why the cycle keeps repeating itself, and who's to blame.

title: Gun violence pressures elected officials to make reforms
description: With three mass shooting within a week leaving 24 Californians dead, public policy makers are searching for answers.

title: Picosecond electron transfer in peptides can help energy technologies
description: Hydrogen bonds reshape peptides to move electrons a million times faster than previously known

title: Inland Empire economy to expand further in 2018
description: Latest data show IE home prices are fastest growing in Southern California

title: Sundance: Guerrero to star as Wilma Mankiller in ‘The Glorias’
description: The film premieres this weekend at the Sundance Film Festival .

description: Use them as gift ideas — or just to treat yourself.

title: RISE classrooms featured on Spectrum News
description: UC Riverside's Rooms for Increasing Student Engagement, or RISE, received the star treatment on Spectrum News recently. The rooms are a campuswide initiative spurred by the pandemic to meet instructional needs, including for in-person and remote learning. The segment featured Israel Fletes, the director of academic technology for XCITE at UC Riverside, and math professor Estela Gavosto.

title: Who’s responsible for roadside rubbish?
description: New UC Riverside research reveals that items in litter typically originate less than two miles from where they’re found — and unless humans remove them, most of these items will never leave the environment.

title: UCR Joins Pen America in Reading Original Works of Resistance
description: For thousands, it was a week to march for civil and human rights. For the Department of Creative Writing, it was also a week to write and speak out for them.

title: UCR Bioengineer Awarded Fulbright Grant
description: A University of California, Riverside scholar has been awarded a Fulbright grant to conduct research at the University of Sao Paulo in Brazil for 2018-19.

title: Supercomputing improves biomass fuel conversion
description: Researchers combine supercomputing with nano-imaging to reveal how to efficiently break down plant biomass and transform it into transportation fuels

title: UCR among top 1% of world universities
description: UC Riverside retains its place among the top 1% of universities, according to the World University Rankings. The campus ranked No. 242 in the 2021-22 list of the top 2,000 out of 19,788 institutions worldwide. UCR was named No. 82 nationally and in the top 50 public institutions in the US.

title: Villa-Lobos: An evening of cello and piano in Riverside
description: The festival was born from a partnership between Paulo C. Chagas, professor with the University of California, Riverside’ Department of Music, and internationally renowned cellist Lars Hoefs.

title: UCR spotlighted in discussion of mental health on campus
description: The widely circulated publication Inside Higher Ed published a story this past week that features a "virtual roundtable" at UC Riverside with the secretary of the U.S. Department of Education.

title: First comprehensive fundraising campaign nears its end
description: UC Riverside is closing in on the end of its first-ever comprehensive fundraising campaign. The total raised through August 23 was $298,116,805.

title: Music lecturer recognized by the National Endowment for the Arts
description: For the past 20 years Tagumpay Mendoza De Leon has been teaching Filipino rondalla music at UCR.

title: More printing locations available on campus
description: UCR adds 19 new printing kiosks throughout the university. The machines are available for students, staff, and faculty.

title: Critical groundwater supplies may never recover from drought
description: New UC Riverside research shows groundwater takes an average of three years to recover from drought — if it ever recovers at all. In the largest study of its kind, scientists found that this recovery time only applies to aquifers that aren’t touched by human activity, and the recovery time might be even longer in regions with excessive pumping.

title: Can the Salton Sea geothermal field prevent the coming lithium shortage?
description: University of California, Riverside scientists will join a first-of-its-kind effort to map out California’s so-called “Lithium Valley,” and learn whether it can meet America’s urgent demand for lithium in a sustainable, environmentally friendly way.

title: Bingeing in the time of coronavirus
description: State and federal officials are asking Americans to stay home during the COVID-19 pandemic.  So is it possible to find an entertaining activity that provides a small respite from our larger societal worries? Derek Burrill, associate professor of media and cultural studies at UC Riverside, has created a list of things to binge on while staying at home.

title: Experiments in growing algae without sunlight
description: Elizabeth Hann, a doctoral student in plant biology at UC Riverside, is using a two-year, $60,000 fellowship from the Link Foundation to test whether she can grow algae for biofuels completely in the dark using solar-generated electricity.

title: NEH grant helps research Pueblo, Colorado’s music history
description: Xóchitl C. Chávez, assistant professor of music at UCR, is a co-principal investigator.

title: UCR ARTS awarded National Endowment for the Arts grant
description: The grant will support “Christina Fernandez: Multiple Exposures,” an exhibition opening in fall 2022.

title: Pheromones lure deadly palm weevils to their doom
description: UC Riverside scientists have a new chemical weapon to seduce and kill the invasive, long-nosed beetles destroying California palm trees by the tens of thousands.

title: Biocompatible glue for corneal repair is a sight for sore eyes
description: The adhesive would replace stitches and conventional adhesive to speed healing and reduce complications and cost

title: Unwritten history: Seattle, a city built by immigrants and Indigenous people
description: ‘Seattle from the Margins,’ a new book by assistant professor Megan Asaka points to the overseen contributions of the Duwamish, Japanese, Filipino, Chinese, and other immigrant communities.

title: University of Maryland scholar is UCR’s next CHASS dean
description: Daryle Williams is a historian who co-directs the online database Enslaved.org.

title: New program aims to increase Latinx students conducting environmental research
description: A $342,000 grant has allowed the expansion of a UC Berkeley program to UCR.

title: Small slice of the American pie, big impact
description: An oral history project archives the experiences and contributions of more than 50 notable Korean Americans and counting

title: UCR freshmen admissions for fall 2020 up 17%
description: UCR admissions up 17% for fall 2020, with gains among underrepresented, first-generation, and low-income students.

title: Highlander Venture Fund invests in Basilard BioTech
description: The UC Riverside-based startup will use the investment to develop next-generation prototypes

title: Inspired by ‘Get Out,’ UCR professor launches course on Afrofuturism and horror
description: Class based on the Oscar-nominated film will see students map out their own versions of the “sunken place” in lieu of a final exam

title: New Livestreaming and Virtual Reality Lab is bringing VR to the masses
description: The lab aims to democratize virtual reality while also providing students new opportunities in the burgeoning digital media industry.

title: UCR 'EARS' students won't let pandemic stop the music
description: To a voyeur at this May 1 virtual songwriting session, it was straight-up fun; a valve release for pent-up pandemic creativity. But the undercurrent of the music production session among members of the UCR EARS music group was something more intentional. Once upon a musical ambition, hitting it big meant flagging the gaze of one of Berry Gordy’s or David Geffen’s minions in some smoky joint, or summoning the help of a DJ willing to give an unknown B-sider a spin on the turntable.

title: UCR ARTS: Christina Fernandez’s photo exhibition captures life
description: This is Fernandez’s first major solo museum show. The images reflect on various social issues and explores her Mexican American identity.

title: UC Riverside names head women's basketball coach
description: Nicole Powell is the Highlanders' new head coach.

title: How the Webb telescope could ultimately help protect Earth
description: UC Riverside astrophysicist Stephen Kane breaks down some unique aspects of the James Webb Space Telescope, explains how separate Venus projects intersect, and how both might benefit Earth.

title: Fundraising head at HBCU Morehouse to lead Advancement
description: UC Riverside has named Monique Michelle Dozier as its vice chancellor for University Advancement. Dozier is currently vice president for Advancement and chief advancement officer at Morehouse College in Atlanta, which is the nation’s only historically Black liberal arts college dedicated to educating and developing men of color, specifically Black men. She will begin her new role at UCR on Aug. 1 overseeing University Advancement, which includes Development, Alumni Engagement, Advancement Finance and Administration, and University Communications.

title: Money magazine ranks UCR No. 40 among 623 colleges
description: UC Riverside was ranked No. 40 on Money magazine’s latest “Best Values” college ranking, released May 16.  It represents an increase of eight places over Money's last best value list, on which UCR ranked No. 48. Among public universities, UCR ranked No. 31 on the list, up from No. 32.

title: The day the ‘60s protest movement came to UCR
description: Fifty years ago, Gov. Ronald Reagan visited UCR, and the campus’s largest-ever student protest erupted

title: The chemical controlling life and death in hair follicles
description: A single chemical is key to controlling when hair follicle cells divide, and when they die. This discovery could not only treat baldness, but ultimately speed wound healing because follicles are a source of stem cells.

title: New dean of School of Education named
description: Joi Spencer has been named the dean of UC Riverside’s School of Education, effective Jan. 1, 2023.  Spencer is a professor of Mathematics Education at the University of San Diego, in the School of Leadership and Education Sciences, or SOLES. During 16 years at USD, Spencer has been associate dean and, most recently, interim dean of SOLES.

title: Grants support programming for Underground Scholars Initiative
description: The money comes from UC Berkeley’s Underground Scholars, via grants from the Andrew Mellon and Crankstart foundations to support the expansion of the Underground Scholars model UC-wide.

title: University of California Application Filing Period Expanded
description: It was announced on Sept. 30 that prospective students looking to enter the University of California, or UC, system as first-years or transfers can now hit that submit button as early as Sat., Oct. 1.

title: Men's, women's basketball teams release schedules
description: UC Riverside's men's and women's basketball teams have released modified schedules for the 2020-21 season.

title: Men's, women's basketball open in Big West tourney
description: UC Riverside’s men’s and women’s basketball teams enter the Big West tournament this week, both propelled by winning streaks. The tournament is held in the new Dollar Loan Center in Henderson, Nevada. The women’s team (15-10, 10-6), led by coach Nicole Powell, has won eight straight games with its quarterfinal round win yesterday over fifth-seeded UCSB, 46-42. With the win, the fourth-seeded Highlanders will advance to the semi-finals on Friday, March 11, where they will take on top-ranked Hawaii at 12:00 p.m. on ESPN+.

title: UCR continues to build a robust remote learning environment for students and faculty
description: Richard Edwards, director of XCITE, shares how UCR has met the challenges of remote learning and the new technologies adopted over the last six months

title: Study provides new insight into why galaxies stop forming stars
description: A team of UCR-led scientists get best measure yet of why star formation stopped in galaxy clusters in the early universe

title: Professor’s own body becomes physiology lab during pandemic
description: Just call him Professor Guinea Pig. Adapting to remote learning this quarter, Professor Rich Cardullo is performing all the experiments for his human physiology laboratory course — on himself.

title: Winter quarter will be mostly remote again
description: In communications sent Oct. 23 and Nov. 30, UCR laid out instructional plans for its winter quarter, which will look much like fall quarter. Fifty courses have been approved for in-class instruction in winter quarter. All will offer students the option of remote instruction.

title: UCR campus set to reopen in fall 2021
description: On Jan. 11, UC President Michael V. Drake announced a fall 2021 systemwide return to in-person instruction.

title: Fall won't be just 'either-or'; it may also be 'both'
description: Only a few weeks ago, it appeared UCR instructors had two choices for instruction in fall 2021: in-person, or remote. A group charged with preparing for fall instruction realized something was missing.

title: For start of winter quarter, an almost-empty campus
description: The omicron variant of COVID-19 has shuttered UC Riverside's classrooms, if only for a short time.  Like most University of California campuses, UCR opted to postpone in-person instruction, owing to the emergence of the highly transmissible variant. The week of Jan. 17 was identified for returning to the classroom. While classrooms are closed, campus remains open. Residence halls, dining facilities, libraries, the bookstore, the Highlander Union Building, and the Student Recreation Center remain open, but with some reduced occupancy and hours.

title: Navigating UCR’s swift transition to remote learning
description: With directives to suspend in-person classes in response to COVID-19, UCR moves to campus wide online instruction

title: Buckley was invited; the pig who peed wasn't
description: Considered by itself, William F. Buckley Jr. having offered the commencement address to the UC Riverside Class of 1970 might lead one to infer this was a time of greater kumbaya among conservatives and liberals. One would be dissuaded by a retelling of the day’s events, including the on-stage introduction of a pig—the pig not being Buckley.

title: Scholar compares exits in Vietnam, Afghanistan
description: Vietnam expert David Biggs compares the U.S. exits from Vietnam and Afghanistan, and finds lessons in Vietnam's eventual prosperity.

title: Latest rankings place UCR at No. 12 among U.S. colleges
description: UC Riverside jumped 20 places — to No. 12 in the U.S. and No. 9 among public universities — in a prestigious college ranking list published annually by Money magazine. As the trend of shifting formulas among the top rankings lists continues, Chancellor Kim Wilcox said UCR’s stature as a leading public university grows.  “It is deeply gratifying to see the national rankings systems having moved so profoundly toward recognizing what UCR does well: maintaining an environment of both research excellence and success for students of all backgrounds,” Wilcox said.

title: Beyond Brilliant: From juvenile detention to college graduation
description: A felony conviction gave Ramón Leija the determination to turn his life around.

title: Switching magnetic polarity at record speed
description: Researchers develop way to use magnetic materials for data storage that is 50 times faster than previous attempts

title: Astronomers discover unusual monster galaxy in the very early universe
description: XMM-2599 lived fast and died young, says UC Riverside-led international team

title: UC responds to Prop 16 outcome
description: As California voters again voted down affirmative action, the University of California and UC Riverside affirmed their commitment to building the system’s underrepresented student population. Proposition 16, which failed 56.1% to 43.9%, would have repealed 1996’s Proposition 209, which— among other things—banned the consideration of race, ethnicity, and gender in college admissions decisions.

title: 'A Happy Homecoming' for Michael Drake
description: In a crisp blue suit, new UC President Michael Drake addressed the challenges facing the UC system in terms of the pandemic and budget shortfalls, and announced the advent of his personal “looking and listening tour.”

title: Study explores infant body position and learning
description: UC Riverside psychologist’s research provides strong evidence that infants’ motor skills directly impact the physical context of their everyday experiences

title: Research reveals ancient Maya lessons on surviving drought
description: A new UC Riverside study casts doubt on drought as the driver of ancient Mayan civilization collapse.

title: Pandemic hasn't deterred UCR applicants; new record is set
description: Defying pandemic-influenced predictions and national trends, the University of California, Riverside has posted record freshman applications for fall 2021.   A total of 52,263 applications were received for the fall 2021 freshman class. That represents an increase over the previous record of 49,252 for fall 2020.

title: Simple experiment explains magnetic resonance
description: UC Riverside physics students design a table-top experiment for the classroom

title: New freshman application record set for UCR
description: The University of California, Riverside has posted record freshman applications for fall 2022.  A total of 54,365 applications were received by the UCR freshman application deadline of Nov. 30. That represents an increase over the previous record of 52,563 for fall 2021. The record prior to that was 49,252 for fall 2020.  UC-wide, 249,855 applications were received by at least one campus. The other eight UC campuses with undergraduate student populations also saw admissions increases.

title: Mystery of four-stranded DNA begins to unravel
description: DNA is usually depicted as double-stranded, but not much is known about parts of the genome that adopt four-stranded structures known as quadruplexes. UC Riverside researchers have discovered that they play a key role in keeping cells healthy.

title: Nanomaterial gives robots chameleon skin
description: A new film made of gold nanoparticles changes color in response to any type of movement. Its unprecedented qualities could allow robots to mimic chameleons and octopi — among other futuristic applications.

title: Light-powered soft robots could suck up oil spills
description: A floating, robotic film designed at UC Riverside could be trained to hoover oil spills at sea or remove contaminants from drinking water.

title: Scientists discover potential cause of Alzheimer’s Disease
description: Prevailing theories posit plaques in the brain cause Alzheimer’s disease. New UC Riverside research points to cells’ slowing ability to clean themselves as the likely cause of unhealthy brain buildup.

title: No Thanksgiving for bacteria or fungus
description: UC Riverside scientists have developed a technique for solving a decades-old mystery involving the chemical in turkey that makes people sleepy. Their new ability to map the atoms involved in the production of tryptophan opens the door to new antibiotic and antifungal drugs.

title: Injections for diabetes, cancer could become unnecessary
description: Researchers at UC Riverside are paving the way for diabetes and cancer patients to forget needles and injections, and instead take pills to manage their conditions.

title: UC Riverside joins new NSF center for the preservation of biological systems
description: The grant is the campus’ first successful bid for an NSF Engineering Research Center

title: Faster, Cheaper Wastewater Treatment Through Improved Oxidation Reactions
description: UCR researchers have developed a simple way to improve Advanced Oxidation Processes

title: Experts on aging
description: For fast access to experts, TEXT or call the 24-hour-experts hotline at 951-312-3049, or email news@ucr.edu  Aging   Ilana Bennett: Assistant professor of psychology. Effects of healthy aging and dementia on the brain and cognition; learning and memory in aging; neuroimaging markers of aging. Ilana.bennett@ucr.edu Brandon Brown: Associate professor, Center for Healthy Communities: HIV and aging. brandon.brown@medsch.ucr.edu

title: School of Medicine signs agreement with AIDS Healthcare Foundation
description: Partnership provides opportunities for UCR medical students to train at a Riverside clinic focused on AIDS treatment

title: UCR School of Medicine and Eisenhower Health establish training affiliation
description: Partnership addresses long-term healthcare needs of Coachella Valley

title: Trust the power of markets
description: People trust decisions made by groups, but information markets are more accurate

title: UC Riverside celebrates campaign completion Feb. 18-20
description: More than 66,000 donors made gifts during the Living the Promise campaign, and the total amount raised will be announced at a live virtual event on Feb 20.

title: Gamma-ray laser moves a step closer to reality
description: Calculations by UC Riverside’s Allen Mills predict metastable positronium bubbles in liquid helium

title: To impress females, Costa’s hummingbirds “sing” with their tail feathers
description: UCR Researchers show how male Costa’s control the acoustics of a tail song produced during high speed dives

title: Lasers can weld ceramics without a furnace
description: Ultrafast pulsed lasers fuse ceramics under ambient conditions and use less than 50 watts of power

title: Silicone membranes create micron-scale temperature maps
description: Development could improve microfluidic devices used for point-of-care diagnostics

title: Double bubbles pierce with less trouble
description: Two optical cavitation bubbles penetrate soft materials better than one

title: Tobacco shops associated with crime in urban communities of color
description: UC Riverside-led study, focused on South Los Angeles, also suggests that medical marijuana dispensaries may not be closely linked to neighborhood violence

title: Pandemic driving reductions won't reduce greenhouse gas emissions much
description: Economists find commuting is the only driving category to remain diminished

title: Grant will help engineer human-like nerve tissue
description: The tissue will be used to study neurological diseases

title: Mike Magpayo extended as head men’s basketball coach
description: UC Riverside Athletics announced today that Mike Magpayo, the 2021 Joe B. Hall Award winner, has been tabbed to lead the UC Riverside men’s basketball program forward on a permanent basis and has officially signed to a five-year contract.

title: So cute you could crush it?
description: A UC Riverside professor’s first-of-its-kind study explores the neural underpinnings of cute aggression

title: New! Engineering Transfer Student Center to Open
description: New school. New classes. New study groups. The transition from a community college to a four-year institution can be difficult but the opening of a new transfer student center at UCR’s Marlan and Rosemary Bourns College of Engineering will help prepare transfer students as they begin the next step in their academic careers. The center, located in Winston Chung Hall, will officially open during a ceremony held on January 8, 2019 from 1 p.m.

title: Physicist to use optical trapping methods to study basic properties of solid-state materials
description: NSF-funded research represents a new approach to the field of 'crystal engineering'

title: Superbloom? If you say so
description: Superbloom is a term concocted by the media, but this year’s wildflowers are still spectacular, especially for the creatures that depend on them

title: The future of the town hall is online
description: Kevin Esterling’s advice to tech companies? Listen to — and learn from — political scientists

title: Business size matters when it comes to economic growth
description: New analysis finds small businesses are powering establishment growth, but medium and large firms contribute more to job gains

title: UC Staff engagement survey results to be discussed at forum
description: RSVP by Jan. 9 to attend the campuswide meeting and share ideas

title: Tomás Rivera Conference continues online
description: Weekly programs surrounding Latino/a literature, identities, race, and more, run through early November.

title: A 50th anniversary celebration for Tomás Rivera’s seminal book: ‘Y no se lo tragó la tierra’
description: The free, virtual events will culminate with an inaugural Tomás Rivera Book Prize.

title: Being ‘Other’ in America
description: When Nora Guerraoui receives word her father has been killed in an apparent hit-and-run, she is forced to return to the small California desert town she left behind and contend with the many memories she’s tried to forget. So sets the stage of “The Other Americans,” the latest novel by Laila Lalami published by Pantheon on March 26.

title: New research shows how the malaria parasite grows and multiplies
description: Study co-led by UC Riverside scientist could help develop strategies to combat the disease

title: Genome structure of malaria parasites linked to virulence
description: UC Riverside-led research could help develop novel therapeutic strategies to combat malaria

title: Early opaque universe linked to galaxy scarcity
description: Team led by UC Riverside astronomer George Becker used the Subaru telescope to make the discovery

title: LA Times examines link between SAT scores, success at UCR
description: An L.A. Times feature by higher education writer Teresa Watanabe describes UCR as a "living laboratory" in which to study how well students with high grades but low SAT scores fare in college.  UCR has the second-lowest SAT scores in the UC system for its entering freshmen. But Times research found there is only a two-point difference in graduation rates between those with SAT scores between 900-1090 and those who scored between 1100-1600.

title: Quantum leap for quantum computing
description: UC Riverside will lead collaborative effort at developing scalable quantum computers

title: UCR scientist rediscovers insect lost for 105 years
description: Little is known about elusive beetle species, despite role in wildflower pollination

title: Murder hornets invade headlines, not the U.S.
description: Though “murder hornets” are dominating recent headlines, there are no Asian Giant Hornets currently known to be living in the U.S. or Canada, according to UC Riverside Entomology Research Museum Senior Scientist Doug Yanega.

title: Physicists name and codify new field in nanotechnology: ‘electron quantum metamaterials’
description: UC Riverside’s Nathaniel Gabor and colleague formulate a vision for the field in a perspective article

title: Study documents poor mental and physical health in rural borderland community members
description: UC Riverside-led study offers vivid picture of health consequences of life events and chronic strain among foreign-born Mexicans in farm working communities

title: Experts on Vaccine Passports
description: UC Riverside has several experts who can comment on certificates of immunity or "vaccine passports."

title: Two ECE faculty on most highly cited list
description: Two electrical and computer engineering (ECE) faculty at the University of California, Riverside have been named to the 2018 Highly Cited Researchers list compiled by Clarivate Analytics, which was previously part of the Thomson Reuters.

title: Hispanic enrollment report names UCR No. 1
description: UC Riverside stands alone among the nation’s 428 more selective public universities by exceeding its potential for the number of Hispanic students it enrolls, according to new report from the Washington, D.C.-based Urban Institute.

title: Inland Empire tech industry should focus on local strengths
description: Growth efforts should link to logisitics, agriculture, and green tech

title: UCR plant cell biologist elected to National Academy of Sciences
description: Sean Cutler becomes ninth UC Riverside faculty member elected to the prestigious academy

title: Why multifamily housing is expensive to build in Los Angeles
description: Report calls for policymakers to enact zoning and other reforms

title: Gordon Watkins: The man who willed a university into being
description: Most things, including universities, start with a whisper, a tremor. UC Riverside bolted from the starting gate, founded as the University of California system’s answer to the esteemed private liberal arts colleges of the East. The chief architect was its first provost, Gordon Watkins, who died 50 years ago, on May 5, 1970. The character of UCR at its founding was said to be the character of Watkins. In fact, UCR’s popular designation at the time was “Watkins college.”

title: Ten UC Riverside professors receive NSF CAREER awards
description: The awards support early career leaders in research and education

title: Study links individual HPV types to HIV infection
description: UC Riverside-led study finds persons with any HPV type, more than one HPV type, or high-risk HPV are more likely to test HIV positive

title: UC Riverside bioengineer seeks to calm influenza’s cytokine storms
description: Work on selective immune system suppression in influenza could transfer directly to COVID-19

title: NIH grant supports new exploratory research aimed at studying Pacific Islander behavioral health
description: UC Riverside-led study will concentrate on alcohol use disorders in Pacific Islander young adults

title: For racial minority adolescents, cigarette and alcohol use tied to suicide
description: Examining more than 20 years of national data for U.S. adolescents, a research team led by Andrew Subica at the University of California, Riverside reports that adolescents have high prevalence of alcohol, cigarette, and marijuana use, and concerning rates of suicide-related thoughts and behaviors.

title: Science fair aimed at Spanish-speaking families set for May 19
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif. (www.ucr.edu) — The University of California, Riverside, is hosting a free, public event on Saturday, May 19, aimed at the Spanish-speaking community. Children, teens, college students, and adults are invited to “Fiesta Familiar: Explorando La Ciencia Juntos,” presented entirely in Spanish, from 10 a.m. to 1 p.m. at the UCR Student Recreation Center.

title: Experts on huanglongbing/citrus greening
description: For fast access to experts, TEXT or call the 24-hour-experts hotline at 951-312-3049, or email news@ucr.edu  Huanglongbing/citrus greening   Jim Adaskaveg: Professor of plant pathology. Disease of tree crops grown in California; biology; epidemiology; ecology of plant pathogenic fungi; mycology; ultra-structure of host-pathogen relationships; biology of wood decay fungi; biological and molecular techniques for the detection and identification of pathogens. jim.adaskaveg@ucr.edu

title: Experts on the environment and climate change
description: For fast access to experts, TEXT or call the 24-hour-experts hotline at 951-312-3049, or email news@ucr.edu

title: Experts on immigration
description: For fast access to experts, TEXT or call the 24-hour-experts hotline at 951-312-3049, or email news@ucr.edu  Immigration   Cecilia Ayón: Associate professor of public policy. Economic, social, and health effects of discrimination; how hostile policy climates contribute to higher stress levels among immigrant communities, particularly those living in Arizona. cecilia.ayon@ucr.edu

title: Keeping the peace when mom and grandma disagree on feeding the kids
description: Nutrition education programs for children should incorporate all family members who act as caregivers

title: Experts on trade
description: For fast access to experts, TEXT or call the 24-hour-experts hotline at 951-312-3049, or email news@ucr.edu  Trade   Jana Grittersova: Associate professor of political science. Sources of government reputation in international markets, international banking, the effects of interest groups on the credibility of international monetary and financial commitments, the role of nonmarket coordination in financial-system development, and political economy of reform. jana.grittersova@ucr.edu

title: UC Riverside receives $4.5 million for engineering graduate education
description: Five GAANN Awards from the U.S. Department of Education will support 90 engineering graduate students

title: Grains in the rain
description: Of the major food crops, only rice is currently able to survive flooding. Thanks to new research, that could soon change -- good news for a world in which rains are increasing in both frequency and intensity.

title: Professor creates artist residency for veterans and COVID-19 frontline workers
description: When the coronavirus pandemic hit, Charles Evered, a professor of playwriting at the University of California, Riverside, began to think about how he could help. He fell back on what he knows: supporting artists. His nonprofit organization, the Evered House, honors his late father, Charles J. Evered, a World War II Army Air Corpsman who succumbed to lung cancer over 40 years ago.

title: Experts on issues in higher education
description: For fast access to experts, TEXT or call the 24-hour-experts hotline at 951-312-3049, or email news@ucr.edu  Issues in higher education Kim Wilcox: Chancellor. Advocates for a university system that acknowledges the importance of raising students’ socioeconomic status; will speak to the disproportionate attention paid to the nation’s private, elite universities; legacy admissions; college access; free college tuition; and the U.S. News rankings. kim.wilcox@ucr.edu.

title: Experts on gun violence and gun policy
description: For fast access to experts, TEXT or call the 24-hour-experts hotline at 951-312-3049, or email news@ucr.edu  Gun violence and gun policy

title: Rewriting the textbook on how steroid hormones enter cells
description: Identification of a transporter that ferries steroids into cells could bring widespread benefits for human health

title: UC Riverside physicists create exotic electron liquid
description: The first production of an electron liquid at room temperature opens the way for new optoelectronic devices and basic physics studies

title: New attacks on graphics processors endanger user privacy
description: Hackers can use the graphics processing unit to spy on web activity, steal passwords, and break into cloud-based applications

title: Electrons take one step forward without two steps back
description: Scientists use molecular dipoles to accelerate electron transfer in one direction and completely suppress it in the other. This “holy grail” of energy science could hasten the design of new and superb energy and electronic materials

title: Six theater employees sew face masks for their colleagues
description: The goal is to make at least 750 masks, which are free for essential UCR employees.

title: First sighting of mysterious Majorana fermion on a common metal
description: Physicists’ discovery could lead to a new family of materials for robust qubits in quantum computing

title: Testing chemicals for birth defects using stem cells, not mice
description: UC Riverside researchers are helping the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency eliminate animal testing

title: Does the presence of colleges and hospitals increase home prices?
description: The institution’s size and the ZIP code’s population can have positive and negative effects

title: How do insects survive on a sugary diet?
description: Study offers clues to how aphids capitalize on relationship with beneficial bacteria through changes in gene expression linked to DNA methylation

title: $2.3 million NIH grant will support efforts to stop mosquito-borne diseases
description: National Institutes of Health award to UCR’s Naoki Yamanaka recognizes highly innovative research

title: Book co-authored by GSOE dean tackles need to improve math education
description: If you think you're not a "math person," you might want to consider why

title: DNS cache poisoning ready for a comeback
description: Derandomizing the source port enables attacks that work on all layers of DNS caches

title: This computer scientist beats hackers at their own game
description: Fatemah Alharbi discovered a serious security flaw, earning thanks from Apple

title: The world is much more alike than different
description: The cornerstone of discrimination is the belief that other people, including people of other races from other countries, are different. They experience life differently; they react differently.  What if research could demonstrate that’s not true? A new study from UC Riverside asserts the world population may have much more in common than it has differences.

title: Family is our focus during pandemic, study finds
description: More fully appreciating family and engaging in more conflict are among the heightened experiences during the coronavirus pandemic, according to a new UC Riverside study. The study from David Funder’s psychology lab looked at how people experience everyday life and its situations and how those experiences change because of an extraordinary event – the global pandemic.

title: How you measure happiness depends where you live
description: The meaning of happiness varies depending where in the world a person lives and so benefits from using different measures, new UC Riverside research finds. Happiness studies historically have focused on the Western ideal of happiness, which is relatively self-centered and big on thrills.

title: UC Riverside research compels response in cyber-security breach
description: Hackers look for vulnerabilities within computer systems, which are constructed for high performance to meet consumer demand. Tensions between systems administrators protecting the network, and those seeking to attack it, run high.

title: UCR research compels response in cyber-security breach
description: Hackers look for vulnerabilities within computer systems, which are constructed for high performance to meet consumer demand. Tensions between systems administrators protecting the network, and those seeking to attack it, run high.

title: Mobile clinics can help address health care needs of Latino farmworkers
description: A University of California, Riverside, study that sought to determine barriers to health care among Spanish-speaking Latino farmworkers in rural communities has devised an innovative health care service delivery model that addresses many challenges these communities face.

title: Free dataset archive helps researchers quickly find a needle in a haystack
description: UCR STAR visualizes public spatio-temporal datasets through an interactive map

title: Chatbots for dementia patients and caregivers need more work
description: Systematic review of apps finds need for evidence-based chatbots that have undergone end user evaluation

title: Vaping lung injury symptoms have been reported online for at least seven years
description: UC Riverside research used internet data mining to monitor health effects reported by electronic cigarette users over time

title: Should we be double masking?
description: UC Riverside epidemiologist answers this and other questions in Q&A

title: New Spectre cyberthreat evades patches
description: New speculative execution attack launches from a computer’s return stack buffer, not the branch predictor

title: New security flaw discovered in Wi-Fi routers
description: Hackers can use your wireless router to extract information, and there’s not much you can do to stop them

title: SourceFinder software stalks malware in the wild
description: UC Riverside computer scientists develop tool to locate malware source code repositories

title: Deafness trumps HIV for deaf people living with HIV
description: UC Riverside-led study participants advocate for collection of more data on deaf individuals

title: Botnet buster finds IoT command and control centers
description: Tool fools malware twice and can trick it into revealing itself

title: UC Riverside and Neuroscience Education Institute partner to deliver continuing medical education nationwide
description: Content developed by School of Medicine for physicians and other health care professionals includes grand rounds and a journal club delivered virtually

title: Why don’t veterans share their stories?
description: What ma

title: Older adults: Daunted by learning a new task? Learn three
description: Learning several new things at once increases cognitive abilities in older adults, according to new research from UC Riverside. UCR psychologist Rachel Wu says one important way of staving off cognitive decline is learning new skills as a child would. That is, be a sponge: seek new skills to learn; maintain motivation as fuel; rely on encouraging mentors to guide you; thrive in an environment where the bar is set high.

title: Understanding bacteria’s metabolism could improve biofuel production
description: A new study reveals how bacteria control the chemicals produced from consuming ‘food.’ The insight could lead to organisms that are more efficient at converting plants into biofuels.  The study, authored by scientists at UC Riverside and Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, has been published in the Journal of the Royal Society Interface.

title: Making freshman calculus add up for more students
description: UC Riverside is leading a new, $1.26 million project to bring calculus classes to life for students who are underrepresented in science, technology, engineering, and math subjects.

title: Harmful metals found in vapors from tank-style electronic cigarettes
description: UC Riverside study analyzed six popular e-cigarette tanks and their atomizers

title: UCR student researcher takes smoking personally
description: You don’t want Careen Khachatoorian for a sister. Not if you smoke, you don’t. Careen’s older brother is trying to conceive a child with his partner. A typical text to her smoker-brother includes a link to a sins-of-smoking article, and reads like this: “See? Pregnant mothers have a greater chance of delivering a child with ADHD if they are exposed to smoke.” Or…  “See? Cigarette smokers don’t produce as much sperm.”

title: JUUL electronic cigarette products linked to cellular damage
description: Study by UC Riverside and Portland State University scientists finds nicotine concentrations in JUULs is dangerously high

title: Fake news can’t fool new algorithm
description: An algorithm that can already detect fake news stories with 75 percent accuracy gets a boost from Snap Research

title: Data mining tools combat COVID-19 misinformation and identify symptoms
description: Computer scientists use Google Trends and a government dataset to track symptoms and sift through misinformation

title: Chemical compound produces beneficial inflammation and remyelination that could help treat multiple sclerosis
description: UC Riverside-led study shows that ‘good inflammation’ promotes axon myelination

title: Like peanut butter? This algorithm has a hunch as to what you'll buy next
description: A new technique can incorporate customer behavior into recommendation algorithms

title: Scientists unlock genetic secrets of wine growers’ worst enemy
description: Following a decade-long effort, scientists have mapped out the genome of an aphid-like pest capable of decimating vineyards. In so doing, they have discovered how it spreads — and potentially how to stop it.

title: UCR among national leaders in degrees that 'pay off'
description: UC Riverside ranked No. 14 among universities nationally in CNBC Make It’s annual “50 Colleges that Pay Off the Most” list. Editors for CNBC Make-It, which is a business-news site, said the ranking carries greater weight due to scrutiny of higher education costs-benefits in the COVID-19 pandemic.

title: When bees get a taste for dead things
description: Typically, bees don’t eat meat. However, a species of stingless 'vulture' bee in the tropics has evolved the ability to do so, presumably due to intense competition for nectar. UC Riverside scientists find these bees' guts resemble those of hyenas and other carrion feeders.

title: Climate-induced soil changes may cause more erosion and flash flooding
description: More intensive water cycle could have impact on biodiversity, human health, and water and food security

title: UCR professor is historical consultant to Jason Momoa’s new film ‘The Last Manhunt’
description: Saban Films just secured worldwide distribution rights to the movie shot in Banning and Joshua Tree.

title: UC Riverside is No. 1 in Pell Grant performance
description: A dive into Washington Monthly’s recent ranking of 393 four-year universities reveals an important success: UC Riverside is the No. 1 university in the nation for Pell Grant performance. The measure considers how many low-income students a university serves compared with statewide earnings. The Pell Grant is the largest federal grant program offered to undergraduates and is typically awarded to students from households earning less than $65,000 per year.

title: U.S. News names UCR No. 1 public for social mobility
description: UC Riverside is the top public university in the U.S. for social mobility, according to the just-released 2022-23 U.S. News & World Report college rankings.

title: Magazine ranks UCR No. 4 for Pell Grant performance
description: Washington Monthly magazine has ranked UC Riverside No. 4 among 444 universities nationwide in terms of its Pell Grant student performance. The accolade, released Monday as part of Washington Monthly’s 2022 college rankings, represents UCR’s excellence in several Pell performance categories that were factored. Those include:

title: UC Riverside reaches 77.3% for six-year graduation rate
description: UC Riverside’s six-year graduation rate — considered a leading measure of higher education excellence — has realized a new record. According to new numbers from UCR’s Office of Institutional Research, among freshmen who entered UCR in 2014, 77.3% graduated by 2020. That breaks the previous record of 76%, set last year.

title: UC Riverside registers greatest gain in U.S. News rankings
description: UC Riverside made larger gains than any university in the United States in the 2019 U.S. News & World Report Best Colleges rankings.

title: Pumpkins, trunk-o-treat, and family fun at UC Riverside
description: UCR’s Community Garden will host its inaugural Fall Festival and Pumpkin Patch on Oct. 26.

title: Research offers superior therapeutic approach for MS
description: Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune disease that affects more than 2.3 million people worldwide. This debilitating condition periodically shutters communication between the brain and other parts of the body, resulting in symptoms that range from numbness and tingling in the arms and legs to blindness and paralysis. While treatments are available to alleviate inflammation, no therapies exist to protect neurons or repair the degraded myelin sheath that normally surrounds nerves.

title: Remyelinating drug could improve vision in patients with multiple sclerosis
description: UC Riverside-led mouse study stresses MS treatment should be started early

title: UCR researchers take up fight against fake news
description: Algorithms reveal patterns to help identify misinformation

title: New journal will spotlight queer and trans religious studies scholarship
description: The open access journal will make research freely available to scholars and public and will not charge authors a submission fee

title: In blue & gold, maps reveal bias in the United States
description: A series of maps created by a UCR professor highlights hot spots for intergroup bias across the nation. The researchers aggregated data to determine the regions where implicit and explicit bias are greatest related to race, weight, and sexual preference.

title: In new economic index, UCR is No. 18 nationally
description: Anew measure of higher education excellence called the Economic Mobility Index, or EMI, ranks UCR No. 18 nationally. The ranking is from a non-profit think tank named Third Way, and aims to measure the role universities play in catalyzing the economy.

title: In new economic index, UCR is No. 18 nationally
description: A new measure of higher education excellence called the Economic Mobility Index, or EMI, ranks UCR No. 18 nationally. The ranking is from a non-profit think tank named Third Way, and aims to measure the role universities play in catalyzing the economy.

title: Meet UCR’s paleontology power pair
description: Paleontologist Nigel Hughes has earned one of the highest honors in his field, an achievement made even more remarkable because last year’s winner was another UCR paleontologist — Mary Droser, his wife.

title: Why Venus rotates, slowly, despite sun’s powerful grip
description: If not for the soupy, fast-moving atmosphere on Venus, Earth’s sister planet would likely not rotate. Instead, Venus would be locked in place, always facing the sun the way the same side of the moon always faces Earth.

title: Demolition makes way for student housing expansion
