description: The first of more than 150 buildings was claimed by a wrecker on Monday, July 22, at a shuttered housing complex that will become the site of a massive student housing expansion at UC Riverside.  The razing of the 50-acre, World War II-era housing complex that came to be known as Canyon Crest Family Student Housing began on July 22 with a small bungalow, with the first blows struck around 10:15 a.m.

title: UCR ranked No. 23 among best value colleges in new college guide
description: UC Riverside is ranked high for financial aid, making an impact, and value in the Princeton Review’s “Best 388 Colleges for 2023.” The lists are based on the Princeton Review’s survey of 160,000 students attending the 388 colleges and universities profiled. They appear in the 2023 edition of the annual college guide, which will be released Aug. 23.

title: Extraterrestrial objects likely delayed complex life on Earth
description: Bombardment of Earth’s surface by asteroids six or more miles long likely delayed the accumulation of oxygen in Earth’s atmosphere. This, in turn, likely delayed the development of complex life on the planet, according to new research that included UC Riverside scientists.

title: UC Riverside crests 76% for six-year graduation rate
description: In the past six years, UC Riverside's six-year graduation rate has improved by 10 percentage points

title: Forbes magazine ranks UC Riverside No. 33 public university
description: UC Riverside is the No. 33 public university in a college ranking from Forbes magazine. UCR was among several UC campuses and 17 public universities in the top 50. The methodology for the Forbes list relies on data from two federal databases, the Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, or IPEDS, and the College Scorecard, as well as several databases that gauge graduates’ earning.

title: 'The Most Important World Leader Since World War II'
description: Mikhail Gorbachev is the man whose actions inserted the terms perestroika and glasnost into the international vernacular. In 1985, Mikhail Gorbachev became the leader of the Soviet Union, presiding over a remarkable five-year span during which until-then unimaginable democratic reforms were instituted,  the Berlin Wall fell, communism was virtually wiped from Eastern Europe, and the Soviet Republic crumbled.

title: Lesser known ozone layer’s outsized role in planet warming
description: New UC Riverside-led research has identified a lesser-known form of ozone playing a big role in heating the Southern Ocean — one of Earth’s main cooling systems.

title: Ancient microbes may help us find extraterrestrial life forms
description: Using light-capturing proteins in living microbes, UC Riverside scientists helped reconstruct what life was like for some of Earth’s earliest organisms. These efforts could help us one day recognize signs of life on other planets.

title: Remembering ‘isotope queen’ Marilyn Fogel, pioneering scientist, beloved mentor
description: Marilyn Fogel, endowed geoecology professor at UC Riverside, died on May 11 in Mariposa, Calif. She was 69. She pioneered the use of isotopes to understand the life history of organisms, both modern and ancient. In so doing, she helped develop biogeochemistry as a new field of science and earned the moniker ‘isotope queen.’

title: The queen is dead. Will the monarchy survive? Should it?
description: Sept. 8, Queen Elizabeth II died at 96 after a 70-year reign, the longest of any British monarch in history. We asked a UC Riverside British history expert, Jonathan Eacott, and a British-born UCR political scientist, Shaun Bowler, to assess the future of the monarchy.

title: Why Jupiter doesn’t have rings like Saturn
description: Because it’s bigger, Jupiter ought to have larger, more spectacular rings than Saturn has. But new UC Riverside research shows Jupiter’s massive moons prevent that vision from lighting up the night sky.

title: Sleeping giant could end deep ocean life
description: A previously overlooked factor — the position of continents — helps fill Earth’s oceans with life-supporting oxygen. Continental movement could ultimately have the opposite effect, killing most deep ocean creatures.

title: Laughing gas in space could mean life
description: Scientists at UC Riverside are suggesting something is missing from the typical roster of chemicals that astrobiologists use to search for life on planets around other stars — laughing gas.

title: UCR Citrus Gifts expands online with citrus and honey-infused marmalades, soaps, and more
description: The fruits of UC Riverside’s research are even easier to enjoy with the Citrus Gifts collection expanding its line of products and making them available online. The collection, featuring marmalades and olive oils from citrus and bee research, have been sold in campus stores for about six years. In June, the campus began selling them online to expand their availability to the wider campus community and alumni. “This idea of creating this very unique UCR gift item is a way to take a piece of UCR home with you,” said Leslie Gerretse, senior manager for Hospitality Services.

title: Massive Mexican earthquakes warn Southern Californians
description: A pair of massive earthquakes in Mexico has some in Southern California on edge, wondering whether the Golden State is next. UC Riverside seismologist Abhijit Ghosh weighs in on the likelihood of more shakers, and how to prepare for them.

title: Could more of Earth’s surface host life?
description: Of all known planets, Earth is as friendly to life as any planet could possibly be — or is it? If Jupiter’s orbit changes, a new study shows Earth could be more hospitable than it is today.

title: Broccoli gas: a better way to find life in space
description: Broccoli, along with other plants and microorganisms, emit gases to help them expel toxins. Scientists believe these gases could provide compelling evidence of life on other planets.

title: Tiniest Ever Ancient Seawater Pockets Revealed
description: The surprising discovery of seawater sealed in what is now North America for 390 million years opens up a new avenue for understanding how oceans change and adapt with changing climate.

title: How do non-parental family members affect LGBTQ youth housing stability?
description: A study set in the Inland Empire and South Texas aims to find out

title: “I just don’t think shelters work”
description: Institutions, not only family rejection, underlie LGBTQ youth homelessness

title: Discovery could dramatically narrow search for space creatures
description: An Earth-like planet orbiting an M dwarf — the most common type of star in the universe — appears to have no atmosphere at all. This discovery could cause a major shift in the search for life on other planets.

title: Earth might be experiencing 7th mass extinction, not 6th
description: New research suggests environmental changes caused the first mass extinction event in history, which occurred millions of years earlier than scientists previously realized.

title: UC Riverside reaches No. 1 in social mobility
description: University of California, Riverside, is the top university in the United States for social mobility in the 2020 U.S. News & World Report Best Colleges rankings.

title: UCR No. 9 among public universities for sustainability
description: UC Riverside is ranked No. 9 among public universities in the Princeton Review’s Guide to Green Colleges. The campus was No. 27 on the overall list of Top 50 Green Colleges, released Oct. 25. The annual list recognizes institutions for superb sustainability practices, strong foundations in sustainability education, and healthy quality of life for students on campus.

title: Wall Street Journal rankings put UCR in top 50 publics
description: UCR Riverside moved into the top 50 public universities in a college rankings system from The Wall Street Journal and Times Higher Education. With the 2022 WSJ/THE report, UCR has climbed 184 positions in the overall rankings in the past five years.

title: UC Riverside No. 1 in U.S. News social mobility rankings
description: For the second consecutive year, UC Riverside is the No. 1 university in the country for social mobility in the U.S. News & World Report Best Colleges rankings.  UCR rose up the charts in the overall rankings as well, now placing No. 34 among all public universities and No. 88 overall.

title: Governor’s budget proposal allocates $25 million for UCR School of Medicine
description: Additional ongoing funding would help the medical school expand enrollment

title: UCR ARTS features work by UCR faculty and alumni in four new exhibitions
description: An opening reception featuring the artists will be held Oct. 16

title: Beyond Brilliant: Campaign highlights inspiring people of UC Riverside
description: Dramatic growth in rankings – including increasing 80 spots in two years (Forbes) and 41 places in one year (Center for World University Rankings) – two Nobel Prize winners joining the faculty, and recognition as the nation’s leader for social mobility (U.S. News & World Report) have positioned UC Riverside as America’s fastest rising university. A new campaign, titled Beyond Brilliant, goes beyond the rankings and profiles UCR students and alumni whose inspiring personal stories demonstrate how the university contributes to the well-being of California and the world.

title: Winter quarter to begin with remote instruction
description: In an announcement to the UC Riverside campus, Chancellor Kim A. Wilcox announced that instruction will be delivered remotely for the first two weeks of the winter quarter. He cited the emergence of the Omicron variant and the start of the quarter taking place just after the New Year’s holiday.  The campus will remain open during this period and in-person instruction is expected to begin the week of Jan. 17.

title: California will inevitably shake like Turkey
description: Many in California have questions about the conditions that caused the Turkish earthquake, and wonder whether the western U.S. is likely to suffer a similar fate. UC Riverside seismologist David Oglesby weighs in with answers.

title: Reducing aerosol pollution without cutting carbon dioxide could make the planet hotter
description: Humans must reduce carbon dioxide and aerosol pollution simultaneously to avoid weakening the ocean’s ability to keep the planet cool, new UC Riverside research shows.

title: Breathing is going to get tougher
description: When global temperatures increase by 4 degrees Celsius, harmful plant emissions and dust will also increase by as much as 14 percent, according to new UC Riverside research.

title: The planet that could end life on Earth
description: A terrestrial planet hovering between Mars and Jupiter would be able to push Earth out of the solar system and wipe out life on this planet, according to a UC Riverside experiment.

title: Hunting Venus 2.0: Scientists sharpen their sights
description: With the first paper compiling all known information about planets like Venus beyond our solar system, scientists are the closest they’ve ever been to finding an analog of Earth’s “twin.”

title: Cleaning your car may not protect you from this carcinogen
description: It is unlikely that a cancer-causing chemical inside your car can be dusted or wiped way, according to new UC Riverside research.

title: UCR environmental engineers to referee California’s big rig truck emission regulation
description: They won’t be wearing vivid black and white striped shirts, but they could. University of California, Riverside, environmental engineers will soon serve as referees in California’s drive for big rig trucks to meet the state’s tailpipe emission standards.

title: Color tiers will end; UCR revisits fall plans
description: Gov. Gavin Newsom’s announcement  about a full California reopening on June 15 didn’t scramble UC Riverside’s plans for fall 2021, but it threw in some hot sauce. “It made us more progressive in our planning,” UCR Chancellor Kim A. Wilcox said. “If COVID-19 vaccinations continue to trend as they are, and if there isn’t a COVID-19 outbreak, campus will look more like ‘normal’ than we thought it would even a short time ago.”

title: Buzzkill?
description: They say love is blind, but if you’re a queen honeybee it could mean true loss of sight.  New research finds male honeybees inject toxins during sex that cause temporary blindness. All sexual activity occurs during a brief early period in a honeybee’s life, during which males die and queens can live for many years without ever mating again.

title: Seeing inside superfog
description: High humidity and plant moisture combine with cold air and smoke from burning vegetation to form particularly dense fog, but researchers can’t predict when

title: UCR ranks No. 32 on Money Magazine’s Best Colleges List
description: Annual rankings lend weight to six-year graduation rates among low-income, first-generation, and under-represented students

title: Study examines how age and ethnicity impact HIV testing
description: UC Riverside-led study in Southern California finds stigma, risk perceptions, and cost among major factors contributing to adults’ willingness to get HIV tested

title: Expert available to comment on Mexico’s presidential election
description: UC Riverside’s Armando Navarro will travel to Mexico City in advance of the July 1 election to survey voters and visit polling places

title: Loveridge Fellows get a crash course in state politics
description: UC Riverside expands its presence in California’s capital

title: UC Riverside among Washington Monthly’s Top 30
description: University achieves high marks for social mobility, research, and public service

title: Investigating the potential for life around the galaxy’s smallest stars
description: When the world’s most powerful telescope launches into space this year, scientists will learn whether Earth-sized planets in our ‘solar neighborhood’ have a key prerequisite for life — an atmosphere.

title: UC Riverside surpasses ambitious vaccination goal
description: Almost 95% of the students who have returned to campus this fall are fully vaccinated against COVID-19. UCR earlier this month passed its campus-wide goal of 90% vaccination, representing a journey that gathered significant momentum in the past few weeks.

title: What was behind 'vote switching' in the 2016 election?
description: Study pinpoints concerns about race and immigration — not economic ones — as likely determinants of vote switching

title: Divided GOP and Dems stand, united they worry
description: Democrats and Republicans will share one important aspect of the 2020 presidential election in common, a UCR psychologist asserts, based on her recently published research. They will experience similar levels of anxiety. A recent Associated Press poll found 53% of voters described themselves as anxious about the 2020 election.

title: State OKs $25M to double UCR medical students
description: Budget allocates ongoing funding to the medical school

title: Often-overlooked glial cell is key to learning and memory
description: UC Riverside biomedical scientists offer simple advice: keep the brain active

title: Physicists’ finding could revolutionize information transmission
description: UC Riverside-led team identifies dark trions as the next carrier of quantum information

title: New research finding gives valleytronics a boost
description: UC Riverside-led team overcomes a stumbling block in this relatively new technology

title: Fungi and bacteria are binging on burned soil
description: UC Riverside researchers have identified tiny organisms that not only survive but thrive during the first year after a wildfire. The findings could help bring land back to life after fires that are increasing in both size and severity.

title: Newly identified bacteria may help bees nourish their young
description: UCR researchers have identified three bacteria that may help prevent spoilage of the pollen that wild bees provision for their offspring

title: Flower faithful native bee makes a reliable pollinator
description: Just like us, the humble sweat bee has a daily routine

title: Everything you’ve ever wanted to know about bees
description: World Bee Day is May 20. To mark the occasion, we gathered some of UC Riverside’s top bee experts to answer questions submitted on our Instagram page. The response created, for lack of a better term, quite a buzz! We got so many questions — hundreds — that we could not answer them all on social media. For those interested in lengthier answers to some of the questions, we’ve posted many of them here, organized by topic.  Entomology

title: New study finds California civics education falls short
description: In the wake of a national election that signaled heightened interest in politics as well as deep fissures that threaten our democracy, a new study by researchers at UC Riverside and UCLA raises concerns about the democratic mission of schools and a lack of support for civic learning across California.

title: How private prison companies are influencing immigration policy
description: Groundbreaking study finds increased support for punitive immigration legislation in districts with privately owned or managed ICE detention facilities

title: Vaccine deadline comes and goes, and reporting surges
description: The deadline to verify one’s vaccination status or file for an exemption passed Aug. 16, with a late surge in reporting by students and employees. In only one week, there was a 13-point spike — from 51% to 64% — in students who verified having received a vaccination, according to UC Riverside numbers reported on Aug. 18. The number of employees climbed by 9%, to almost 74%.

title: In sexual conflict, ant queens prevail in evolutionary arms race
description: It’s hidden from sight, but there’s an epic battle of the sexes raging in the leafcutter ant species Atta colombica. Competing males deliver sperm in a fluid that’s toxic to rivals’ sperm, while females quash their efforts in order to ensure their own reproductive success.

title: Political scientist’s book takes honest look at sanctuary cities
description: In his new book, Loren Collingwood traces the history of — and attitudes toward — contemporary U.S. sanctuary policies

title: Why is 90% the magic number?
description: With a month until fall quarter begins, the number of verified vaccinations at UCR reached about 65% for students, and just over 75% for employees. The numbers were updated Aug. 20.  In late July, the University of California system moved the goal line for what constitutes a fully vaccinated campus, from 75% to 90%.

title: Booster mandate explained; students vaccines available
description: Emails to students and employees this week stressed the need to comply with booster mandates. This effectively refreshes the mandate requirements students and employees were asked to comply with this past fall, based on UC requirements. That mandate was met with more than a 95% vaccination rate among UCR’s students and employees.

title: Brain protein linked to seizures, abnormal social behaviors
description: UC Riverside mouse study focused on neurons in the hippocampus

title: Star-shaped brain cells may be linked to stuttering
description: UC Riverside-led study examined the effects of the medication risperidone on brain metabolism in stuttering

title: Student Shoutout: From summer memories to favorite classes
description: Temperatures are rising and UCR students are dreaming of vacations.

title: Scientists decode DNA secrets of world’s toughest bean
description: UCR scientists have decoded the genome of black-eyed peas, offering hope for feeding Earth's expanding population, especially as the climate changes.

title: UCR alumna’s story on rapper Nipsey Hussle results in Emmy nomination
description: The Fox 11 reporter’s profile ran four months before the artist’s murder.

title: Unraveling a mystery surrounding embryonic cells
description: Neural crest study results could boost stem cell therapies

title: Bee mite arrival in Hawaii causes pathogen changes in honeybee predators
description: UC Riverside-led research, done on the Big Island, shows effects of mite introduction have cascaded through entire pathogen communities

title: Researchers find peptide that treats, prevents killer citrus disease
description: New UC Riverside research affirms a unique peptide found in an Australian plant can destroy the No. 1 killer of citrus trees worldwide and help prevent infection.

title: When COVID-19 darkens your door
description: The Villanueva twins graduated from UCR a month after their father, Manuel, died from COVID-19.

title: Outpost Concert Series: Music that elevates the senses
description: Running Nov. 6 through April 2020, the series’ five programs will highlight music composed over the past 40 years.

title: Beyond Brilliant: Katherine Maldonado
description: Last summer, Katherine Maldonado, a first-generation graduate student at the University of California, Riverside, became one of 133 recipients nationally of a 2019 Ford Foundation Fellowship.  Maldonado, a UCLA graduate, is now working toward her doctorate in sociology, and her $72,000 Ford Foundation award will support her studies over three years. A Watts native and mother of three sons herself, she examines the experiences of formerly gang-involved women who are now mothers.

title: It's back to the classroom on Jan. 31
description: UC Riverside resumes in-person instruction on Jan. 31.

title: UC Riverside named No. 15 public university
description: In its 2020 ranking of top national universities, Washington Monthly magazine has named UC Riverside No. 27 among all institutions, and No. 15 among public universities. UCR climbed one spot among publics, from No. 16 in 2019.

title: Psychologist to explore how brain remembers precise information
description: A person’s general intelligence and ability to understand language are reliant on the brain’s ability to maintain precise information acquired over a short period of time.

title: Experts on heat waves
description: Heat Waves For fast access to experts, TEXT or call the 24-hour-experts hotline at 951-312-3049, or email news@ucr.edu  Robert Allen, assistant professor of climatology. Allen uses climate models in his research and can talk to reporters about how such models can improve our understanding of climate change. “Several observational studies have shown the frequency of occurrence of extreme warm temperatures has increased,” he says. rjallen@ucr.edu

title: An ancient Maya ambassador’s bones show a life of privilege and hardship
description: Ajpach’ Waal forged an alliance between two dynasties but died in obscurity

title: Monuments that matter
description: Paper urges archaeologists and historians to work closely with people who are grappling with racism in public monuments

title: UCR, University Innovation Alliance mark milestone
description: The University Innovation Alliance, or UIA, a national group of public research universities working to improve student success, announced June 7 that it has exceeded graduation targets set during President Obama’s College Opportunity Summit.

title: Modern activities follow the contours of ancient Teotihuacan
description: Lidar mapping study reveals vast landscape modifications that still influence construction and farming

title: Why weren’t New World rabbits domesticated?
description: Archaeologists find the answer in rabbit social behavior

title: $4 million grant will study factors that lead to success for UC minority students in STEM disciplines
description: The National Science Foundation has awarded a five-year, $4 million grant to fund a program for minority students across nine University of California campuses.

title: Carbon monoxide detectors could warn of extraterrestrial life
description: For some distant worlds, carbon monoxide may actually be compatible with a robust microbial biosphere

title: Slime travelers
description: New UC Riverside research settles a longstanding debate about whether the most ancient animal communities were deliberately mobile. It turns out they were, because they were hungry.

title: Pioneering UC Riverside geoecologist elected to the National Academy of Sciences
description: Marilyn Fogel, a University of California, Riverside endowed geoecology professor, received one of the highest honors in science this week with her election to the National Academy of Sciences, or NAS. Membership in the NAS is rare. According to the Congressional Research Service, there are 6.9 million scientists in the U.S. However, there are only 2,347 active NAS members and 487 foreign associates.

title: Study finds electronic cigarettes damage brain stem cells
description: A research team at the University of California, Riverside, has found that electronic cigarettes, often targeted to youth and pregnant women, produce a stress response in neural stem cells, which are critical cells in the brain. Present throughout life, stem cells become specialized cells with more specific functions, such as brain cells, blood cells, or bone. Far more sensitive to stress than the specialized cells they become, stem cells provide a model to study exposure to toxicants, such as cigarette smoke.

title: How genome organization influences cell fate
description: UC Riverside-led study identifies how blood stem cells maintain their fate

title: UC Riverside Research in Brief
description: How does climate change affect California’s mountain lakes? A team of researchers, including UCR’s James O. Sickman, a professor of hydrology, and Kevin Skeen, a research technician, has published a study in Limnology and Oceanography Letters showing that spring snowpack best predicts summer warming in small Sierra Nevada lakes.

title: Research identifies earlier origin of neural crest cells
description: UC Riverside-led research could aid regenerative stem cell therapies

title: Star tours
description: Astronomers have a new tool in their search for extraterrestrial life – a sophisticated bot that helps identify stars hosting planets similar to Jupiter and Saturn.

title: Australia enables UCR to dig into Earth’s wild past
description: Australian officials signed an agreement last night allowing UC Riverside to continue its pioneering research on a government-owned goldmine for unusual fossils. Nilpena Station is a city-sized plot of land in the Australian Outback. It harbors the richest collection on Earth of animal species around 550 million years old. Some of its fossil beds are the size of a tennis court and contain entire communities of organisms.

title: NASA’s TESS mission finds ‘missing link’ planets
description: NASA’s newest planet-hunting satellite has discovered a type of planet missing from our own solar system.  Launched in 2018, the Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite, or TESS, has found three new worlds around a neighboring star. Stephen Kane, a UC Riverside associate professor of planetary astrophysics, says the new star system, called TESS Object of Interest, or TOI-270, is exactly what the satellite was designed to find.

title: Making sense of a ‘7.1’
description: Abhijit Ghosh, UCR associate professor of geophysics, is racing to understand everything he can about the fault that was unknown until it produced a 7.1 magnitude earthquake on July 5. Ghosh's work could help officials prepare for the next big shake.

title: The most spectacular celestial vision you’ll never see
description: Contrary to previous thought, a gigantic planet in wild orbit does not preclude the presence of an Earth-like planet in the same solar system – or life on that planet. What’s more, the view from that Earth-like planet as its giant neighbor moves past would be unlike anything it is possible to view in our own night skies on Earth, according to new research led by Stephen Kane, associate professor of planetary astrophysics at UC Riverside.

title: Earthquakes, chickens, and bugs, oh my!
description: New big data algorithms improve earthquake detection; monitor livestock health and agricultural pests

title: The thrust of the problem
description: A new understanding of a fault that caused a deadly 7.8 magnitude earthquake can help scientists better predict where and when the next big one will hit.

title: Scientists develop new method to detect oxygen on exoplanets
description: UC Riverside scientists have developed a new method for detecting oxygen in exoplanet atmospheres that may accelerate the search for life.

title: Ancient meteorite site on Earth could reveal new clues about Mars’ past
description: UC Riverside scientists have devised new analytical tools to break down the enigmatic history of Mars’ atmosphere — and whether life was once possible there.

title: Newly discovered planet zips around baby star in a week
description: The discovery gives scientists a front seat to the earliest stages of planet formation

title: Newly discovered planet survived the death of its star
description: Astronomers report what may be the first example of an intact planet closely orbiting a white dwarf

title: COVID-19: Some faculty-student teams figured out how to continue their research
description: In the midst of the pandemic, faculty mentored research projects are being supported through CAMP.

title: Surprising number of exoplanets could host life
description: A new UC Riverside study shows other stars could have as many as seven Earth-like planets in the absence of a gas giant like Jupiter.

title: Using Earth’s history to inform the search for life on exoplanets
description: UC Riverside is leading one of the NASA Astrobiology Program’s eight new research teams tackling questions about the evolution and origins of life on Earth and the possibility of life beyond our solar system.

title: To survive asteroid impact, algae learned to hunt
description: Tiny, seemingly harmless ocean plants survived the darkness of the asteroid strike that killed the dinosaurs by learning a ghoulish behavior — eating other living creatures.

title: UCR student housing part of major expansion
description: On a sunny morning at the north end of UC Riverside, bulldozers and dump trucks are busily grading dirt while construction crews put together a frame foundation for the campus’ newest housing and dining complex.

title: Scientists unpack how taste neurons control food intake
description: UC Riverside-led research on fruit fly could lead to better understanding of how taste information is coded in the brain

title: New method expands the world of small RNAs
description: PANDORA sequencing method developed by UC Riverside-led team can detect once-undetectable small RNAs

title: Full-campus effort invigorates transfer student recruitment
description: Early 2017 was a nervous time on the UC Riverside campus.

title: GSOE dean is interim provost and executive vice chancellor
description: UC Riverside Chancellor Kim A. Wilcox announced today the appointment of Thomas M. Smith as interim provost and executive vice chancellor, pending approval by UC President Janet Napolitano.

title: Some domesticated plants ignore beneficial soil microbes
description: Domestication yielded bigger crops often at the expense of plant microbiomes

title: Study finds natural selection favors cheaters
description: UC Riverside research focused on interaction between nitrogen-fixing bacteria and their hosts

title: Space travel can make the gut leaky
description: UC Riverside-led study tested the effects of microgravity on intestinal epithelial cells

title: Campus housing has changed - a lot - while you were away
description: As students show up for move-in day at UC Riverside, they are arriving to a campus that –from a housing perspective – is reinvented from the pre-pandemic campus of two Septembers ago. Two residential communities – Dundee Residence Hall and the North District Apartments – are open for students, significantly alleviating the space crunch UC Riverside has faced since its student population began rocketing in the 2000s. UCR has more than doubled its population of 20 years ago, and is projected to have 35,000 students by 2035.

title: Genetic changes help mosquitoes survive pesticide attacks
description: UCR study shows how intensive pesticide use is driving mosquito evolution at the genetic level

title: Biologists decipher a key piece of the odor-detection puzzle in flies, mosquitoes
description: UC Riverside basic discovery offers path to safer products to protect against disease-carrying mosquitoes, chemicals to control crop-damaging pests

title: Researchers to Target Mosquito Egg Production to Curtail Disease
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif.

title: UCR recognizes longtime generosity of Campbell family with building renaming
description: The University Laboratory Building is being renamed the “Rochelle and Allison Campbell Hall”

title: Economic Forecast Conference delivers good news
description: A decade after the recession of 2008, the region is home to the fastest job growth in Southern California and is the most improved among the major surrounding metro areas

title: Rise of oxygen on Earth: Initial estimates off by 100 million years
description: New research shows the permanent rise of oxygen in our atmosphere, which set the stage for life as we know it, happened 100 million years later than previously thought. A team including UC Riverside found that oxygen fluctuated dramatically after its early appearance before becoming a permanent constituent of the atmosphere.

title: Glass nanopore pulls DNA like spaghetti through a needle
description: The purely electrical technique captures cell-free DNA from the surface of a sample

title: Q&A with Eddie Comeaux
description: UC Riverside Graduate School of Education professor Eddie Comeaux served as co-chair of a University of California-wide task force deciding the fate of SATs in the UC system.

title: Study identifies new temperature sensing mechanism in plants
description: Phytochrome foci have different behaviors at different temperatures and types of light

title: Scientists identify how plants sense temperature
description: When it gets hot outside, humans and animals have the luxury of seeking shelter in the shade or cool, air-conditioned buildings. But plants are stuck. While not immune to changing climate, plants respond to the rising mercury in different ways. Temperature affects the distribution of plants around the planet. It also affects the flowering time, crop yield, and even resistance to disease.

title: Drug found to correct gene defect that causes immune-driven gut leakiness
description: UC Riverside-led study is the first to show how tofacitinib rescues gut barrier function from overactive immune cells

title: Drug decreases gut leakiness associated with ulcerative colitis
description: UC Riverside-led study is the first to show how tofacitinib affects epithelial cells lining the gut

title: UCR campus establishes remote learning hubs for fall quarter
description: Several spaces have been outfitted to serve students with hybrid class schedules.

title: UCR researcher addresses incentive disparities in HIV research
description: To encourage subjects to participate in clinical and behavioral HIV studies, researchers often offer incentives such as cash or gift cards. But such remuneration could distort the sampling and end up inadvertently hurting the research findings. Lured by the incentives, participants could easily conceal information about themselves to qualify. Or they could give false information about themselves in order to stay in the study.

title: How can you beat the COVID-19 blues? Find your flow
description: Finding the right activity could mean you experience the same well-being during the long quarantine as you would when not in quarantine, UCR research finds.

title: After four years of hard work, Match Day arrives for UC Riverside medical students
description: 38 students in Class of 2019 were matched for a residency program of their choice

title: Federal grant will help develop new stroke treatment
description: The device aims to reduce brain swelling and deliver a neuroprotective drug

title: National Magazine Honors Program focused on diversifying STEM fields
description: UC Riverside Bridges to the Baccalaureate Program receives 2018 Inspiring Programs in STEM Award from INSIGHT Into Diversity magazine

title: Experts address anxiety about returning to work during pandemic
description: UC Riverside is set to reopen in fall 2021

title: Experts on brain-eating amoeba
description: For fast access to experts, email news@ucr.edu  Haizhou Liu, associate professor of chemical and environmental engineering. Professor Liu works to discover new and improved methods of removing impurities from drinking water and ensuring the safety of our water supply. Liu can speak to the difference between chloramine and chlorine, and water treatment chemistry in general. haizhou@engr.ucr.edu

title: Scientists short-circuit maturity in insects, opening new paths to disease prevention
description: New research from UC Riverside shows, contrary to previous scientific belief, a hormone required for sexual maturity in insects cannot travel across the blood-brain barrier unless aided by a transporter protein. The finding may soon allow scientists to prevent disease-spreading mosquitoes from maturing, or to boost reproduction in beneficial bumblebees.

title: Parasite infestations revealed by tiny chicken backpacks
description: Blood-feeding livestock mites can be detected with wearable sensor technology nicknamed “Fitbits for chickens.”

title: Scientists developing new solutions for honeybee colony collapse
description: The University of California, Riverside, is leading a new effort to stop and reverse a worldwide decline in honeybees, which threatens food security and prices.

title: Cicada explosion mystifies insect experts
description: Doug Yanega, senior scientist at UC Riverside’s Entomology Research Museum, discusses one of nature's unsolved mysteries: the 17-year life cycle of cicadas in the Eastern U.S.

title: School of Medicine celebrates Match Day online
description: Nearly 70 graduates were accepted into residency programs of their choice in 2020

title: Study shows common insecticide is harmful in any amount
description: A new UC Riverside study shows that a type of insecticide made for commercial plant nurseries is harmful to a typical bee even when applied well below the label rate.

title: Biochemist spins out joint venture company with Atomwise
description: Over the past few years, biochemist John Jefferson Perry at the University of California, Riverside, has collaborated on a number of projects with Atomwise Inc., a company that uses artificial intelligence, or AI, for drug discovery. Now Perry and the company have formed a joint venture called Theia Biosciences.

title: Hummingbirds can smell their way out of danger
description: In less time than it takes to read this sentence, hummingbirds can catch a whiff of potential trouble. That’s the result of new UC Riverside research showing, contrary to popular belief, the tiny birds do have an active sense of smell.

title: Improving treatment of spinal cord injuries
description: Osmotic therapy device reduces swelling to prevent secondary injuries in rats

title: Rising temperatures overcook bumblebees’ brunch
description: Bumblebees pollinate many of our favorite foods, but their own diet is being upset by climate change, according to a new UC Riverside study.

title: Genetic discovery could spell mosquitoes’ death knell
description: A UC Riverside genetic discovery could turn disease-carrying mosquitoes into insect Peter Pans, preventing them from ever maturing or multiplying.

title: Scientists fail to locate once-common CA bumble bees
description: Several species of California bumble bees have gone missing in the first statewide census of the fuzzy pollinators in 40 years. If they can be found, a recent court ruling could help save them.

title: Hook injury from catch-and-release can reduce fish feeding
description: Study shows mouth injuries caused by hook removal reduce feeding performance in suction-feeding fish

title: The scent that could save California’s avocados
description: UC Riverside scientists are on the hunt for a chemical that disrupts “evil” weevils’ mating and could prevent them from destroying California’s supply of avocados.

title: Cousin of crop-killing bacteria mutating rapidly
description: A bacterial species closely related to deadly citrus greening disease is rapidly evolving its ability to infect insect hosts, and possibly plants as well.

title: 195 ways to help California’s painted ladies
description: By documenting hundreds of new nectar plants for painted ladies, scientists have renewed hope these charismatic butterflies may prove resilient to climate change.

title: Chemical cocktail in skin summons disease-spreading mosquitoes
description: A UC Riverside-led team discovered the exact chemical combination that causes Zika, dengue and yellow fever-spreading mosquitoes to locate and land on their victims.

title: ‘Marvel’s 616’ Disney+ TV show features UCR graphic novelist John Jennings
description: Jennings discusses the importance of representation in comics in the new documentary series debuting Nov. 20

title: Shang-Chi, an Asian superhero on the big screen
description: Marvel’s first Asian film protagonist marks many milestones.

title: UCR, Riverside schools push back against pollution
description: A grant recently awarded to the Riverside Unified School District and UC Riverside will provide a high school curriculum that addresses air quality, in a region that is among the worst polluters in the country.  The grant is for $1.19 million and is from the National Science Foundation, or NSF.

title: Inland Empire construction jobs and building activity increase
description: The latest Inland Empire Business Activity Index shows business activity in the region continuing its upward climb with the local construction industry making key contributions

title: Nationwide project seeks to understand how brain exercises produce cognitive benefits
description: How does memory training lead to cognitive benefits? Aaron Seitz, director of the Brain Game Center for mental fitness and well-being at the University of California, Riverside, has wrestled with this question for several years.

title: Inland Empire wage growth continues in tight labor market
description: The regions's home affordability helps local labor force expand

title: Inland Empire business activity jumps following first quarter slowdown
description: New analysis reveals region’s most and least competitive industries

title: Conspicuous slowdown in business activity hits Inland Empire
description: Region’s job growth underperforms state for first time since 2012

title: Inland Empire business activity takes a nosedive
description: Pandemic highlights strain on households with children

title: Not so quiet, please
description: UC Riverside mouse study finds early exposure to sounds can address hypersensitivity to noise associated with Fragile X Syndrome

title: Center for Ideas and Society has new co-directors
description: Meet professors Dylan Rodríguez and Jeanette Kohl.

title: UC Riverside men's, women's basketball teams open seasons
description: The Highlanders men’s and women’s basketball programs enter the 2021-22 season under the banner of “great expectations.” This will mark both teams’ 20th year in the Big West Conference. The men’s team finished last season 13-7, and 8-4 in Big West play. The team registered its highest Big West Tournament seed in program history at three before securing the program's first tournament win in 10 years with a 62-52 victory over Hawaii in the quarterfinal round.

title: A new look at ‘The Chicano Experience’
description: Professor Alfredo Mirandé’s 1985 foundational sociology book has a completely revised second edition.

title: Power play: Manipulation and absurdity in photography
description: California Museum of Photography exhibition explores how artist Robert Cumming exposed the truth and trickery of photography

title: Dual exhibitions from photographer John Divola examine social identity and the sublime
description: “STRATUM” and “Clive Wearing’s Dilemma” are on view at the California Museum of Photography May 11-Sept. 8

title: Out of the ashes and into the fire
description: ‘Facing Fire’ explores the beauty, threat, and devastation of California’s growing wildfires

title: In the eye of the beholder
description: A new exhibition at the California Museum of Photography explores the iconic work of documentary photographer Bruce Davidson and the evolution of meaning in photographs

title: ‘Art in the Plague Year’ exhibition seeks art imagining a world beyond 2020
description: The open call marks the first time the California Museum of Photography has solicited art from the public at this scale

title: Still life in shades of gray
description: How Toni Morrison helped an economics professor turn grief into art

title: UCR ARTS celebrates new name, purpose
description: The newly renamed arts institution will bring enhanced programming and scholarship to downtown Riverside

title: UCR Arts Exhibition blurs boundaries of art and architecture
description: “Red Carpet in C” will open at the Barbara and Art Culver Center of the Arts on Aug. 18

title: UCR Arts exhibition examines architecture and painting
description: “Painting Architecture” will open at the Barbara and Art Culver Center of the Arts on Sept. 1

title: How associative fear memory is formed in the brain
description: UC Riverside mouse study provides insights into how pathological fear memory in PTSD could be suppressed

title: New drug target found for COVID-19
description: Scientists discover critical protein complex that lets virus hide from immune system

title: Downtowns are still the biggest job centers in most regions
description: Renewed spending on leisure, entertainment bodes well for downtown businesses

title: Inland Empire has more jobs now than it lost during pandemic
description: Local wages are not rising enough to keep up with inflation

title: Arts patron and UCR supporter Henry Coil dies at 85
description: Henry W. Coil Jr., a Riverside native and community booster whose construction firm and personal giving preserved historic buildings, built multiple schools and strengthened programs for young people and the arts, died October 3, 2018 at the age of 85.

title: Deconstructing the indestructible ‘Luke Cage’
description: “How do you show that he’s bulletproof?” asks artist and University of California, Riverside professor John Jennings, while discussing Marvel superhero Luke Cage. “You have to shoot him. You have to have a black man during the Black Lives Matter movement shot every episode to prove that he’s bulletproof. And that’s problematic.”

title: Hip-hop diaspora: Life, culture and academia
description: When

title: Finding grace through waste in ‘Intolerable Beauty’
description: The new exhibition from artist and environmental activist Chris Jordan runs July 6-Jan. 5 at the Culver Center of the Arts

title: The enduring power of art as activism in “Emory Douglas: Bold Visual Language”
description: Although the Black Panther Party dissolved nearly 40 years ago, the movement’s legacy endures — largely through the iconic imagery created by former party member Emory Douglas.

title: Skateboarder’s view: Photo exhibit captures an inside look at California’s skate parks
description: A photo exhibit and book launch are set for Sept. 19 in Orange County, with the show traveling to UCR’s Culver Center of the Arts in January 2020.

title: Global warming, El Niño could cause wetter winters, drier conditions in other months
description: Research indicates warming ocean temperatures will intensify winter rainfall in California

title: ‘Empty Vessel’ offers a rare insider’s view of California skate parks
description: Photographer Amir Zaki highlights the unique architectural spaces and their place in California culture

title: Connecting the world through images and sound
description: UCR professor’s research weaves together a visual and auditory presentation of Riverside, Brazil, India, Russia, and Germany.

title: Gender insecurity prompts women MMA fighters to date hypermasculine men
description: Challenging gender norms in sport can lead to overdoing them in intimate relationships

title: UCR ARTS goes virtual
description: Experience 360-degree exhibition tours, artist interviews, hands-on activities, and more from the comfort of home

title: UCR ARTS reopens May 13 — now with free admission
description: Explore six exhibitions at the California Museum of Photography and Culver Center of the Arts with new measures ensuring guest safety

title: ‘Adventurous Music for Curious Ears’
description: The 2021-22 Outpost Concert Series kicks off the five-concert season on Nov. 3.

title: UCR Arts receives American Alliance of Museums accreditation
description: AAM is the fields’ gold standard for museum excellence.

title: Scientists crack structure of enzyme complex linked to cancer
description: UC Riverside-led study offers important information for understanding “de novo DNA methylation"

title: New funding to significantly boost cancer, ALS research
description: UC Riverside’s Maurizio Pellecchia receives grants totaling nearly $2.5 million from National Academy of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine; and National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke

title: Researchers use a molecular trojan horse to deliver chemotherapeutic drug to cancer cells
description: A UCR research team has discovered a way for chemotherapy drug paclitaxel to target migrating cancer cells

title: UC Riverside researchers find potent chemical agents that can thwart cancer metastasis
description: Novel agents 135H11 and 135H12 move research closer to drug development

title: Scientists crack structure of a novel enzyme linked to cell growth and cancer
description: UC Riverside-led study could lead to the development of drugs that target liver and other cancers

title: Doubling down on cancer-causing genes
description: NIH grant of $2.2 million could help researchers target two oncogenes, potentially leading to therapies for melanoma, lung cancer, and other tumors

title: A new approach to targeting cancer cells
description: UC Riverside researchers develop new drugs that target therapeutically relevant protein surfaces

title: Experts on earthquakes
description: Earthquakes For fast access to experts, TEXT or call the 24-hour-experts hotline at 951-312-3049, or email news@ucr.edu Nicolas Barth, assistant professor of geology

title: Cancer researcher named UCR medical school’s newest endowed chair
description: Adam Godzik has been named the Bruce D. and Nancy B. Varner Presidential Endowed Chair in Cancer Research

title: UCR mechanical engineering professor receives award to quantify roadside pollutants
description: Near-road air quality continues to be an important issue for transportation agencies. Invisible plumes of dirty air from cars and trucks on roadways spread to surrounding neighborhoods increasing residents’ risk of cancer, asthma, heart disease, and other illnesses.

title: Looming insect invasion threatens California wine and avocados
description: UC Riverside is testing whether a sesame seed-sized wasp can control a pest that could seriously damage California crops including wine, walnuts, and avocados.

title: Girly and a fighter. But are MMA women breaking barriers?
description: Study finds male-dominated MMA is not friendly to gender equality.

title: Measuring greenhouse gases on the go
description: New mobile emissions van allows UCR researchers to track atmospheric emissions anytime, anywhere

title: First person: Sandra Ayllón on life as a DACA student
description: The Supreme Court ruled against the Trump administration’s attempt to end DACA in a 5-to-4 decision on Thursday, June 18.

title: Native American students experience college life during a one-week summer program
description: For 17 years Native American Student Programs has been hosting Gathering of the Tribes, the longest running Native American youth summer program in the UC system.

title: A look at graduation celebrations — at home
description: Photos show how two students commemorated their undergraduate journeys.

title: UCR earns Seal of Excelencia certification
description: Excelencia in Education, the nation’s premier authority on efforts accelerating Latino student success in higher education, announced today UC Riverside has been certified with the Seal of Excelencia in 2021. The national announcement was made this morning by Excelencia in Education during a press conference at the Mayflower Hotel in Washington, D.C. James Kvaal, the U.S. Department of Education under secretary, delivered remarks. UCR is one of just 10 institutions nationwide to earn Seal of Excelencia certification this year.

title: How UCR became a national leader in enrolling Chicanx/Latinx students
description: The population’s growth over the last half century has been driven by students

title: 50 years of Black and Chicano/Latino histories at UCR
description: African Student Programs, Chicano Student Programs celebrate a milestone on campus. At the center of it is student success.

title: Couldn’t socially distance? Blame your working memory
description: UC Riverside-led study highlights critical role working memory capacity plays in social distancing compliance during early stages of the COVID-19 pandemic

title: Research advances understanding of how the brain focuses while ignoring distractions
description: UC Riverside mouse study has implications for treating neuropsychiatric diseases such as ADHD and schizophrenia

title: Genetic background may affect adaptions to aging
description: UC Riverside-led study evaluated individual differences in DNA methylation across 10 years in two Scandinavian samples of same‐sex aging twins

title: Study of perception and memory in older adults will improve understanding of dementias
description: UC Riverside scientists will use a $2 million NIH grant to study the brain’s locus coeruleus

title: How the coronavirus could be prevented from invading a host cell
description: UC Riverside-led study shows inhibiting two host cell proteases can accomplish the task

title: Who benefits from brain training and why?
description: Joint UC Riverside and UC Irvine study shows “near transfer” predicts “far transfer”

title: Leader effectiveness may depend on emotional expression
description: When they don’t express negative emotions, women are seen as more effective leaders than men

title: Do you act before you think or think before you act?
description: UC Riverside psychologists’ experiments explain which choice rules daily life

title: Celebrity sightings have a built-in contradiction
description: UC Riverside research helps explain a tradeoff in human behavior

title: It's a three-peat: UCR again tops social mobility ranking
description: For the third consecutive year, U.S. News & World Report has named UC Riverside the top university in the nation for social mobility. The social mobility category considers the degree to which a university elevates its low-income graduates to a higher standard of living. As rankings leaders such as U.S. News have adjusted their formulas in the past few years, they increasingly consider social mobility among the leading measures of higher education success.

title: UC Riverside climbs in Washington Monthly rankings
description: In its 2019 ranking of top national universities, Washington Monthly magazine has named UC Riverside No. 27 among all institutions, and No. 16 among public universities. UCR was No. 28 in 2018. Washington Monthly also ranked UCR second best in the nation in how well its low-income students perform. UCR’s first-generation student performance is No. 14 on the list.

title: Another opportunity for DACA students
description: On Dec. 4, a federal judge restored the rights afforded undocumented immigrants eligible for the Obama-era Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, or DACA program.  The program was established within the Department of Homeland Security in 2012 to grant work permits and protection from deportation to young people brought to the United States without documentation when they were children.

title: Student Freedom Initiative adds UCR to its next cohort of member institutions
description: Today, Student Freedom Initiative announced the next round of Minority Serving Institutions, or MSIs, that will participate in its program.  UC Riverside, ranked No. 1 in the U.S. for social mobility by U.S. News and World Report, was one of the universities selected.

title: UC Riverside part of new Hispanic universities alliance
description: UC Riverside is among 20 of the nation’s top research universities that have formed the Alliance of Hispanic Serving Research Universities. The announcement was made June 9 in Washington, D.C. The 20 universities represent every university that has been both categorized as R1 (very high research activity) by the Carnegie Classification of Institutions of Higher Education and designated as a Hispanic Serving Institution by the U.S. Department of Education.

title: UC psychologists devise free test for measuring intelligence
description: Raven’s Advanced Progressive Matrices, or APM, is a widely used standardized test to measure reasoning ability, often administered to undergraduate students. One drawback, however, is that the test, which has been in use for about 80 years, takes 40 to 60 minutes to complete. Another is that the test kit and answer sheets can cost hundreds of dollars, this amount increasing with more people taking the test.

title: When restricting capital movement, don’t go it alone
description: When it comes to avoiding reputational costs of economic policy controls, there is safety in numbers. That’s the finding of a recent study of capital controls, or government restrictions on the cross-border movement of money and capital. The researchers assert it’s one of the most systematic studies yet of the reputational risks associated with capital controls among emerging markets.

title: In the space of a day, restrictions go away
description: The promised return-to-normal set by Gov. Gavin Newsom came with the promised easing of restrictions, and then some. In April, Newsom announced that the familiar color tiers of the pandemic and their mandates would go away on June 15. The heads up gave UCR and the rest of the state a nod that progressive planning for fall is a safe bet.

title: Inland Empire business activity to hit pre-pandemic levels by end of year
description: Weak spot: labor market lags other parts of the economy

title: Plant stress transformed into rapid tests for dangerous chemicals
description: UC Riverside scientists have modified proteins involved in plants’ natural response to stress, making them the basis of innovative tests for banned pesticides and deadly, synthetic cannabinoids.

title: Partners help us stay connected during pandemic
description: A pair of UCR studies reveal that living with a romantic partner helps people feel more socially connected during COVID-19. But no other pandemic-era social dynamic carries notable benefits, the researchers found: not your kids, not kibitzing with your bestie on FaceTime, and not your adorable-adoring pets.

title: From the streets to the stratosphere: clean driving technology enables cleaner rocket fuel
description: A chemical used in electric vehicle batteries could also give us carbon-free fuel for space flight, according to new UC Riverside research.

title: Creating dance opportunities and careers for Inland Empire youth
description: Inaugural “Celebrating our Constellation: UCR + RCC + AB Miller” event brought together UCR, Riverside City College, and AB Miller High School students.

title: Research links anti-immigrant prejudice to mortality risk
description: When it comes to mortality, U.S.-born individuals of immigrant descent fare much worse than their foreign-born counterparts — but why?

title: Picking the perfect pomegranate
description: Consumer sensory panel shows several promising alternatives to the industry-standard ‘Wonderful’ pomegranate

title: Highlander Day — virtual style
description: Undergraduate Admissions has shifted to an online, weeklong program for prospective, admitted, and transfer students.

title: Scalable quantum computing research supported by $2 million grant
description: Project aims to make quantum computers easier to produce and operable at room temperature

title: Research suggests the happiest introverts may be extraverts
description: If you are an introvert, force yourself to be an extravert. You’ll be happier.  That’s the suggestion of the first-ever study asking people to act like extraverts for a prolonged period. For one week, the 123 participants were asked to – in some cases – push the boundaries of their willingness to engage, by acting as extraverts. For another week, the same group was asked to act like introverts.

title: ‘Little Free Pantry’ now available to student parents at Oban Family Housing
description: Students with families living at UC Riverside's Oban Family Housing now have access to a small pantry at any time of the day.  Small hand sanitizers, canned veggies, coffee, and other nonperishable food items sit inside the Little Free Pantry, a roughly 2-foot-by-1.5-foot wooden miniature shed-shaped case inspired by the Little Free Library stands that hold free books for the community. At Oban Family Housing the Little Free Pantry hangs on a wall inside the laundry room, which grants residents access 24/7.

title: Newsom appoints UCR Highlander to Student Aid Commission
description: Angel Rodriguez, an alumnus and current grad student, urges students to apply for Cal Grants

title: The Milky Way kidnapped several tiny galaxies from its neighbor
description: UC Riverside-led research shows our galaxy is undergoing a massive merger with its largest satellite galaxy, the Large Magellanic Cloud

title: Astronomers discover triplet of black holes on collision course
description: Unique expertise of UC Riverside scientists helped make the discovery

title: Black holes stunt growth of dwarf galaxies
description: UC Riverside astronomers find large-scale winds associated with active black holes in small galaxies suppress star formation

title: Chemical ‘nose’ sniffs critical differences in DNA structures
description: Small changes in the structure of DNA have been implicated in breast cancer and other diseases, but they’ve been extremely difficult to detect — until now. Using what they describe as a “chemical nose,” UC Riverside chemists are able to “smell” when bits of DNA are folded in unusual ways.

title: Observed COVID-19 variability may have underlying molecular sources
description: UC Riverside-led study shows how variations in SARS-CoV-2 host gene expression can be linked to variations in COVID-19 susceptibility and symptom severity

title: New School of Medicine Education Building receives full approval from UC Regents
description: The Regents of the University of California have given final approval for the construction of the School of Medicine’s new Education Building II at UC Riverside. The vote, which approved the final design, the full budget, and the California Environmental Quality Act, or CEQA, findings, took place during the Regents’ meeting on Wednesday, March 17, 2021.

title: Experts on wildfires
description: For fast access to experts, TEXT or call the 24-hour-experts hotline at 951-312-3049, or email news@ucr.edu

title: Beyond Brilliant: Regina Louise
description: Regina Louise has never known a “normal” childhood. Throughout her tumultuous youth, she was shuffled through over 30 foster homes and psychiatric facilities, all before the age of 18.  Subjected to neglect, abuse, overmedication, and solitary confinement while in foster care, Louise’s trauma was compounded by a racially motivated ruling, which prevented her counselor, Jeanne Kerr, from adopting her in 1974 on the basis that Kerr was white and Louise was black.

title: Beyond Brilliant: Alfonso Maldonado '13
description: Heading north from Riverside, Alfonso Maldonado '13 often makes the more-than-50-mile drive to the Adelanto U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement Processing Center in the Mojave Desert. There he meets with clients; most, newly arrived immigrants to the United States seeking asylum while their cases maneuver the legal system. Maldonado represents roughly 20 clients at any one time. “My very first trip to Adelanto I was terrified,” said Maldonado, 30.

title: Experts on the Salton Sea
description: For fast access to experts, TEXT or call the 24-hour-experts hotline at 951-312-3049, or email news@ucr.edu  Salton Sea Emma Aronson: Associate professor of microbiology and plant pathology. Microbiome of the Salton Sea; microbial ecology of dust; wind- transported microorganisms; environmental microbiology; soil microbial ecology. emma.aronson@ucr.edu

title: Same-gender couples have better interactions
description: Same-gender couples have higher-quality interactions with one another than heterosexual couples in Southern California, a new UC Riverside study finds. The study also holds that couples with two men have the smallest social networks. Researcher Megan Robbins says the recently published study is the first to compare same- and different-sex couples’ social networks and daily interactions with one another.

title: A different type of holiday party for Guardian Scholars
description: The program works to make the holidays special for foster youth, despite the pandemic’s challenges.

title: Research affirms the power of 'we'
description: A healthy relationship starts with the word “we.”  Past research by UC Riverside psychologist Megan Robbins has emphasized the power of first-person personal pronouns such as “we” and “us” in relationships. “We-talk” is an indicator of interdependence, meaning partners affect one another’s thoughts, feelings, and behaviors. This is a shift from self-oriented to relationship-oriented.

title: Romantic partners help us see silver linings, study says
description: We’re often told we are responsible for our own happiness. But in challenging situations, a UC Riverside study not only demonstrates the benefits of positive reframing – finding a “silver lining” – but also suggests our partners can be more adept at finding that silver lining than we are.    A UCR psychology researcher says the findings, based on a study of couples coping with breast cancer, may provide a roadmap for a more contented spouse.

title: How diet influences taste sensitivity and preference
description: What you eat influences your taste for what you might want to eat next. So claims a University of California, Riverside, study performed on fruit flies. The study, published in the Journal of Neuroscience, offers a better understanding of neurophysiological plasticity of the taste system in flies.

title: Switching from tobacco to e-cigarettes does not reverse respiratory epithelium damage
description: UC Riverside study reports e-cigarette prolonged use may contribute to airway epithelium damage and lead to respiratory diseases

title: How UCR Library’s contact-free curbside delivery works
description: Students, faculty, and staff can still access books and materials.

title: Coolants in Puff electronic cigarettes present health hazard
description: UC Riverside-led study highlights need for regulation to protect public health

title: Joan Didion's 'lost' commencement address, revealed
description: California-rooted author and new journalism maven Joan Didion, who died Dec. 23, 2021, delivered a commencement address at UC Riverside in 1975. In subsequent decades, excerpts have frequently been quoted in major media, including in a New York Times review of her book “The Year of Magical Thinking” and again in a Times story on the day of her passing.

title: Thirdhand smoke can trigger skin diseases
description: UC Riverside-led clinical study advances molecular understanding of THS effects on skin

title: Will we be benevolent gods?
description: In his blog-turned-book, Eric Schwitzgebel tackles philosophical questions both big and (seemingly) small

title: A drunk driver killed her parents. Now she’s graduating to honor them
description: Azalea Corral has a family photo that shows her three younger siblings and parents smiling together against a Santa Barbara countryside backdrop. It was taken on February 8, 2020 — the last time they would pose together for a photo.  The following day, both her parents succumbed to bodily injuries after a drunk driver struck them while they were out on their usual evening stroll in Goleta, a community about 12 miles west of Santa Barbara. Corral’s siblings were in the house; she was on a train back to Riverside.

title: How do worms develop their gut?
description: The pandemic helped a husband-and-wife team at UC Riverside solve the mystery

title: How the brain stores remote fear memory
description: UC Riverside mouse study could lead to novel therapies for people living with PTSD

title: Studies identify new strategies for insect control
description: Mosquitoes spread several diseases, such as malaria and dengue. In 2020 about 241 million cases of malaria occurred worldwide, with a few more million cases occurring in 2021.

title: Project Moving Forward: A benchmark for student success
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif. - As a young teacher, Linda Navarrette traveled to South Africa with one assignment: help teachers develop critical thinking skills in their students. Little did she know that her efforts in those impoverished communities would change her life. The experience catapulted her career into education, cementing her support for students who are learning English as a second language.

title: What Makes Kids With Autism Less Social Than Their Typically Developing Peers?
description: Pick a hand, any hand. That familiar refrain, repeated in schoolyards the world over, is the basis of a simple guessing game that was recently adapted to study how and why kids with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) interact with the people around them.

title: How stressed-out plants produce their own aspirin
description: Plants protect themselves from environmental hazards by producing salicylic acid, also known as aspirin. A new understanding of this process may help plants survive climate change.

title: New York Times analysis notes UCR's student success
description: The New York Times and Urban Institute compared similar colleges in determining which schools are exceeding student success expectations - and which schools aren't meeting them.

title: Why are plants green?
description: UC Riverside-led research team’s model to explain photosynthesis lays out the next challenging phase of research on how green plants transform light energy into chemical energy

description: UC Riverside has admitted a record number of freshmen for fall 2021 with a total of 34,671 admits — an increase of 1,964 students from the year before, according to data released by the University of California on July 19.

title: Commuters are inhaling unacceptably high levels of carcinogens
description: New UC Riverside research shows the average commuter in California is breathing unsustainably high levels of benzene and formaldehyde, two Prop. 65-listed, carcinogenic chemicals.

description: UC Riverside biomedical scientist Marcus Kaul explains

title: UCR poet wins 2018 American Book Award
description: There was a time when Rachelle Cruz, M.F.A. ’12, had all but given up on getting her poetry collection published.

title: Experts on the Academy Awards
description: The Oscars For fast access to experts, TEXT or call the 24-hour-experts hotline at 951-312-3049, or email news@ucr.edu  The 94th Oscars will air live on ABC on Sunday, March 27, 2022. The 94th Oscars will allow the entertainment community and fans from around the world to witness the night’s glamour and glory. Experts from the University of California, Riverside are available to discuss various Academy Awards topics, including acting, theatre, screenwriting, gender, culture, and more.

title: Trions exhibit novel characteristics in moiré superlattices
description: When two similar atomic layers with mismatching lattice constants — the constant distance between a layer’s unit cells — and/or orientation are stacked together, the resulting bilayer can exhibit a moiré pattern and form a moiré superlattice.

title: Deadline to provide vaccination proof is Aug. 16
description: Aug. 16 is the deadline for UC Riverside employees and students to upload vaccination records for fall 2021. The announcement was made in a July 16 message from Chancellor Kim A. Wilcox to the campus community.

description: University of California President Janet Napolitano met with a few hundred students at Rancho Verde High School in Moreno Valley on Friday, Nov. 2 to explain how a college education is within their reach.

title: University of California names Michael Drake its president
description: The University of California Board of Regents unanimously named Ohio State University President Michael V. Drake, M.D., as the next president of the 10-campus UC system.  Drake, 69, is the 21st UC president, succeeding the retiring Janet Napolitano. When he assumes the helm in August, he will be the first person of color to lead the UC system. He has almost four decades experience in the UC system, first as a medical student, then as a faculty member, systemwide vice president for health affairs, and a chancellor.

title: Celebrating a decade of support for UCR Guardian Scholars
description: A decade ago, Tuppett Yates, a professor of psychology at the University of California, Riverside, launched the Guardian Scholars Program in the hopes of creating a support system for students who grew up in foster care.

title: Campbell family gives $10 million to UC Riverside
description: The gift from the mother-daughter philanthropists is tied for the largest ever to the university from individual donors

title: UC Riverside and Eurosemillas partner to bring the next generation of avocados to market
