title: Alumna brings music history to life for the next generation
description: The Rock & Roll Hall of Fame has a new director of curatorial affairs: UCR’s Nwaka Onwusa ’08

title: Out of this world: An alumna’s dream comes true
description: Brittany Seto ’16, who studied computer science at UC Riverside, interned at NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory, where a record number of UCR undergraduates are spending the summer

title: New movie aims to foster change in a broken system
description: “I Am Somebody’s Child,” a film based on UCR alumna Regina Louise’s memoir about growing up in foster care, premieres April 20 on Lifetime

title: Calling all Highlanders
description: UC Riverside is encouraging its estimated 120,000 graduates to take part in the campus’ first-ever Alumni Roll Call. Starting Feb. 1, all alumni are being asked to fill out an online form that takes about 10 minutes to complete. The Roll Call is UCR’s version of a census, seeking updated contact information and asking questions about what events, activities, career resources, and volunteer opportunities appeal to alumni.

title: Inland Empire outpacing California in business establishment growth
description: Region has more than offset establishment losses from the ‘Great Recession’

title: Experts on stroke
description: For fast access to experts, TEXT or call the 24-hour-experts hotline at 951-312-3049, or email news@ucr.edu  Stroke   Byron Ford: Professor of biomedical sciences. Developing neuregulin-1 (NRG1) as a treatment in clinical trials for stroke; neuroscience; cellular and molecular mechanisms involved in the pathophysiology of stroke and acute brain injuries. byron.ford@ucr.edu   Lama Al-Khoury: Associate clinical professor. Stroke; stroke prevention; headaches; neurology. lama.al-khoury@ucr.edu

title: Steering into the future of connected and automated vehicles
description: More than 1 billion motor vehicles travel roadways worldwide and that number is expected to double within one or two decades.  The rise in automobiles and trucks have led to increased social, economic, and safety issues, such as the more than 30,000 deaths from car related accidents on US highways every year, according to a US Department of Transportation (DOT)

title: $20M sustainable nanotechnology partnership renewed
description: The National Science Foundation, or NSF, has renewed funding for a UC Riverside laboratory solving big environmental and agricultural challenges with very small chemical particles called nanomaterials.

title: Researcher: Tests should expect more of older adults
description: A UCR psychology researcher says the bar is too low for “functional independence” in older adults, and should be aligned with skills younger adults must conquer.  The Activities of Daily Living, or ADL, questionnaire is a standard used by healthcare professionals to decide what services older adults need to remain independent. These activities include eating and bathing. The Instrumental Activities of Daily Life, or IADL, questionnaire is a stepped-up standard that also considers basic skills such as managing money and preparing meals.

title: $6.3 million will help UC Riverside save America’s avocado orchards
description: New grants totaling $6.3 million will help UC Riverside solve problems facing American avocado orchards, including a lethal fungal disease called Laurel Wilt. The disease can destroy an entire avocado orchard in a couple of weeks once symptoms develop. It is already present in Florida. Without effective treatments, it will inevitably spread to California, the nation’s leading producer of avocados.

title: Mysteries of nickel oxide – a promising spintronic material – are revealed
description: UC Riverside team determines how electron spins interact with crystal lattice in nickel oxide

title: UC Riverside research will help protect military software from hackers
description: Outdated military software and hardware is vulnerable to attack

title: Screening may miss one-quarter of child sexual abuse cases
description: Up to one-quarter of people who suffer child sexual abuse might be passed over for treatment because of current screening procedures, according to UC Riverside psychology researchers. Their just-published study also finds that whether survivors of child sexual abuse identify themselves as abuse survivors influences the outcomes they experience in young adulthood.

title: Good parent bond = good COVID behavior
description: Containing the COVID-19 pandemic depends on the degree to which people exhibit prosocial behavior — behavior that benefits others. We wear masks to protect ourselves, but also our neighbors. We get vaccines to stop the spread of the coronavirus, to edge society closer to herd immunity. A new study from UC Riverside finds that the degree to which adolescents exhibit prosocial behaviors generally, and COVID-19 health protective behaviors in particular, depends on the security they feel in relationships with their primary caregivers.

title: UCR offering webinars with campus tour guides
description: Every spring, hundreds of prospective college students flock to UC Riverside for a tour of the campus to help them decide where to go that fall. With on-campus tours no longer possible, UCR is offering an online alternative. Last month, its team of student tour guides began offering Zoom meetings for high school and transfer students wanting to know more about the campus.

title: Family secret inspires new novel by UC Riverside’s Kate Anger
description: A story about coming-of-age, betrayal, and revenge, ‘The Shinnery’ is inspired by the author’s family history and a trial that shook 1890s Texas.

title: Three factors could explain physician burnout
description: UC Riverside doctors share their thoughts on a growing medical crisis

title: Should companies let employees choose their tasks?
description: The tactic can be useful with very skilled employees and independent projects

title: Men's Basketball tramples Cornhuskers in season opener
description: LINCOLN, NEB.- For the second time in three years, the UC Riverside Men's Basketball Team (1-0) opened its season on the road with a big win over a power five conference team. Tuesday night, the Highlanders roasted the Cornhuskers (0-1) from Nebraska 66-47, marking the program's largest margin of victory on opening night against a DI opponent, and the first time the Huskers have lost their home opener since 1980.

title: Agile organizations should look to knowledge, not tasks
description: Employees with diverse skills, knowledge, and goals will design their work better from the get-go

title: UCR faculty weigh in on 'American Dirt'
description: "American Dirt" is the No. 1 New York Times bestseller, has been called this generation’s "Grapes of Wrath" and received strong reviews from Publishers Weekly and Kirkus. It has received support from prominent Mexican American and Latina authors, including Sandra Cisneros, Erika Sánchez, Reyna Grande, and Julia Alvarez, who predicted the book would “change hearts and transform policies.” Stephen King loves it. So does John Grisham. Oprah Winfrey has anointed it in her Oprah's Book Club.

title: A Ph.D. in punk? Only at UC Riverside
description: Marlen Ríos-Hernández takes a scholarly approach to the mosh pit

title: Earning her chances

But luck alone doesn’t account for the seven courses she took during spring quarter in order to complete her bachelor’s degree — and the 3.36 GPA she earned doing it — while also meeting deadlines for a doctoral program application.

title: For UC Riverside Bioengineering Professor Immune System Research was Personal

Professor Morikis is well known for his work in immunophysics and immunoengineering, where he used physics and engineering approaches to understand molecular mechanisms of immunology, develop disease models, and design new drugs and molecular sensors for autoimmune and inflammatory diseases.

Jennifer Scheper Hughes, a professor in the Department of History at the University of California, Riverside, examines this period from historical and theological perspectives in her new book, “The Church of the Dead: The Epidemic of 1576 and the Birth of Christianity in the Americas.”

Danko Turcic, an associate professor of operations and supply chain management at UC Riverside’s School of Business, said the current environment is causing “previously unseen disruptions in both supply and demand.”

description: Poetry collection captures the author's own life, as well as many of the golden state’s overlooked truths: genocide, environmental degradation, and climate change.

title: What is your moral responsibility in Ukraine?
description: Letters to the editor populate the pages of media outlets, speaking to America's and Americans' moral authority to act, or not to act, in Ukraine. You and I didn't cause this. Then why do we feel we should be doing something more - and what do we do with that anxiety? We turned to John Martin Fischer, a UC Riverside philosophy professor who is a world-leading expert on free will and moral responsibility. Fischer's ruminations on near-death experiences have been consumed by millions in his writings and on YouTube videos.

description: Calit2 was created by the state of California over 20 years ago to ensure the state remains on the leading edge of information technology, communications

title: Parasitic plants conspire to keep hosts alive
description: The plant that encourages kissing at Christmas is in fact a parasite, and new research reveals mistletoe has an unusual feeding strategy. When two mistletoes invade the same tree, they increase photosynthesis to get the nutrients they need, essentially sharing the tree and causing it less harm.

title: $1.7 million grant to unlock barley’s genetic superpowers
description: Barley is important for more than beer. A UC Riverside geneticist has won $1.7 million to study how one of the world’s staple foods might survive climate change.

title: Discovery is key to creating heat-tolerant crops
description: By 2050 global warming could reduce crop yields by one-third. UC Riverside researchers have identified a gene that could put the genie back in the bottle.

title: Grow and eat your own vaccines?
description: The future of vaccines may look more like eating a salad than getting a shot in the arm. UC Riverside scientists are studying whether they can turn edible plants like lettuce into mRNA vaccine factories.

title: UC Riverside receives 15,000 surgical masks from Chinese-American philanthropist group
description: The Chinese Americans Donation Center also donated 1,000 face shields to the School of Medicine

title: Scientists can switch on plants’ response to light
description: Scientists have figured out how plants respond to light and can flip this genetic switch to encourage food growth - even in the dark. The discovery could help increase food supply for an expanding population with shrinking opportunities for farming.

title: The no-tech way to preserve California’s state grass
description: Though it is disappearing, California’s official state grass has the ability to live for 100 years or more. New research demonstrates that sheep and cattle can help it achieve that longevity.

title: Scientists solve 50-year-old mystery behind plant growth
description: A team of researchers led by UC Riverside has demonstrated for the first time one way that a small molecule turns a single cell into something as large as a tree. For half a century, scientists have known that all plants depend on this molecule, auxin, to grow. Until now, they didn't understand exactly how auxin sets growth in motion.

title: New strategies to save the world’s most indispensable grain
description: A UC Riverside-led team has learned what happens to the roots of rice plants when they’re confronted with two types of stressful scenarios: too much water, or too little. These observations form the basis of new protective strategies.

title: Precise solar observations fed millions in ancient Mexico
description: Without clocks or modern tools, ancient Mexicans watched the sun to maintain a farming calendar that precisely tracked seasons and even adjusted for leap years.

title: $1 million award supports first generation students
description: UC Riverside has been selected as one of 10 American Talent Initiative members to participate in the Kessler Scholars Collaborative. As part of the collaborative, UCR will receive a five-year, $1 million grant. First established at the University of Michigan in 2008, Kessler Scholars provides student financial support and academic, professional, and personal support services to first-generation, limited-income students throughout their four-year college experiences.

title: Experts on SATs/standardized tests
description: For fast access to experts, TEXT or call the 24-hour-experts hotline at 951-312-3049, or email news@ucr.edu  SATs/standardized tests   Stephen Brint: Distinguished professor of Sociology. Brint has written articles and books on standardized testing and its role in higher education. He is especially interested in solving education inequalities associated with racial and social class gaps. brint@ucr.edu

title: Without this, plants cannot respond to temperature
description: UC Riverside scientists have significantly advanced the race to control plant responses to temperature on a rapidly warming planet. Key to this breakthrough is miRNA, a molecule nearly 200,000 times smaller than the width of a human hair.

title: Landscaping for drought: we’re doing it wrong
description: Many Southern Californians plant trees prized for drought tolerance, but a new UC Riverside-led study shows that these trees lose this tolerance once they’re watered.

title: How UCR student-athletes, coaches, and athletics staff have responded to a shortened spring season
description: On the morning of March 12, head men’s basketball coach David Patrick was at an Anaheim hotel preparing his team to take on UC Santa Barbara in the first round of the Big West Tournament.  But he didn’t really expect the game, which was scheduled to take place in only a couple hours, to take place.  In the middle of the team’s pregame walk-through, he got a call from UCR Athletics Director Tamica Smith Jones confirming his fears: the tournament, and indeed the rest of the season, had been canceled in an effort to stop the spread of COVID-19.

title: Can ethics classes actually influence students’ moral behavior?
description: Philosophers and ethicists have never had scientific proof that university ethics classes affect student moral behavior — until now. A research team led by a philosopher at the University of California, Riverside, has conducted the first controlled study aiming to discover whether such a correlation exists using direct observational data rather than self-reported information.

title: A new beat on life
description: Before they arrived at UC Riverside, Kevin Krause ’92 and Ray Rodriguez ’92 were junior college rivals on the basketball court. So when they got to campus as Highlander teammates, they were surprised — and not altogether thrilled — to discover they would be roommates.

title: UCR enters Big West tournament as No. 3 seed, first game Thursday
description: The UC Riverside men’s basketball team is hoping to cap off the best season in program history with a first-ever trip to the NCAA tournament. But the Highlanders will have to win the Big West Men’s Basketball Championship to do so, which begins this Tuesday at the at the Michelob ULTRA Arena at Mandalay Bay in Las Vegas.

title: Queen’s genes determine sex of entire ant colonies
description: UC Riverside researchers have discovered the genetic basis for a quirk of the animal kingdom — how ant queens produce broods that are entirely male or female.

title: Jewish Studies expert discusses rise in antisemitic attacks
description: The Associated Press reported this week that preliminary data compiled by the Anti-Defamation League shows an increase in violent attacks, vandalism and harassment of Jews in the U.S., around the world, and online, since fighting broke out between Israel and Gaza’s militant rulers Hamas earlier this month.

title: Should we live in the moment — or not?
description: John Martin Fischer, a leading philosopher of free will and moral responsibility, has written two companion essays exploring the ideas of mindfulness and living in the moment, which are often encapsulated in the phrase: “Be here now.”

title: How to burst your bubble: broadening your social media horizons
description: A computer scientist explains how our online behavior drives us into echo chambers

title: Perceiving support helps people cope with waiting
description: 'Worry and waiting' researcher's latest findings chart perceived support throughout periods of waiting

title: Men's Basketball names associate coach to top job
description: Associate men's basketball head coach Mike Magpayo will lead the Highlanders following the announcement that head coach David Patrick accepted the associate head Men's Basketball coaching position at the University of Arkansas, a move that provides Patrick with a return to the SEC and the opportunity to be closer to family in the South.

title: Microbiome confers resistance to cholera
description: Many parts of the world are in the midst of a deadly pandemic of cholera, an extreme form of watery diarrhea. UC Riverside scientists have discovered specific gut bacteria make some people resistant to it — a finding that could save lives.

title: UC Riverside discovers first effective treatment for citrus-destroying disease
description: UC Riverside scientists have found the first substance capable of controlling Citrus Greening Disease, which has devastated citrus farms in Florida and also threatens California.

title: Carb-eating bacteria under viral threat
description: Strictly speaking, humans cannot digest complex carbohydrates — that’s the job of bacteria in our large intestines. UC Riverside scientists have just discovered a new group of viruses that attack these bacteria.

title: Let them eat rocks
description: UC Riverside is leading an effort that could help ensure food security and improve the worst effects of climate change — by studying rock-eating bacteria and fungi.

title: New tools in the fight against lethal citrus disease
description: Scientists are closer to gaining the upper hand on Huanglongbing, a disease that has wiped out citrus orchards across the globe. New models of the bacterium linked to the disease reveal control methods that were previously unavailable.

title: Proteins enable crop-infecting fungi to ‘smell’ food
description: New UC Riverside research shows the same proteins that enable human senses such as smell also allow certain fungi to sense something they can eat. The study offers new avenues for protecting people from starvation due to pathogenic fungus-induced food shortages. Understanding how fungi sense and digest plants can also help scientists engineer fungal strains that are more efficient at producing biofuels.

title: Root bacteria could help defeat fatal citrus disease
description: A UC Riverside-led team is looking at tiny underground microorganisms for a way to prevent a huge problem — Huanglongbing, a disease with no cure that has decimated citrus orchards worldwide. The National Institute of Food and Agriculture has awarded the team $10 million to investigate the role of soil and root microbes in the disease.

title: Turning food waste back into food
description: UC Riverside scientists have discovered fermented food waste can boost bacteria that increase crop growth, making plants more resistant to pathogens and reducing carbon emissions from farming.

title: Protein discovery could help enable eco-friendly fungicides
description: New UC Riverside research reveals an essential step in scientists’ quest to create targeted, more eco-friendly fungicides that protect food crops.

title: $1.9 million award could keep Zika virus at bay
description: A UC Riverside virologist has won a $1.9 million award to help prevent the re-emergence of Zika virus, which causes microcephaly in newborns and Guillain-Barre syndrome in adults.

title: Black eyed peas could help eliminate need for fertilizer
description: Black eyed peas’ ability to attract beneficial bacteria isn’t diminished by modern farming practices, new UC Riverside research shows. Planting it in rotation with other crops could help growers avoid the need for costly, environmentally damaging fertilizers.

title: Why doesn’t fire kill some bacteria and fungi?
description: UC Riverside scientists will spend the next three years studying the traits that allow soil microbes to respond to fire, as well as the role those microbes play in storing or emitting powerful greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide or nitrous oxide.

title: Human gut bacteria have sex to share vitamin B12
description: Your gut bacteria need vitamin B12 just as much as you do. Though DNA is usually passed from parent to child, new research shows gut bacteria transfer genes through “sex” in order to take their vitamins.

title: Meet the forest microbes that can survive megafires
description: New UC Riverside research shows fungi and bacteria able to survive redwood tanoak forest megafires are microbial “cousins” that often increase in abundance after feeling the flames.

title: Drought increases microbe-laden dust landing in Sierras
description: Dust from all over the world is landing in the Sierra Nevada mountains carrying microbes that are toxic to both plants and humans. Research from UC Riverside shows higher concentrations of the dust are landing at lower elevations, where people are more likely to be hiking.

title: Mexican mangroves have been capturing carbon for 5,000 years
description: Researchers have identified a new reason to protect mangrove forests: they’ve been quietly keeping carbon out of Earth’s atmosphere for the past 5,000 years.

title: After wildfires, do microbes exhale potent greenhouse gas?
description: Laughing gas is no laughing matter — nitrous oxide is a greenhouse gas with 300 times the warming potential of carbon dioxide. Scientists are racing to learn whether microorganisms send more of it into the atmosphere after wildfires.

title: Gift to School of Medicine aims to alleviate inland Southern California’s physician shortage
description: Inland Empire Health Plan’s gift of $2.6M will create up to 23 awards designed to encourage students to practice in the region

title: Electronic nose startup gets whiff of success
description: Chromanose chosen for National Science Foundation Innovation Corps entrepreneurial support

title: $3 million grant aims to prolong life for dialysis patients
description: The five-year survival rate for people on dialysis is under 50 percent. University of California researchers are hoping to improve that prognosis.

title: $1.6 million grant helps high school students get to college
description: The federal grant supports UCR’s work in San Bernardino area schools.

title: Nutrient-recycling microbes may feel the heat
description: Study led by UCR researcher explores how climate change affects nature’s ability to recycle

title: Battling bubbles: How plants protect themselves from killer fungus
description: UCR researchers show how plants fight against infections by delivering protective molecules into fungi using bubble-like exosomes

title: Research identifies mechanism that helps plants fight bacterial infection
description: UC Riverside study could lead to better strategies for protecting crops from attacks by pathogens

title: Culture war battles at schools harm public education, UC report finds
description: Educators have sought to avoid controversy by pulling back on teaching lessons in civics, politics, and the history and experiences of America’s minority communities.

title: Study confirms link between spatial and math skills
description: Improving students’ spatial skills could improve math skills as well

title: UCR among top 1.3% of world institutions
description: UC Riverside ranked in the top 1.3% of universities worldwide in the 2022-23 Center for World University Rankings, released Monday, April 25. The campus ranked No. 249 out of 19,788 institutions. Nationally, UCR landed at No. 81. The rankings are published by the Center for World University Rankings, a consultancy based in the United Arab Emirates. Institutions are evaluated on four key factors: education, employability, faculty, and research.

title: New School of Medicine building begins construction
description: UC Riverside began construction Friday, Oct. 22 of a new School of Medicine building that will allow for growing class sizes and increasing the number of physicians trained in the underserved Inland Southern California. Campus and community leaders celebrated the start of the project at a groundbreaking ceremony at the project site south of the existing School of Medicine Education on the east side of campus.

title: Research suggests Trump’s ‘Muslim ban’ produced rare shift in public opinion
description: Far from its intended effect, the ban generated public opposition to the policy, according to a study co-authored by UCR’s Loren Collingwood

title: Wildfires can cause dangerous debris flows
description: Wildfires don’t stop being dangerous after the flames go out. Even one modest rainfall after a fire can cause a deadly landslide, according to new UC Riverside research.

title: UC officials applaud Supreme Court's DACA decision
description: University of California officials applauded on Thursday the U.S. Supreme Court’s decision to strike down the Trump administration’s attempt to end a program that allowed 650,000 Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, or DACA, recipients to live and work in the country.

title: Fall campaigns underway; fans look to basketball openings
description: Schedules are ongoing for many fall sports, with excitement building for the men's and women's basketball seasons, which begin later this fall and come on the heels of impressive 2021-22 campaigns for both. Following are early season reviews and pre-season previews for UC Riverside's fall sports teams.  All ticket purchases for UCR Athletics home events must be made online. Home games are free for UCR students with an R’Card.

title: 'Love thy neighbor, mask up'
description: Both religious and patriotic messages helped persuade white evangelicals to wear masks to protect against COVID-19. The lessons may carry over to vaccine messaging.

title: Why some people vote against their own beliefs
description: Many low-education voters who embrace social welfare programs vote against their own beliefs, new UC Riverside research holds. The mitigating factor is education: The more education one has, the more likely one is to stick to one’s policy preferences.

title: Grad students battle for best pitch
description: UC Riverside's best and brightest will go head to head during annual Grad Slam finals event, held at the Culver Center

title: Tantrums, ‘Toy Story’ marathons, and Zoom mishaps
description: Last week, UCR’s Healthy Campus group released tips for staying physically and mentally healthy while social distancing and working from home. But for many faculty and staff members with young children, a number of these recommendations might seem difficult — if not impossible — to follow. Being forced indoors with a child, or children, who either won’t sit still or need constant supervision or attention is a difficult enough task to perform on a day off.

title: Border surge's cause is more complicated than COVID-19
description: The United States border has seen an increase in families — primarily men with their children — and most recently a surge in unaccompanied minors traveling north from Central America through Mexico. They are fleeing gang violence, high homicide rates, and lack of economic opportunities. In some cases, such as in Guatemala, even hunger. According to the Pew Research Center, the U.S. Border Patrol apprehended nearly 100,000 migrants in February; this after apprehensions had fallen to about 16,000 in April 2020.

title: Mamma Mia! Sweden gains the most musicians during the pandemic
description: Musician migration rates muted during pandemic, but interesting regional trends emerge

title: Surveys with repetitive questions yield bad data, study finds
description: “In as few as six or eight questions, people are already answering in such a way that you’re worse off if you’re trying to predict real-world behavior”

title: Inland Empire economy nears full recovery from pandemic downturn
description: Available labor supply likely to be among 2022’s biggest restraints on growth

title: Mass customization can make fashion more sustainable if customers are willing to wait for it
description: High fees for disposal and recycling can boost the sustainable effect under some circumstances

title: California’s creative economy bounces back but expands unevenly
description: New analysis tracks performance of state’s creative industries before, during, and after covid, revealing longer term direction

title: Inland Empire business activity still going strong
description: Business activity in the Inland Empire has continued to grow, and in the context of today’s increasingly uncertain economic environment, stands in stark contrast to growth trends in the nation, according to the new Inland Empire Business Activity Index released today by the UCR School of Business Center for Economic Forecasting and Development. The region’s economy officially transitioned from recovery to expansion in the fourth quarter of 2021 and growth is forecast to continue throughout 2022.

title: Regents approve plans for new School of Business building
description: The Regents of the University of California have approved construction plans for a new UC Riverside School of Business building that will provide more instructional and administrative space to meet growing enrollment demand. The vote, which took place July 20, allows the campus to move forward with construction this fall. The new building is expected to be completed by fall 2024.

title: Inland Empire business activity growth contrasts with national decline
description: Business activity in the Inland Empire continued to rise in the latest numbers, standing in stark contrast to the decline in GDP at the national level, according to the new Inland Empire Business Activity Index released today by the UCR School of Business Center for Economic Forecasting and Development. The increase in the region’s business activity in the second quarter of 2022 (the latest data available) does, however, represent a significant decline in growth from recent quarters.

title: Will the U.S. economy fall into recession in 2023? Only if the Fed intensifies current tightening policies
description: The U.S. economy has little chance of falling into a recession this year or next unless the Federal Reserve raises interest rates more than they are currently projecting, according to a new forecast released yesterday at the 13th annual Inland Empire Economic Forecast Conference, hosted by the UC Riverside School of Business.

title: Pandemic left behind, the Inland Empire economy flourished in 2022
description: Despite the recession drumbeat getting louder in many quarters across the nation, the Inland Empire’s economy is not only showing strength, but is outstripping California’s other major metros and the state as a whole along some very key measures, according to an analysis released today by the UC Riverside School of Business Center for Economic Forecasting and Development.

title: Symposium celebrates 50 Years of clean air leadership
description: CARB’s 50th Anniversary Technology Symposium and Showcase highlighted CARB’s history driving innovative technologies that have made monumental improvements to California’s air quality

title: How to improve corporate social and environmental responsibility
description: Targeted violation reports are more likely to encourage vertical integration and reward “good” firms

title: UC systemwide survey reveals disparities among undocumented students
description: Findings include greater instances of depression, financial instability, and lower grade point averages.

title: Stu Krieger remembers John Singleton by the ‘quiet power he possessed’
description: The UC Riverside professor of screenwriting worked with Singleton in the early 1990s.

title: ‘The Anxiety of Laughing’ will be screened at Dances With Films festival in June
description: The film was directed by UCR Professor Robin Uriel Russin and written by UCR alum Andrew Justvig.

title: Chemicals in your living room cause diabetes in mice
description: A new UC Riverside study shows flame retardants found in nearly every American home cause mice to give birth to offspring that become diabetic.

title: Living the Promise campaign hits $300 million goal
description: UC Riverside surpassed its $300 million goal on Sept. 10 for its first comprehensive fundraising campaign, “Living the Promise: The Campaign for UC Riverside.” Although the overall dollar goal has been reached, the campaign isn’t yet over. The effort, which was publicly launched on October 15, 2016, will close on Dec. 31, 2020, and university fundraisers hope to encourage greater participation from UCR alumni and friends, particularly in support of students.

title: The science behind the scenes of ‘Basmati Blues’
description: UCR geneticist Norman Ellstrand lent his scientific expertise to a musical romantic comedy centered around genetically modified rice

title: Brian Haynes to be appointed UCR Vice Chancellor for Student Affairs
description: Administrator is currently head of Student Affairs at Cal State San Bernardino

title: Research shows we’re surprisingly similar to Earth’s first animals
description: Today’s humans share genes with 555-million-year-old oceanic creatures missing heads.

title: UC Riverside Fall 2018 admissions show surge in transfer student numbers
description: In two years, UCR transfer applications have climbed by 23 percent.

title: ‘Uncovering the buried past of early Korean American history’ in Riverside
description: The book ‘Pachappa Camp: The First Koreatown in the United States’ was published this week by Professor Edward T. Chang.

title: LIVE: Ron Athey’s collective memoir is guest-curated by Professor Jennifer Doyle
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif. - After a performance, Jennifer Doyle wants the audience to walk away with intense emotions. And the live performance she is guest-curating at The Broad contemporary art museum in Los Angeles, “Gifts of the Spirit: Prophecy, Automatism and Discernment” is not the exception.

title: AP readiness program expands to San Bernardino County
description: A proven success, the program will broaden its reach to serve even more Inland Empire high schoolers and their teachers beginning in fall 2018

title: UCR poll: 'If it's Trump vs. Newsom, Newsom wins'
description: A poll of UC Riverside social sciences professors holds that Gov. Gavin Newsom should prevail in the current recall effort against him. Two committees, RescueCalifornia.org and RecallGavin2020.com, have launched efforts to gain 1.5 million signatures to put a Newsom recall on the ballot. The deadline for submitting signatures is March 17, with signatures verified by April 29. Proponents predict more than two million signatures, and Newsom supporters concede recall proponents probably have enough.

title: Political scientists make battleground state predictions
description: UC Riverside political science professors were polled on their predictions for eight battleground states, and the results carry some optimism for the Joe Biden camp.

title: 'I know that we're going to get through it'
description: As election day morphs into election days, UC Riverside’s students are like voters red and blue alike: seeking comfort where they can find it. “I think everyone wanted a definite result. We did not get that,” said political scientist Shaun Bowler.

title: What’s behind the Trump administration’s antitrust challenge to the AT&T-Time Warner merger?
description: Attorney-led seminar will examine the Department of Justice's civil lawsuit and its implications in advance of the trial's March 20 kickoff

title: UC Riverside scores another big win in college rankings
description: UC Riverside climbed 37 places in the most recent Forbes magazine rankings, from No. 64 to No. 27.

title: UC Riverside featured in Amazon Prime series
description: UC Riverside's episode on the Amazon Prime streaming series “The College Tour” is now live and viewable on YouTube.

title: This is the dawning of the age of the vaccine passport
description: The vaccine passport is coming.

title: Inland Empire business activity outpacing U.S. GDP growth
description: Local manufacturing industry remains a key growth sector

title: Expert: Student loan forgiveness is a win - but only for some
description: On Wednesday, President Joe Biden announced a student loan debt program that would forgive $10,000 in debt for borrowers who earn less than $125,000 and an additional $10,000 for those who received Pell Grants. Many borrowers are celebrating the liberation from debt that — for some — has prevented them from buying homes and setting aside savings.

title: Economic turmoil expected through second quarter of 2020
description: COVID-19 will deliver a blow but how bad it will be is yet to be seen

title: In search of UC Riverside's missing not-mascot
description: He is a UC Riverside icon, beloved even, and yet discouraged from attending official university events. Before his refresh, at least, he had the appearance of having been through it. Sun-bleached, sort of grubby, like he was on the losing side of a fight at the juice bar.

title: New economic outlook optimistic but warns of ‘wild cards’ that could send things spiraling
description: A second outbreak will have even worse damage

title: This is how our economy can survive the pandemic
description: Economist Gloria González-Rivera offers insight on how to limit damage

title: UC Riverside-led research predicted the pandemic economic recession
description: “The reality of 2020 hits us in the face and I have never been so prescient in my academic research as with this line of work.”

title: Policymakers are short shrifting the creative economy
description: COVID-19 health mandates disproportionally affect arts and culture businesses

title: California does not need to choose between post-pandemic economic growth and reducing carbon emissions
description: Surprisingly, environmental leader California has a smaller ‘green economy’ than the average U.S. state and would need to add many thousands of environmentally friendly jobs to catch up. The good news is it’s on track to do just that, according to a new analysis released today by the UCR School of Business Center for Economic Forecasting and Development.

title: Novel mechanism links genetic defect in IBD patients to gut leakiness
description: UC Riverside-led study in mice and human tissue is the first to show how a disease mutation weakens barrier properties of epithelial cells lining the gut

title: Public lecture to focus on synthetic genome engineering
description: Lei Stanley Qi of Stanford University will give the 2021 Thomas and Salma Haider Biomedical Breakthrough Lecture at UC Riverside

title: A more targeted therapy to treat inflammatory bowel disease
description: UC Riverside mouse study focuses on the receptor TNFR1

title: Building robust collaborations to ‘ATTACK’ future pandemics
description: As the COVID-19 pandemic continues, the development of antiviral drug treatments has become a critical weapon in our arsenal against the virus.  Harnessing the research and scientific brainpower needed to treat and prevent the next pandemic is the University of California - National Labs Antiviral Treatments Targeting All Coronaviruses and Key RNA viruses, or ATTACK, Consortium.

title: Researchers develop molecular traps to target SARS-CoV-2
description: Joint effort by UC Riverside and UCLA scientists aims to stop the COVID-19-spreading virus from attacking immune cells

title: Scientists discover new avian immunological pathway
description: UC Riverside-led team identifies a new host protein interaction that produces a robust immune response to viral infection in birds and may lead to better poultry vaccines

title: Scientists profile FDA-approved drugs to potentially treat hundreds of genetic disorders
description: New method developed by UC Riverside researchers quickly assesses drug potential for rare disorders

title: How sepsis need not be fatal
description: UC Riverside-led team identifies molecular driver and protector of this life-threatening medical emergency

title: A potential antiviral for SARS and SARS-like coronaviruses
description: UC Riverside-led study shows how an effective therapy against SARS-CoV-2 could be developed

title: Marginalized communities of color face high COVID-19 risk
description: UC Riverside study focused on farm-working communities in California’s Eastern Coachella Valley

title: $3.5 million Givaudan gift will protect citrus collection
description: The University of California, Riverside announced today a $3.5 million donation from Givaudan to support UCR’s Citrus Variety Collection. The gift will help protect one of world’s most extensive citrus diversity collections from the impending threat of citrus greening disease, also known as Huanglongbing, or HLB.

title: COVID-19 vaccines for very young children
description: UC Riverside vaccine expert David Lo shares his thoughts in a Q&A

title: UCR biomedical scientist joins international SARS-CoV-2 group assembled by NIAID
description: SAVE focuses on mutations in SARS-CoV-2 and emerging virus variants

title: Riverside clinic to address healthcare needs of the homeless
description: UniHealth Foundation grant to UC Riverside aims to increase the health and well-being of the unhoused population in Riverside County

title: Coronavirus lab and testing in place for fall quarter
description: As the fall quarter begins, UC Riverside has a new diagnostic lab operating on campus that will rapidly process samples from students and employees as part of an ongoing coronavirus testing program. The lab, located at the Multidisciplinary Research Building, or MRB, tested its first sample in August and opened in early September.  The result of months of collaboration between several campus groups, the lab allows UCR to conduct its own independent testing of the campus community at a rate of about 600 samples a day. Results are processed within 24 hours.

title: More than half of American adults with advanced multiple sclerosis report mistreatment by caregivers
description: UC Riverside-led study describes first published survey documenting nature and extent of caregiver mistreatment of this population

title: UC Riverside joins campuses to pilot a smartphone app that aims to limit spread of COVID-19
description: A program to test a smartphone-based COVID-19 exposure notification system will expand to an additional five University of California campus locations, including UC Riverside, as a result of success from an initial deployment earlier this fall at two UC campuses.  The program is a joint effort between the UCs and the state of California to assess the free, voluntary technology for potential use by all Californians.

title: School of Medicine to serve as lead site for clinical trial on stuttering
description: Phase 2 study investigates efficacy of the drug ecopipam developed by Emalex Biosciences Inc.

title: Pandemic led to profound changes in multiple sclerosis clinical practice
description: UC Riverside-led national survey of MS specialists finds nearly 10% had been redeployed to the front lines of COVID-19 patient care

title: Campus sees drop in COVID-19 cases while vaccination rates rise
description: Since mid-April, UC Riverside has had only a handful of positive COVID-19 cases, continuing a rapid decline that began in January. Campus leaders involved in COVID-19 prevention efforts credit the low positivity rate to proactive efforts including the creation of a homegrown diagnostic lab, regular testing of students, and continuous messaging about the importance of social distancing and wearing face coverings. From September through mid-April, the campus conducted nearly 29,000 tests on campus with a positivity rate of 0.41%.

title: High-tech air quality research center dedicated in Riverside
description: The California Air Resources Board dedicated its new state-of-the-art Southern California headquarters Thursday, Nov. 18, on a 19-acre site near the UC Riverside campus. The 402,000-square-foot laboratory and office facility, located on land provided by UCR, is one of the largest and most advanced vehicle emissions testing and research facilities in the world, agency officials said.

title: Non-sworn, unarmed safety responders to join UCR’s Police Department
description: UC Riverside plans to implement new measures this fall that reflect major changes in how it approaches campus safety. They include a tiered-approach in which the UC Riverside Police Department will add a new category of non-sworn, unarmed safety personnel to respond to calls. Another addition will be behavioral health specialists trained to deescalate situations. UCR is on track to be among the first UC campuses to implement such changes.

title: School of Business launches new actuarial science degree program
description: UC Riverside’s School of Business is now offering a degree in actuarial science, providing a direct path for students seeking careers in finance and insurance. Actuarial science is a discipline that involves assessing financial risks using mathematical and statistical methods. Most who study it go on to work in high-paying positions in finance and insurance.

title: A shot in the arm
description: UC Riverside experts answer questions on Americans needing just one COVID-19 booster vaccine each year

title: Discovery of antibody structure could lead to treatment for Crimean Congo Hemorrhagic Fever virus
description: Study provides insights into fighting broad range of pathogen’s viral strains

title: COVID-19 took serious toll on Native Hawaiian/Pacific Islander mental and physical health
description: Two UC Riverside-led studies found concerning psychological and physical health problems among more than 300 NH/PIs in five US states

title: Two School of Medicine faculty elected to National Academy of Medicine
description: Deborah Deas and Mario Sims are recognized for their contributions to advancing public health

title: Salton Sea dust triggers lung inflammation
description: UC Riverside study has health implications for people living around California’s largest lake

title: Addressing the anxiety crisis
description: UC Riverside mental health professionals answer questions specific to adults, children, and students

title: Mired in silence
description: Health of Southern California’s farmworkers needs to be a priority, says UC Riverside study

title: Is ChatGPT a threat to education?
description: UC Riverside experts share thoughts on the AI-powered language model that understands and responds to natural language

title: Study reveals the workings of nature’s own earthquake blocker
description: A new UC Riverside study finds a naturally occurring “earthquake gate” that decides which earthquakes are allowed to grow into magnitude 8 or greater.

title: UC Riverside-led study sheds light on how IBD can develop
description: Inflammatory bowel disease, or IBD, describes Crohn’s disease and ulcerative colitis, two chronic diseases that cause inflammation in the intestines. IBD, which affects about 3 million adults in the United States, is an autoimmune disorder — a condition in which the body’s immune system attacks healthy tissues. Its symptoms include diarrhea, rectal bleeding, fatigue, weight loss, and stomach cramps.

title: How an autism gene contributes to infertility
description: UC Riverside mouse study shows how gene mutation leads to ovaries failing prematurely

title: UCR ecologist on geoengineering: a new solution to the climate crisis
description: As many gather for Earth Day 2021, A UC Riverside ecologist urges caution toward solar geoengineering, an increasingly popular solution to the climate crisis.

title: Health impact of chemicals in plastics is handed down two generations
description: UC Riverside mouse study finds paternal exposure to phthalates increases risk of metabolic diseases in progeny

title: Researcher-community partnership uses collaborative process to yield novel insights
description: Until recently, psychologist Kalina Michalska had never used community-based participatory research, or CBPR, in her work, but now she can’t imagine not using it. CBPR, which dates to the early 1930s, is an intensive research approach that involves partnerships between researchers and community members throughout the research process, giving communities a voice in how the research proceeds and allowing them to make use of the findings more effectually.

title: How concerned should we be about the Delta variant?
description: UC Riverside experts share their thoughts

title: Sending kids back to school: is it too soon?
description: After more than a year of lockdown, school is back in session. But many people are wondering whether it should be. Here, UC Riverside experts in viruses, medical policy and education share their thoughts about whether in-person learning at this moment in time is an A+ idea, and offer ideas about how to move forward.

title: UCR experts weigh drought's long-term impacts
description: Gov. Gavin Newsom declared a drought emergency for the entire state of California this past month. The period from Oct. 1, 2020 to Sept. 30, 2021 was the second-driest year on record in California. Almost 90% of the state is in throes of extreme drought. Reservoir storage is 60% of average. Said one state water official: "It's almost beyond comprehension." We asked UCR experts what the future holds if drought conditions persist. Hoori Ajami, groundwater hydrologist

title: Should Congress treat insurrectionists as the Romans did?
description: The political divide that led to the Jan. 6, 2021 insurrection on the Capitol building has been perpetuated in discourse over how to properly address the role  of legislators who may have been involved. On the Jan. 6 anniversary of the insurrection, Michele Salzman, a UC Riverside history professor, published an opinion article in Zocalo urging lawmakers to look to the Roman response to another famous attack on another capital — the fifth century sack of the city of Rome by the Visigoths.

title: UCR scientists discover tarantula-killing worm
description: UC Riverside scientists have named a newly discovered species of worm that kills tarantulas after American actor, musician and producer Jeff Daniels, a distinction no other entertainer can claim.

title: It's more than hot. It's dangerous.
description: It's the time of year when Inland Southern California becomes a 27,000-square-mile skillet. We asked UC Riverside physicians how to stay safe and hydrated.

title: Billionaires in the great beyond
description: UCR scientists weigh in on the first successful civilian trip to space, and the ethics of being a billion-dollar rocket man.

title: Statement on dismissal of tenured faculty member
description: Today the Regents of the University of California voted to dismiss a tenured professor, who had been on unpaid suspension, for violating the Faculty Code of Conduct due to sexual misconduct with a student over whom they had academic responsibility. This decision was consistent with the recommendation of the UC Riverside Academic Senate Privilege and Tenure Committee, UC Riverside Chancellor Kim A. Wilcox, and President Michael Drake.

title: Discovery increases likelihood of growing food despite drought
description: University of California scientists have discovered genetic data that will help food crops like tomatoes and rice survive longer, more intense periods of drought on our warming planet.

title: UCR experts: Newsom's CARE courts an 'oxymoron'
description: Experts on the plight of the unhoused contend the plan would criminalize being poor and mentally ill

title: Experts urge reconsideration of 'standard' for time-keeping
description: To gauge the impacts of dark mornings in some parts of the country, we spoke with two UC Riverside experts

title: Should you get a second booster shot for COVID-19?
description: UC Riverside’s Dr. David Lo, a vaccine expert, shares his thoughts

title: Unusual team finds gigantic planet hidden in plain sight
description: A UC Riverside astronomer and a group of eagle-eyed citizen scientists have discovered a giant gas planet hidden from view by typical stargazing tools.

title: To mask, or not to mask?
description: To gauge whether scientists agree with popular sentiment around mask wearing, we check in here with three UC Riverside virologists and epidemiologists.

title: Free speech, meet Elon Musk's Twitter
description: This week, billionaire Elon Musk struck a deal to buy Twitter for $44 billion. His statements before and since have led many to believe he intends to ease or eliminate content moderation. “Free speech is the bedrock of a functioning democracy, and Twitter is the digital town square where matters vital to the future of humanity are debated,” he said. Here, UCR professor of political science and public policy Kevin Esterling weighs in on Musk's pending acquisition. Esterling is director of the Laboratory for Technology, Communication and Democracy.

title: Prof pours cold water on coffee pod controversy
description: New research from the University of Quebec declares coffee pods are “better for the planet than filtered brew.” Here to weigh in on the matter is UCR's Andrew Gray, who studies the movement of plastic pollutants through the environment.

title: Monkeypox explained
description: UC Riverside experts discuss disease symptoms, vaccines, and anxiety management

title: New center to address health disparities in inland Southern California
description: Five-year, $16 million grant from the National Institutes of Health will help launch Center for Health Disparities Research at UC Riverside

title: Medical school led the way for safe return to classrooms
description: The School of Medicine has lessons to share after several months of in-person classes with no documented cases of COVID-19 transmission

title: Is that a persistent cold, bad allergies, … or long COVID?
description: Dr. Martin Schlusselberg of the UCR School of Medicine explains

title: Manganese in Central Valley water threatens fetuses and children
description: Water in California’s Central Valley contains enough manganese to cause cognitive disabilities and motor control issues in children, and Parkinson’s-like symptoms in adults.

title: 22 Southern California newspapers will be preserved, digitized, and available to the public
description: A John Randolph Haynes and Dora Haynes Foundation grant will help preserve 150 years of local journalism at UC Riverside.

title: Comprehensive digital photography collection and $500k endowment donated to UCR ARTS
description: The gift from Jim and Georgia Steinhart marks the art center’s inaugural born-digital collection and first-ever endowment

title: Monster tumbleweed: Invasive new species is here to stay
description: A new species of gigantic tumbleweed once predicted to go extinct is not only here to stay — it’s likely to expand its territory.  The species, Salsola ryanii, is significantly larger than either of its parent plants, which can grow up to 6 feet tall. A new study from UC Riverside supports the theory that the new tumbleweed grows more vigorously because it is a hybrid with doubled pairs of its parents’ chromosomes.

title: UCR explores collaboration with China’s top educations and entrepreneurs
description: This spring, a University of California, Riverside delegation traveled 6,698 miles west to Guangzhou, Guangdong, and Anhui Province in eastern China to strengthen UCR’s relationships with the region’s top educators, researchers, and government officials. Across the Pacific Ocean, Chancellor Kim A.

title: Hearing amplifies need for funding to support student growth
description: Assembly Select Committee on the California Master Plan for Higher Education deliberates how to best meet the needs of faculty and staff to support future scholars

title: UC Riverside and Chile boost entrepreneurship efforts through partnership
description: Office of Technology Partnerships collaborates with Know Hub Chile to accelerate technology commercialization, transfer, and growth

title: A political mind
description: Mina Hanin's career goals were shaped by his upbringing in Egypt

title: Chancellor closes academic year with end-of-year report
description: UCR’s vision of enrollment, infrastructure, and international growth come to fruition in the 2017-2018 academic year

title: Engineering a better future
description: Souradeep Bhattacharya aims to make an impact where the needs are greatest

title: Racing to the finish line
description: Taylor Brown, track and field champion, nominated for 2018 NCAA Woman of the Year award

title: UC Riverside welcomes first full-time immigration attorney
description: Karina Gutierrez makes the case for expanded legal services for UCR’s immigrant students

title: Winners of 2018 UCR Medallion, Alumni Awards of Distinction Announced
description: Recipients to be honored at Chancellor’s Dinner on Oct. 20

title: Remembering John Frederick Baker
description: Chief engineer who oversaw the transition from the Holiday Inn to the UCR Extension Center passes away at age 86

title: UC Riverside to host solar conference
description: Conference will focus on solar, energy storage systems, and microgrids

title: Shrub encroachment on grasslands can increase groundwater recharge
description: Vegetation changes can outweigh climate change in rangeland water budgets

title: UCR metallurgist available to speak about the science of 'Black Panther'
description: Suveen Mathaudhu is an engineer, educator, and expert on the science of superheroes

title: Here are some of the biggest things that happened at UCR this year
description: Two Nobel Laureates and historic college ratings are among the institution’s accolades in 2018

title: Integrating acquisition and analysis in AI systems
description: UCR engineering professors receive $1.2M Navy grant to make artificial intelligent (AI) systems smarter

title: The unintended consequences of using a ventilator
description: Breakthrough research addresses a long-standing question in pulmonary medicine about whether modern ventilators overstretch lung tissue. They do.

title: UC Riverside helps secure the future of food
description: If you’re eating fruits, nuts, grains, or vegetables in a few years, you’ll likely owe a debt of gratitude to UC Riverside. The university has created a program to transition today’s undergraduates into professional scientists solving tomorrow’s farming challenges. The program, called Plants-3D, will train students to discover, design, and deploy biology and engineering solutions to the projected problem of massive-scale food insecurity due to climate change.

title: Engineering Commencement Speakers Announced
description: David Tsai, this year’s engineering keynote speaker for the Marlan and Rosemary Bourns College of Engineering (BCOE), will follow in his father’s footsteps to inspire tomorrow’s engineers while Crysthal Alvarez, the first engineer in her family, will address her fellow graduates as the student speaker.

title: Inland Empire business activity continues upward climb
description: UCR School of Business report also forecasts limits to future growth due to a tightening labor market in the region and beyond

title: Dance with your soul at UC Riverside’s ‘NOT FESTIVAL’
description: NOT FESTIVAL comes to Southern California, led by UCR’s Luis Lara Malvacías

title: $1 million gift empowers next generation of scientists
description: Undergraduate research is benefactor of gift from Rochelle Campbell and Professor Sue Wessler

title: It’s not easy being green
description: Despite how essential plants are for life on Earth, little is known about how parts of plant cells orchestrate growth and greening. By creating mutant plants, UC Riverside researchers have uncovered a cellular communication pathway sought by scientists for decades.

title: Biologists unravel tangled mystery of plant cell growth
description: When cells don’t divide into proper copies of themselves, living things fail to grow as they should. For the first time, scientists now understand how a protein called TANGLED1 can lead to accurate cell division in plants.

title: Agricultural area residents in danger of inhaling toxic aerosols
description: Excess selenium from fertilizers and other natural sources can create air pollution that could lead to lung cancer, asthma, and Type 2 diabetes, according to new UC Riverside research.

title: Researchers warn of tick-borne disease babesiosis
description: UC Riverside and Yale University team sequences and mines genome of the pathogen Babesia duncani

title: New coronavirus protein reveals drug target
description: Drugs previously in development for SARS could be effective for COVID-19

title: Electromagnetic levitation whips nanomaterials into shape
description: Electromagnetic field directs shape formed by gas phase metal molecules

title: Cleaner water through corn
description: Activated carbon made from corn stover filters 98% of a pollutant from water

title: Nanofiber filter captures almost 100% of coronavirus aerosols
description: The filter could help curb airborne spread of COVID-19 virus

title: Tiny tomatoes could mean big profits for urban agriculture
description: Grants support continued development of tomatoes for vertical farming

title: A new water treatment technology could also help Mars explorers
description: A catalyst that destroys perchlorate in water could clean Martian soil

title: Vaccine exemption process detailed
description: This past week, UCR announced an Aug. 16 deadline for UC Riverside employees and students to upload vaccination records for fall 2021. The message was a follow-up to the UC system’s announcement of a SARS-CoV-2 Vaccination Program that would require vaccinations for employees and students to be on campus for fall 2021.

title: Using light to control materials
description: Supercomputers and machine learning will help scientists optimize light-driven electron transfer

title: Pollution cleanup method destroys toxic “forever chemicals”
description: An insidious category of carcinogenic pollutants known as “forever chemicals” may not be so permanent after all. University of California, Riverside, chemical engineering and environmental scientists recently published new methods to chemically break up these harmful substances found in drinking water into smaller compounds that are essentially harmless.

title: Graduate students create mental health support network
description: R’Grad Peer Support Group meets weekly and is designed to be a nonclinical outlet.

title: Experts on Black Lives Matter
description: For fast access to experts, TEXT or call the 24-hour-experts hotline at 951-312-3049, or email news@ucr.edu.  Michelle C. Burroughs: director of community engagement and outreach for the Center for Healthy Communities. Burroughs is involved with the CHC’s engagement with the community focusing on the Black Lives Matter movement as well as social inequities. She is also a member of Chancellor Kim A. Wilcox’s Campus Safety Taskforce and the School of Medicine Diversity Committee.

title: Fall instruction roadmap released
description: Final decisions about which fall 2021 classes will be in-person are at least several weeks away. But with May registration for fall classes looming, an Instructional Continuity working group has released a roadmap for what fall 2021 will look like. A March 2 letter from Interim Provost Thomas Smith said UCR’s strategy is a return to 75-80% in-person instruction, with department chairs responsible for determining which courses will be in-person and which will be remote.

title: An interview with UCR Engineering parents
description: Parent's of graduating electrical engineering student, Frances and Ruperd Wilson Sr. reflect on their son's time at BCOE.    Q: What inspired Ruperd to attend UCR and become an Electrical Engineer?

title: When disaster strikes, a search website for first responders will save lives
description: Researchers are building a tool that searches real-time text, photo, and video from many sources to help responders allocate resources

title: Mark Rubin, whose philanthropic efforts span UCR, dies at 84
description: Mark Rubin, a Riverside-area property developer, Holocaust survivor, and ardent supporter of education and healthcare in the Inland Empire, died Saturday, February 13, 2021. He was 84.

title: Juvenile incarceration has mixed effects on future convictions
description: Juvenile Incarceration is a double-edged sword and rehabilitation programs may improve welfare of convicted juveniles

title: Building the future for UCR's School of Business
description: Beverly Bailey knows a thing or two about building things.  As a student at Riverside City College, she helped her boyfriend Scott hang patio covers on the weekends. When she turned 20, she bought and ran a small café in Chino, putting her entrepreneurial spirit to the test as she worked some of the longest days of her life. Then she earned her real estate license, making a living helping people build their dream homes.

title: Stanislavski at UC Riverside: A place where actors, scholars meet
description: What does it take to bring together actors and scholars? For Bella Merlin, professor of acting and directing at the University of California, Riverside, it takes a practical acting laboratory. A place where ideas and facts will come together.

title: Can Putin accept peace but also save face?
description: Wednesday, we asked UC Riverside Professor and leading Ukraine-Russia expert Paul D'Anieri to weigh in on breaking developments related to a 15-point peace plan being discussed that could end the month-long war between Ukraine and Russia. The conditions would surround Ukrainian neutrality — with a peace plan's fate dependent on what that means to Ukraine, Russia, and even the West.

title: UCR wins $10 million to develop AI for sustainable agriculture
description: The University of California, Riverside, has won a $10 million grant to develop artificial intelligence that will increase the environmental and economic stability of agriculture in the Western U.S.

title: Experts on Ukraine-Russia
description: The war in Ukraine For fast access to experts, TEXT or call 951-534-8912, or email news@ucr.edu

title: China-Russia: Any alliance is conditional, temporary
description: Related to Russia's ongoing war with Ukraine, China is fielding as many requests for aid from Russia as it's receiving threats from the West about what will happen if it provides that aid. We asked two UC Riverside China experts to provide perspective about the likelihood of all-in Chinese aid to Russia.

title: UCR faculty member's book shares stories of teachers of color
description: “What are you … on their side?” The comment was one of many snarky remarks white teachers made about interactions between a Latino colleague and his diverse student population. In the staff lounge at the Sacramento, Calif., public school, the same teachers called the students “monkeys bouncing off the walls” and “losers.” The Latino teacher pushed back. But he reached a point where it was so frustrating to be in the lounge that he stopped going.

title: Managing earthquakes triggered by oil production
description: A team of scientists has developed an approach to disposing wastewater that reduces the danger of triggering an earthquake.

title: UCR joins forces with NASA on missions to Venus
description: By joining NASA on their newly announced missions, UC Riverside is hoping to learn how Venus went from pleasant, Earth-like planet to blistering wasteland.

title: Following rain, desert microbes exhale potent greenhouse gas
description: New UC Riverside research shows how, after it rains, microbes in desert soil convert one form of pollution into another — laughing gas.

title: Benefactor Esther Fincher Hays leaves a lasting legacy at UCR
description: Esther Fincher Hays, an academic physician, community activist, and philanthropist who supported UC Riverside’s programs in medicine, engineering and music, died June 10, 2021 at her home in Riverside. She was 94 years old. Born in Lexington, Kentucky and raised in Ithaca, NY, Hays attend Cornell University, Cornell Medical School, and completed her internship and residency at New York Hospital. There she met Dr. Daniel M. Hays, whom she married in 1951. In 1954 they moved to Los Angeles, where they raised four children.

title: Board of trustees lead Beyond Brilliant by example
description: There’s more to university life than filling out admissions forms, showing up for classes, and studying for tests. Erik Anderson, an Inland Empire business leader and philanthropist, wants all students at the University of California, Riverside to take advantage of the world-class education they are being offered. And he’s pledging $5 million to help make that happen.

title: UC Riverside launches student-centered Beyond Brilliant
description: No student should have to choose between buying books or food. Or pass up an internship opportunity because they can’t afford gas. Or drop out of school to ease the financial burden on their family. But these choices are a reality for many students who attend the University of California, Riverside.

title: Lifelong UCR advocate Charlie Field dies
description: Charles “Charlie” Field, an attorney, judge, and community leader who was among UC Riverside’s first graduates, died Oct. 29. He was 85 years old.

title: Appreciation for library automation had roots in Vietnam War
description: On hot and steamy days in Saigon, Vietnam, there was only one place for an enlisted man to cool off for a while. “That place was the library,” said UC Riverside alumna Ann Kelsey, who served as a civilian librarian for the U.S. Army from 1969-70. “The libraries were air conditioned because of the books, not the people, though. If they weren’t, the books would mold in two days.”

title: Endowed gift will broaden the horizon for UCR students
description: A $2 million gift from the Pollitt family will fund scholarships that support study abroad opportunities.

title: Art Riggs remembered for pioneering research on diabetes, arthritis and cancer
description: UC Riverside alumnus and friend Arthur D. (Art) Riggs, a pioneering researcher and expert in diabetes who helped launch the biotechnology industry, died March 23, 2022. He was 82.

title: UC Riverside admits most California freshmen among UCs
description: UC Riverside has admitted a record number of freshmen for fall 2022 with a total of 37,262 admits — an increase of 2,591 students from the previous year, according to data released August 10 by the University of California.

title: Five new trustees appointed to UCR Foundation board
description: The UCR Foundation Board of Trustees has welcomed a new chair and five new members, all of whom began their two-year terms July 1.   The 40-member volunteer Board of Trustees oversees UCR’s affiliated foundation, receiving and managing the investment of a $260.2 million endowment as of May 31 that supports the long-term strength of UCR’s research programs, colleges, and scholarship funds. Trustees advocate for UCR and advance its mission by seeking and securing private support for its programs.

title: Late UCR professor honored through endowed award
description: Tom Morton, a professor emeritus of chemistry at the University of California, Riverside, died March 3, 2020. He is remembered as a global citizen and scientist who embraced foreign languages and cultures, demonstrated a cross-disciplinary passion for scientific research, and who showed concern for the environment.

title: Scholarship helps students chart course for science-to-policy careers
description: When six lifelong friends gathered in 2018 for a reunion in California’s Anza-Borrego State Park, they didn’t sit around the campfire telling spooky stories. Instead, they brainstormed ways they could help students at the University of California, Riverside.

title: Join us for UCR’s 2022 Homecoming
description: UC Riverside alumni are invited back to campus for one of the biggest Homecoming celebrations in the university's history. Set for November 18 and 19, the event will celebrate everything UCR — past, present, and future.

title: New Vice Provost & Dean of Undergraduate Education named
description: Louie Rodríguez has been named UC Riverside’s next vice provost and dean of undergraduate education (VPDUE), effective April 1.

title: New Vice Provost & Dean of Graduate Studies named
description: Lidia Kos has been named UC Riverside’s next vice provost & dean of graduate studies, or VPDGS, effective July 15, 2023.

title: Taking photos of slides helps students remember
description: Students often take camera-phone photos of slides during an instructor’s presentation. But the question has lingered whether this practice helps students remember information. A first-of-its-kind study answers the question, finding that taking pictures of PowerPoint slides during an online presentation helped students remember the slide content better than for slides they did not photograph. The study was recently published in the Journal of Applied Research in Memory and Cognition by UC Riverside psychology professor and researcher Annie Ditta.

title: Liking another group doesn't mean you dislike your own
description: More than 70 years ago, a pair of psychologists conducted a study in which they asked young Black girls to choose between Black and white dolls. The girls overwhelmingly chose white dolls, ascribing positive attributes to them. The Black girls’ choices and reasoning were interpreted by study authors to indicate “a feeling of inferiority among African-American children and damaged... self-esteem.” The die was cast in psychology discourse: If you like a group to which you don’t belong — an “outgroup” — it’s because you have bad feelings about your own group — your “ingroup.”

title: UCR pundits predict Democrats will take the Senate
description: Most political scientists and prognosticators predict a GOP win in the U.S. House of Representativeson Nov. 8, and so much of the media’s focus has turned to a tighter suite of contests – those for U.S. Senate seats.

title: Prop 30: A lift for rideshare companies, at the expense of the uber-rich?
description: Proposition 30 would call for Californians earning more than $2 million per year to help fund zero-emission vehicle purchases and infrastructure, and — to a lesser extent — to fund wildfire response and prevention. It would generate between $3.5 to $5 billion annually by taxing the personal incomes of 35,000, or .2% of Californians who account for 30% of the state’s taxable income. Half of the funding dedicated to zero-emissions vehicles, or ZEVs, would go toward rebates for low-to-middle-income residents who buy ZEVs.

title: Ukraine advances don't equal Russian retreat
description: The past week has been one of alternately hopeful and discouraging news in the 7-months-long invasion of Ukraine by Russia. We asked Ukraine expert Paul D'Anieri for guidance on whether the developments signal a winddown in Russian aggression or if they foretell a next, more perilous chapter. D'Anieri wrote the 2019 book “Ukraine and Russia" and a 2007 book, “Understanding Ukrainian Politics: Power, Politics and Institutional Design.” For the 2017-18 academic year, he served as a fellow in the Harvard University Ukrainian Research Institution.

title: Apple TV+ series features UCR professor as 'gratitude expert'
description: The lessons in today’s preschool animated series are a moonshot from the anvil-dropping antics of their parents’-parents’ generation. Case in point: UC Riverside psychology researcher Sonja Lyubomirsky is the “gratitude expert” for a new preschool animated series from Apple TV+, “Sago Mini Friends.”

title: Author revisits lessons of prison yoga
description: The narrative surrounding the virtues of yoga instruction inside prisons is incomplete, according to a UC Riverside professor who taught yoga in prisons for several years and has written a book about the experience. “There is a false narrative, which is ‘if you improve yourself, you won’t get incarcerated,’” said Farah Godrej, an associate professor of political science. “Inside prisons, this idea of self-improvement is used in a way that’s insidious. It becomes an apparatus for telling incarcerated persons that incarceration is their own fault.”

title: China response is less visible, not less dangerous
description: In wake of a renewed COVID-19 lockdown, Chinese citizens protested openly in the streets the past several days. It's a rare display in China, where civil unrest is historically greeted with harsh government recriminations. We asked UCR professors Perry Link and Rich Carpiano to weigh in. Link co-translated The Tiananmen Papers, related to the 1989 democracy protests. In response to his role in the translation, since 1996 he has been blacklisted by China.

title: Skip the angry-letter-never-sent; try a grateful one
description: It’s long been said that writing an angry letter – but not mailing it —– is an effective way of venting without backlash. UC Riverside researchers say the converse — penning letters-never-sent expressing gratitude — carries a benefit, as well. There is an entire area of study in psychology devoted to gratitude, including its benefits and how to practice it. Gratitude, in terms of psychology research, is the acknowledgment of a kindness or benefit from another person. Research has identified expressing gratitude as one of the most successful happiness strategies.

title: Cruising past 'good' and setting their sights on 'great'
description: Coming off its two most successful seasons ever, UC Riverside Men’s Basketball Coach Mike Magpayo said the team was looking to make the jump “from good to great.” The needle is trending toward Magpayo’s goal. Following a win against Idaho on Dec. 11, the men’s team has won five of its last six games. And his players are hot, having captured Big West Player of the Week honors for two of the past three weeks.

title: Is Swift retribution in the offing for Ticketmaster?
description: A chaotic rollout of tickets for Taylor Swift’s upcoming tour has drawn renewed scrutiny of whether Ticketmaster unfairly dominates the ticketing industry, a charge that first surfaced in earnest in a 1990s skirmish with the grunge band Pearl Jam. We asked UCR experts whether Ticketmaster is a monopoly and should be subjected to antitrust action.

title: 'Rockonomics' professor: Ticketmaster gets a bad rap
description: A chaotic rollout of tickets for Taylor Swift’s upcoming tour has drawn renewed scrutiny of whether Ticketmaster unfairly dominates the ticketing industry.
